Clinical Pearls

• Always consider PML in natalizumab-treated MS patients with new focal deficits, especially non-enhancing MRI lesions.
• Early CSF JC virus PCR confirms diagnosis; sensitivity ~80%, but a negative result may need repeat testing if clinical suspicion remains high.
• Monitor for immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) after PLEX; low-dose steroids may be needed to control IRIS.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misidentifying PML lesions as MS relapses and treating with steroids, which worsens prognosis.
2. Assuming drug discontinuation alone suffices—delayed immune recovery can lead to rapid neurological decline.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AAN Practice Advisory on PML Management (2020): Class I, Level A evidence supports plasma exchange (3–5 sessions) to accelerate natalizumab clearance.
• European Medicines Agency Label Update (2019): Recommends therapeutic plasma exchange within 14 days of PML diagnosis for natalizumab-associated cases.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• Hemiparesis: involvement of corticospinal fibers in internal capsule and adjacent subcortical white matter.
• Hemianopia: occipital lobe and optic radiations in the parietal/temporal white matter are common PML sites.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• JC virus remains latent in kidney and lymphoid tissue; immunosuppression (natalizumab) allows reactivation and CNS entry.
• Virus infects oligodendrocytes, causing lytic demyelination without inflammatory contrast enhancement on MRI.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. New focal neurological deficits in natalizumab patient → urgent brain MRI
2. MRI: non-enhancing, T2/FLAIR hyperintense subcortical lesions → suspect PML
3. CSF for JC virus PCR → confirm diagnosis
4. Immediately discontinue natalizumab and initiate plasmapheresis
5. Monitor for IRIS and manage supportively

Neuroimaging Pearls

• PML lesions: asymmetric, non-enhancing, lack mass effect, often involve U-fibers.
• Lack of gadolinium enhancement helps distinguish from MS relapse or lymphoma.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Plasmapheresis protocol: 3–5 exchanges (1–1.5 plasma volumes) over 7–14 days; monitor for hypocalcemia.
• IRIS management: low-dose steroids (e.g., prednisone 0.5 mg/kg) if significant edema.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) encephalitis is the most common sporadic viral encephalitis in adults, characterized by hemorrhagic necrosis of the temporal and inferior frontal lobes. Following reactivation in the trigeminal ganglion, HSV travels via axonal transport to the CNS. Patients present with fever, headache, focal seizures, altered mental status and behavioral changes. Acyclovir—a nucleoside analogue activated by viral thymidine kinase—blocks viral DNA polymerase, halting replication. Prompt initiation of intravenous therapy is critical; inadequate duration risks persistent viral replication and relapse. International guidelines endorse a treatment window of 14–21 days in immunocompetent adults to ensure eradication from CNS reservoirs and minimize morbidity and mortality.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) 2013 guidelines (updated online 2021) recommend intravenous acyclovir at 10 mg/kg every 8 hours for 14–21 days in immunocompetent adults (Level II-2 evidence). A meta-analysis of cohort studies found a 70% reduction in mortality when therapy was extended ≥14 days versus shorter courses. The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice parameter (2007) similarly supports a minimum 14-day regimen, with extension to 21 days reserved for immunocompromised patients or those with persistently positive CSF PCR at day 14. Early treatment within 48 hours of symptom onset optimizes CNS drug penetration; standard pharmacokinetics achieve therapeutic CSF levels by day 3–4. Courses shorter than 14 days correlate with relapse rates >10%, whereas a 14-day regimen maintains relapse <5% in immunocompetent hosts.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 7 days
• Too brief to eradicate HSV from CNS parenchyma.
• Reflects confusion with typical durations for bacterial meningitis adjuncts, not viral encephalitis.
• Underestimates risk of relapse and incomplete resolution seen in RCTs.

C. 21 days
• While 21 days can be used in immunocompromised or PCR-positive patients, it exceeds the minimal recommended duration for immunocompetent adults.
• Commonly mistaken as “standard” when it is actually the upper end of a range.

D. 72 hours
• Duration matches empiric antibiotic “window” before LP, not antiviral therapy.
• Reflects misunderstanding of acute management timelines versus full antiviral course.

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate empiric acyclovir immediately on suspicion of viral encephalitis—do not await PCR results.
• Ensure adequate IV hydration and monitor creatinine; acyclovir is nephrotoxic if crystals precipitate.
• Consider repeat CSF PCR at day 14 if clinical symptoms persist to guide extension to 21 days.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Discontinuing acyclovir once fever resolves rather than completing the full 14-day course.
• Mistaking focal deficits and acute confusion for stroke and delaying antiviral therapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines for Management of Encephalitis (2013; online update 2021): IV acyclovir 10 mg/kg q8h for 14–21 days (Level II-2).
• ESCMID Guidelines on Viral Encephalitis (2017): Recommend a minimum 14-day acyclovir regimen in immunocompetent adults (Consensus-based).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

HSV-1 shows tropism for the limbic system—particularly the medial temporal lobes and orbitofrontal cortex—leading to characteristic personality changes, memory impairment and focal seizures.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

After latent infection in trigeminal ganglia, HSV-1 reactivates and travels retrograde to the CNS. Viral replication in neuronal nuclei triggers an intense inflammatory response, resulting in hemorrhagic necrosis and blood–brain barrier disruption.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Emergency CT/MRI to exclude mass lesion
2. Lumbar puncture: lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, normal/low glucose
3. CSF PCR for HSV DNA (sensitivity ~98%)
4. Empiric IV acyclovir within hours of presentation
5. MRI with FLAIR/DWI for characteristic temporal lobe changes

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI FLAIR: hyperintense signal in medial temporal lobes
• GRE/SWI sequences reveal petechial hemorrhages typical of HSV necrosis

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mechanism: Acyclovir is phosphorylated by viral thymidine kinase → inhibits viral DNA polymerase.
• Dosing: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (adjust for creatinine clearance)
• Duration: minimum 14 days; monitor for nephrotoxicity and adjust hydration accordingly.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] • Segmental myelopathies: lesions extending ≥3 vertebral segments on T2‐weighted MRI often indicate infections (HTLV-1, HIV, CMV) or NMO spectrum disorders rather than classical MS.
• Oligoclonal bands: “unpaired” (CSF‐only) IgG bands reflect intrathecal synthesis, seen in inflammatory myelopathies including HTLV-1–associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP).
• Epidemiology and pathogenesis: HTLV-1 is endemic in parts of Africa, Japan, and the Caribbean; it infects CD4+ T cells leading to chronic inflammation of the spinal cord, predominantly affecting corticospinal tracts.

Evidence-Based Analysis

HTLV-1–associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP) is characterized by slowly progressive spastic paraparesis, sensory ataxia, and sphincter dysfunction. MRI shows a longitudinally extensive lesion (often thoracic), with T2 hyperintensity spanning multiple segments; enhancement is variable. CSF reveals elevated protein and intrathecal IgG bands without matched serum bands (unpaired OCBs).
Osame et al. (Ann Neurol 1990) established diagnostic criteria: clinical features + seropositivity for anti–HTLV-1 antibodies in serum/CSF. No standardized IDSA guidelines exist, but the 2020 Clinical Infectious Diseases consensus recommends proviral load measurement to gauge disease activity (Level B evidence). HAM/TSP lesions differ from MS (<2 segments, periventricular brain lesions) and CMV polyradiculomyelitis (acute onset, high CSF pleocytosis).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. HIV
• Vacuolar myelopathy occurs in advanced HIV with spongiform changes, not longitudinally extensive T2 lesions; MRI is often normal or shows diffuse cord atrophy. OCBs are matched (serum + CSF).
• Misconception: any viral infection in immunocompromised will produce long cord lesions. Differentiator: HIV myelopathy is late‐stage, with concomitant brain atrophy and cognitive decline.

C. CMV
• CMV myeloradiculitis presents acutely in severely immunosuppressed (e.g., AIDS CD4<50), with polyradicular pain, rapid progression, high CSF neutrophils & protein. MRI may show nerve root enhancement rather than a continuous thoracolumbar T2 lesion.
• Misconception: CMV causes any extensive spinal cord lesion. Differentiator: acute onset, CSF pleocytosis, radicular enhancement.

D. Progressive MS
• Progressive MS features multifocal brain lesions (periventricular, juxtacortical) and short spinal lesions (<2 vertebral segments); cerebellar signs often present. OCBs are matched in serum and CSF.
• Misconception: progressive course + OCBs = MS. Differentiator: lesion length, distribution, lack of brain MRI lesions.

2. Assuming matched OCBs = HAM/TSP; in reality, HAM/TSP shows unmatched CSF bands.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• WHO HTLV-1 Counseling and Testing Guidelines (2016): Recommends screening pregnant women in endemic areas; diagnosis via ELISA + confirmatory Western blot (Level B).
• CIoDa Expert Consensus on HAM/TSP (Clinical Infectious Diseases 2020): Advises measurement of HTLV-1 proviral load for monitoring (Level B); suggests corticosteroids as first-line immunotherapy.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The lateral corticospinal tracts (motor) and dorsal columns (proprioception) in the thoracic spinal cord are preferentially damaged by chronic HTLV-1–mediated inflammation, leading to spasticity and sensory ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

HTLV-1 infects CD4+ T lymphocytes; Tax viral protein drives release of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g., IFN-γ, TNF-α), resulting in chronic immune-mediated destruction of spinal cord white matter.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Exclude compressive myelopathy via MRI.
2. Identify longitudinally extensive T2 signal.
3. Perform CSF analysis: protein, cell count, OCB pattern.
4. Test serum and CSF for anti–HTLV-1 antibodies; confirm with Western blot.
5. Measure proviral load for prognosis.
6. Rule out differential (HIV, CMV, NMO, MS) with appropriate serologies/PCR.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Long spinal cord hyperintensity spanning ≥3 segments without significant enhancement or mass effect is hallmark of HAM/TSP; lack of contrast enhancement helps differentiate from active MS or CMV.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No curative antiviral exists; corticosteroids (e.g., high-dose methylprednisolone) may transiently improve symptoms. Interferon-α 3 MU subcutaneously three times weekly has shown modest benefit in small trials (Osame et al., J Infect Dis 2005).

[Exam: Part II 2019] Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) is a rapidly fatal central nervous system infection caused by Naegleria fowleri, a free‐living amoeba found in warm freshwater.
• Neuroanatomy: Olfactory neuroepithelium lies adjacent to the cribriform plate; olfactory nerve filaments traverse the plate to synapse in the olfactory bulb.
• Pathophysiology: Trophozoites adhere to the nasal mucosa, migrate along olfactory nerves through the cribriform plate, invade frontal lobes, causing hemorrhagic necrosis.
• Epidemiology: Incidence is extremely low (<0.003 cases/million), but case‐fatality exceeds 97%. Early recognition hinges on recent freshwater exposure and fulminant meningoencephalitic presentation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct: Naegleria fowleri trophozoites enter the CNS by traversing the olfactory nerve fibers through the cribriform plate. Martinez and Janitschke (1977) first demonstrated this route in animal models; subsequent human autopsy series corroborate olfactory bulb hemorrhagic necrosis at the cribriform interface. The CDC’s 2018 guidelines emphasize that nasal irrigation with contaminated water can seed trophozoites into the olfactory mucosa, which then penetrate the central nervous system. Clinically, onset is abrupt (1–9 days post‐exposure) with fever, headache, and rapidly progressive meningoencephalitis—without prompt amphotericin B and adjunctive miltefosine, mortality approaches 100% (Seidel et al., 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. It is self-limited.
• Why incorrect: PAM uniformly progresses to death within days to weeks.
• Misconception: Confusing with chronic granulomatous amebic encephalitis by Acanthamoeba spp., which has a subacute course.
• Differentiator: PAM’s fulminant course contrasts with self‐limiting viral meningitis.

C. It is very common.
• Why incorrect: Fewer than 300 cases reported worldwide since 1965.
• Misconception: Equating freshwater exposure risk with high incidence.
• Differentiator: Incidence <0.003 per million versus bacterial meningitis (2–10/100,000 annually).

D. It is caused by a bacterial infection.
• Why incorrect: Etiologic agent is a thermophilic protozoan, not bacteria.
• Misconception: Assuming purulent CSF pleocytosis always indicates bacterial etiology.
• Differentiator: Wet mount of CSF shows motile amoebae, not Gram‐positive/negative organisms.

Clinical Pearls

- Always ask about recent freshwater exposure (lakes, rivers, heated pools) in rapidly progressive meningoencephalitis.
• Examine a fresh CSF wet mount for motile trophozoites; standard cultures and Gram stain are often negative.
• Early combination therapy with high‐dose amphotericin B (intrathecal and IV) plus oral miltefosine and fluconazole offers the best chance for survival.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing Naegleria fowleri (PAM) with Acanthamoeba spp. granulomatous encephalitis; the former is acute, the latter subacute/chronic.
• Misattributing neutrophil‐predominant CSF pleocytosis solely to bacterial meningitis and delaying amoebic-specific therapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) Guidelines on Free-Living Amebae (2014; updated 2018): Recommend combination therapy with amphotericin B (level II evidence), fluconazole, azithromycin, rifampin, and miltefosine.
• CDC MMWR “Treatment of Primary Amebic Meningoencephalitis with Miltefosine — United States, 2013” (2018 update): Case series suggest adjunctive miltefosine reduces trophozoite load and improves survival (level III evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Trophozoites adhere to the olfactory receptor neurons in the nasal mucosa, migrate along the fila olfactoria through the lamina cribrosa of the ethmoid bone, reach the olfactory bulb, and then spread into the frontal lobes, causing necrosis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Naegleria fowleri trophozoites produce cytolytic proteins (e.g., pore-forming amoebapore) and phospholipases that disrupt host cell membranes and the blood–brain barrier, leading to hemorrhagic necrosis and intense neutrophilic inflammation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: Freshwater exposure + rapid neurologic decline
2. CSF analysis: Neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, low glucose
3. Wet mount: Motile, amoeboid trophozoites
4. Confirmatory: PCR for Naegleria fowleri DNA or immunofluorescence

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI may reveal early unilateral olfactory bulb hyperintensity, hemorrhagic necrosis of frontal lobes, and cerebral edema. CT often shows diffuse cerebral swelling without meningeal enhancement.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Amphotericin B: IV 1–1.5 mg/kg/day + intrathecal 1.5 mg/day
• Miltefosine: 50 mg TID orally (adult) for at least 28 days
• Adjuncts: Fluconazole 200 mg BID, azithromycin 500 mg daily, rifampin 600 mg daily

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Brucella species are small, facultative intracellular, gram-negative coccobacilli that invade macrophages and replicate within the reticuloendothelial system. Effective treatment requires antibiotics with high intracellular penetration and prolonged course to prevent relapse. First-line regimens combine a tetracycline (doxycycline) with either an aminoglycoside or rifampin for at least six weeks. In neurobrucellosis, third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone) or aminoglycosides are added to doxycycline–rifampin to enhance CNS penetration.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Doxycycline (100 mg PO bid for ≥6 weeks) is the cornerstone of brucellosis therapy due to excellent intracellular distribution and oral bioavailability. The World Health Organization (2022) and the Infectious Diseases Society of America (2020) both recommend doxycycline + rifampin for uncomplicated brucellosis (Level A evidence). A landmark randomized trial (Solís et al., 2000) demonstrated that doxycycline plus rifampin yields relapse rates <10%, similar to doxycycline plus streptomycin but with better tolerability. For neurobrucellosis (not specified here), doxycycline and rifampin are supplemented with ceftriaxone or an aminoglycoside to ensure adequate CNS levels (Pappas et al., 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Ceftriaxone
– Monotherapy provides insufficient intracellular activity against Brucella.
– Often used adjunctively for neurobrucellosis, not as sole agent.

C. Rifampin
– Rifampin monotherapy leads to relapse rates >30%.
– Potent CYP450 inducer causing significant drug interactions.

D. Streptomycin
– Aminoglycoside monotherapy has high relapse and requires parenteral administration.
– Ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity limit its use as sole therapy.

Clinical Pearls

1. Always use combination therapy (doxycycline + rifampin) for at least 6 weeks to reduce relapse.
2. In neurobrucellosis, add ceftriaxone (2 g daily) or an aminoglycoside for optimal CNS penetration.
3. Monitor liver enzymes with doxycycline–rifampin regimens and renal function with aminoglycosides.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Selecting monotherapy (e.g., rifampin alone) due to ease of administration; leads to high relapse.
2. Underestimating duration—courses <6 weeks are associated with treatment failure.
3. Assuming third-generation cephalosporins alone suffice for Brucella; they lack adequate intracellular bactericidal activity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- World Health Organization Technical Report Series, 2022: Recommends doxycycline 100 mg bid + rifampin 600–900 mg daily for 6 weeks in uncomplicated brucellosis (Grade A).
• IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines, 2020: Endorses either doxycycline + streptomycin or doxycycline + rifampin; highlights doxycycline–rifampin as outpatient standard (Level I evidence).
• Solís et al., Clinical Infectious Diseases, 2000 (RCT): Demonstrated non-inferiority of doxycycline–rifampin vs doxycycline–streptomycin (relapse <10%).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect brucellosis in febrile patients with livestock exposure or consumption of unpasteurized dairy.
2. Obtain blood cultures (may require prolonged incubation) and serology (standard agglutination, ELISA).
3. Use PCR in CSF when neurobrucellosis is suspected.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Doxycycline: 100 mg PO bid for ≥6 weeks; penetrates macrophages.
• Rifampin: 600–900 mg PO daily; monitor for hepatotoxicity and drug–drug interactions.
• Streptomycin: 1 g IM daily for 2–3 weeks if used; monitor renal function and audiometry.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Neuroretinitis presents as optic disc edema followed days later by a macular “star” of lipid-rich exudates in Henle’s layer of the outer plexiform layer. Increased vascular permeability at the optic nerve head allows lipoproteinaceous fluid to radiate in a petaloid pattern around the fovea. Bartonella henselae, transmitted via cat scratch or bite, is the most common cause of infectious neuroretinitis (cat scratch disease). Recognizing the classic funduscopic signs—disc swelling with yellow-orange exudates—is critical for prompt antimicrobial therapy and optimizing visual recovery. (73 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Bartonella henselae infects small vessel endothelium, triggering focal vasculitis of retinal and optic nerve head vessels. Serous leakage produces the macular star exudates in ~50% of neuroretinitis cases. The AAO Preferred Practice Pattern: Uveitis (2018) recommends Bartonella serology in patients with neuroretinitis (Level II evidence). IDSA guidelines for Cat Scratch Disease (Carithers et al., Clin Infect Dis 2006) endorse oral azithromycin as first-line therapy (Grade B, Level II), showing reduction in symptom duration. Spectral-domain OCT studies (Chen et al., Ophthalmology 2019) demonstrate hyperreflective foci in Henle’s layer corresponding to orange-yellow exudates on fundus exam, confirming Bartonella henselae as the predominant pathogen in this presentation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. TB
• Causes chorioretinitis with serpiginous-like choroidal lesions, not optic disc edema with exudative macular star.
• Misconception: equating any posterior segment inflammation with neuroretinitis.
• Differentiator: TB lesions localize to the choroid and lack classic macular star.

C. CMV
• In immunocompromised hosts, CMV retinitis shows granular “pizza-pie” lesions with hemorrhages, not discrete lipid exudates.
• Misconception: assuming viral etiologies uniformly produce macular stars.
• Differentiator: prominent hemorrhages and minimal exudative patterns in CMV.

D. Toxoplasmosis
• Presents as focal necrotizing retinitis adjacent to old pigmented scars (“headlight in the fog”) with dense vitritis, without macular star.
• Misconception: attributing any white retinal lesion to toxoplasmosis.
• Differentiator: active lesion with overlying vitreous haze, absence of optic disc star pattern.

• Fluorescein angiography: early disc hyperfluorescence with late leakage.
• Early azithromycin (500 mg day 1, then 250 mg daily) improves recovery.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking macular star exudates for diabetic/hypertensive maculopathy; correlate with optic disc edema timing.
2. Failing to order Bartonella serology in immunocompetent patients with neuroretinitis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Carithers RL Jr et al., IDSA Practice Guidelines for Cat Scratch Disease (Clin Infect Dis 2006): Recommends oral azithromycin for moderate disease (Grade B, Level II).
• American Academy of Ophthalmology, Preferred Practice Pattern: Uveitis (2018): Advises Bartonella serologic testing in neuroretinitis (Level II).
• Chen E et al., “OCT Features of Neuroretinitis” (Ophthalmology 2019): Correlated Henle’s layer hyperreflectivity with clinical exudates.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Exudates localize in Henle’s fiber layer (outer plexiform layer) of the macula, where photoreceptor axons radiate, producing the star configuration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

B. henselae infects vascular endothelium, inciting immune-mediated vascular permeability at the optic nerve head; lipid-rich plasma exudes into the outer plexiform layer forming the macular star.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Elicit history: cat exposure, lymphadenopathy.
2. Fundoscopy: look for optic disc edema + macular star.
3. Serology: Bartonella henselae IgM/IgG.
4. OCT & fluorescein angiography to confirm exudates & disc leakage.
5. Initiate azithromycin; consider doxycycline/rifampin for severe cases.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- OCT: subretinal fluid and hyperreflective foci in Henle’s layer.
• Fluorescein angiography: early disc leakage before exudation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Azithromycin: 500 mg PO on day 1, then 250 mg daily ×4 days.
• Alternatives: Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID or Rifampin 300 mg PO BID for 4–6 weeks.
• Avoid steroids until adequate antibiotic coverage.

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Subdural empyema is an extra‐axial accumulation of purulent fluid between the dura and arachnoid, often originating from contiguous infection (sinusitis, otitis) or post‐traumatic seeding. Key points:
• Anatomy of the subdural space – lies superficial to the arachnoid, bridged by cortical veins.
• Pathophysiology – bacterial colonization produces an inflammatory exudate that can rapidly cause mass effect and venous thrombosis.
• Neuroimaging – MRI with contrast and diffusion‐weighted sequences show a crescentic, rim‐enhancing collection with restricted diffusion, distinguishing it from other entities.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Subdural abscess
• “Subdural abscess” is an archaic term; current nomenclature uses “empyema.” More importantly, intracerebral abscesses are intra‐axial, exhibit central necrosis with peripheral capsule, and do not outline the subdural space.
• Misconception: equating abscess with empyema.
• Differentiation: intraparenchymal abscess shows central diffusion restriction within brain tissue, not crescentic extra‐axial.

B. TB meningitis
• Presents subacutely with basal meningeal enhancement, hydrocephalus, cranial nerve palsies, CSF lymphocytosis, elevated protein, low glucose.
• Misconception: constitutional symptoms (night sweats, weight loss) = TB always.
• Differentiation: no focal extra‐axial collection or restricted diffusion on MRI.

D. Brain tumor
• Neoplasms may cause weight loss (“B symptoms”) but seldom fever or night sweats. Imaging shows a solid or ring‐enhancing intra‐axial mass with vasogenic edema, not a crescentic extra‐axial collection.
• Misconception: associating any contrast‐enhancing lesion with tumor.
• Differentiation: tumors lack restricted diffusion of purulent material and are not confined to the subdural space.

Clinical Pearls

1. Subdural empyema is a neurosurgical emergency—delay increases mortality to >50%. Early MRI with DWI is critical.
2. DWI hyperintensity in an extra‐axial crescentic collection differentiates empyema from chronic subdural hematoma (no diffusion restriction).
3. Look for sinus or mastoid source; up to 40% of cases originate from paranasal sinusitis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling subdural empyema as “subdural hematoma” in a febrile patient—key DWI and enhancement differences.
2. Over‐attributing constitutional symptoms (night sweats, weight loss) to TB meningitis without correlating imaging findings.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. IDSA Guidelines on Management of Brain Abscess and Subdural Empyema (2023 update): recommends immediate neurosurgical drainage with empirical coverage (ceftriaxone + metronidazole ± vancomycin) (Level II).
2. EFNS/EAN Consensus on Intracranial Infections (2021): emphasizes DWI MRI for early diagnosis and advocates 6–8 weeks of tailored antimicrobial therapy post‐drainage (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Bridging veins traverse the subdural space; infection here risks venous thrombosis and cortical infarction. The thin arachnoid impedes reabsorption of purulent fluid.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Bacteria seed the subdural compartment via contiguous spread or hematogenous routes, triggering cytokine‐mediated inflammation, exudate formation, elevated intracranial pressure and venous congestion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect in febrile patient with headache ± focal deficits.
2. Urgent MRI with contrast + DWI.
3. Blood cultures; avoid lumbar puncture until imaging rules out mass effect.
4. Neurosurgical drainage.
5. Tailored intravenous antibiotics for 6–8 weeks.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• DWI: high signal in empyema due to restricted diffusion of pus.
• Contrast: smooth, uniform rim enhancement along dura.
• May show midline shift and cortical venous thrombosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Empirical regimen: vancomycin (15–20 mg/kg q8–12h), ceftriaxone (2 g IV q12h), metronidazole (500 mg IV q8h) pending cultures; adjust duration to 6–8 weeks based on intraoperative cultures.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. Subdural empyema is frequently tested as an emergency requiring rapid imaging and neurosurgical referral; image‐based stems often focus on DWI vs enhancement patterns for differentiation.

The correct answer is C. Subdural empyema. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Part II 2018] West Nile virus (WNV) is an arthropod‐borne Flavivirus that can cause neuroinvasive disease by crossing the blood–brain barrier. Key concepts:
1. Virology: WNV is a single‐stranded RNA Flavivirus transmitted by Culex mosquitoes.
2. Pathogenesis: Neuroinvasion leads to meningoencephalitis, anterior horn cell infection (flaccid paralysis), and basal ganglia/thalami involvement.
3. Management principle: No specific antivirals are approved; care centers on critical supportive measures (airway, fluids, seizure control).

(Word count: 85)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive care is the cornerstone of management for WNV encephalitis. There are no antiviral agents with proven efficacy: ribavirin and interferon‐α have shown in vitro activity but failed to demonstrate clinical benefit in controlled or observational studies (Sejvar et al., 2003, Clin Infect Dis). A 2020 CDC guideline emphasizes aggressive supportive measures—respiratory support, hemodynamic stabilization, seizure management—and close monitoring in an intensive care setting for patients with decreased consciousness or respiratory compromise (CDC, 2020). Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and corticosteroids remain investigational; randomized trials are lacking and case series do not support routine use.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Antiviral therapy
– Incorrect: No licensed antivirals (e.g., acyclovir) target WNV.
– Misconception: Treat all viral encephalitides like HSV with acyclovir.
– Differentiator: WNV is resistant to nucleoside analogues used for herpesviruses.

C. Corticosteroids
– Incorrect: Steroids may dampen antiviral immunity; no trials show benefit.
– Misconception: “All encephalitis benefits from anti‐inflammatory therapy.”
– Differentiator: Steroids are reserved for autoimmune encephalitis, not WNV.

D. Immunoglobulin therapy
– Incorrect: IVIG with high anti‐WNV titers is investigational; no phase III data.
– Misconception: Passive immunization universally effective in viral infections.
– Differentiator: No proven mortality or morbidity reduction in WNV.

1. In WNV encephalitis, CSF shows lymphocytic pleocytosis with elevated protein; CSF IgM confirms diagnosis.
2. Risk factors for severe neuroinvasive disease include age >60, immunosuppression, and diabetes.
3. Avoid unnecessary antivirals or steroids; focus on intracranial pressure management and seizure prophylaxis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Starting acyclovir empirically for WNV encephalitis—acyclovir covers HSV/VZV but not Flaviviruses.
2. Prescribing high‐dose steroids in viral encephalitis—steroids are contraindicated unless autoimmune etiology is confirmed.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. CDC (2020) “West Nile Virus Clinical Guidelines”: Recommends supportive care only; no antiviral or immunomodulatory therapy (Level CIII).
2. ACIP/IDSA Vector‐Borne Disease Guidelines (2018): Advise against routine use of IVIG or corticosteroids; emphasize surveillance and preventive measures (Level CII).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

WNV targets anterior horn cells causing acute flaccid paralysis and infects deep gray nuclei (basal ganglia, thalami) leading to movement disorders and altered consciousness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

After mosquito inoculation, WNV replicates in dendritic cells, enters circulation, crosses the blood–brain barrier via infected leukocytes or endothelial transcytosis, and induces neuronal apoptosis through cytokine‐mediated inflammation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in endemic season with fever, headache, altered mental status.
2. MRI: T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in thalami, basal ganglia, brainstem.
3. CSF analysis: Lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein; confirm with CSF WNV IgM (ELISA).
4. Supportive care; monitor for respiratory failure.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI often shows bilateral thalamic and basal ganglia hyperintensities, occasionally involving mesial temporal lobes—distinguishing from HSV which favors temporal lobes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No approved antivirals; investigational therapies (ribavirin, interferon‐α, high‐titer IVIG) remain unproven. Management focuses on supportive interventions.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) arises from JC polyomavirus reactivation in patients with impaired CNS immunosurveillance. Natalizumab, an anti–α4-integrin monoclonal antibody, blocks lymphocyte trafficking across the blood–brain barrier, increasing PML risk significantly after ~24 months of therapy. Clinically, PML presents subacutely—over weeks to months—with progressive cognitive decline, dysarthria, visual deficits, or motor weakness, contrasting with the more acute, steroid-responsive relapses of multiple sclerosis. Key neuroimmunological concepts include oligodendrocyte infection by JC virus, the role of integrins in leukocyte endothelial adhesion, and characteristic MRI patterns (nonenhancing, confluent T2/FLAIR lesions without mass effect).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Natalizumab-associated PML risk was quantified by Bloomgren et al. (N Engl J Med 2012;366:1870–1880), showing an overall incidence of ~4.2 per 1,000 patients after 24 months. By inhibiting α4-integrin, natalizumab reduces CNS T-cell surveillance, permitting JC virus lytic infection of oligodendrocytes. The American Academy of Neurology’s 2018 guideline recommends baseline and semiannual anti–JC virus antibody (JCV Ab) testing; a JCV Ab index >1.5 correlates with high PML risk (Class II evidence). MRI in early PML demonstrates asymmetric, subcortical T2/FLAIR hyperintensities often involving U-fibers, without mass effect or with punctate “milky way” enhancement. Definitive diagnosis requires CSF JC virus PCR (sensitivity ~80–90%, specificity >95%). In contrast, MS relapses and ADEM produce contrast-enhancing lesions and typically improve with corticosteroids. Immediate natalizumab cessation and plasma exchange are critical to accelerate immune reconstitution and mitigate progression.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis
• Presentation: RRMS relapses are acute (<2 weeks), focal, steroid-responsive, and often include partial recovery.
• Misconception: New cognitive or speech deficits in MS patients always represent a relapse.
• Differentiator: PML symptoms evolve insidiously over weeks to months, with poor steroid response and distinct MRI features (nonenhancing, confluent white matter lesions).

C. Secondary progressive multiple sclerosis
• Presentation: SPMS shows gradual neurological decline over years, often with accumulating disability and fewer active inflammatory lesions.
• Misconception: Progressive deterioration in MS after natalizumab indicates SPMS.
• Differentiator: SPMS lacks the subacute onset of new focal deficits and JC virus positivity; MRI shows marked atrophy and “black holes,” not acute demyelinating lesions.

D. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM)
• Presentation: Typically a monophasic, post-infectious or post-vaccination demyelination in children/young adults with encephalopathy.
• Misconception: Any new demyelinating event in MS patients resembles ADEM.
• Differentiator: ADEM lesions are large, often symmetric, with uniform enhancement; clinical course is monophasic with good steroid response, unlike PML.

Clinical Pearls

1. Anti–JC virus antibody index testing every 6 months stratifies natalizumab PML risk; index >1.5 is high-risk.
2. Extended-interval dosing (6–8 weeks) of natalizumab may halve the risk of PML compared to standard 4-week dosing.
3. Surveillance brain MRI at 3–4 month intervals can detect asymptomatic PML lesions, improving outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing subacute cognitive decline to MS relapse rather than PML in natalizumab-treated patients.
2. Expecting PML lesions to uniformly enhance; early PML often lacks enhancement or shows punctate “milky way” patterns.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology, “Evidence-based guideline update: Monitoring for PML in natalizumab-treated MS patients,” 2018. Recommends baseline and semiannual anti–JCV Ab testing and brain MRI every 3–4 months (Level B).
2. European Medicines Agency PRAC, “Assessment of natalizumab extended interval dosing,” 2019. Advises considering 6–8 week dosing intervals after 24 months to reduce PML risk (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PML lesions preferentially involve subcortical U-fibers and watershed zones in frontal, parietal, and occipital lobes, reflecting oligodendrocyte JC virus tropism in these regions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

JC virus infects oligodendrocytes and astrocytes; natalizumab-induced blockade of α4-integrin impairs CD4+ and CD8+ T-cell CNS entry, allowing unchecked viral replication and demyelination without robust inflammatory response.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. High clinical suspicion in natalizumab-treated patient with new subacute cognitive/motor deficits
2. Brain MRI with T2/FLAIR and contrast sequences
3. CSF analysis including JC virus PCR
4. Immediate natalizumab discontinuation and plasma exchange if PCR positive

Neuroimaging Pearls

Early PML lesions: T2/FLAIR hyperintense, ill-defined without mass effect; later may show punctate or peripheral enhancement (“milky way” sign) and variable diffusion restriction.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Natalizumab blocks α4-integrin on lymphocytes, preventing CNS entry. Upon PML diagnosis, plasmapheresis accelerates drug clearance; no proven antiviral exists, though mirtazapine (5-HT2A antagonist) and mefloquine have been used experimentally.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Recognition of PML risk with natalizumab and its subacute presentation is a frequently tested concept on neurology board examinations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is a rapidly progressive, fatal prionopathy characterized by:
• Misfolded prion protein (PrP^Sc) accumulation leading to spongiform cortical and subcortical degeneration.
• MRI diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) “cortical ribbon” hyperintensity reflecting laminar cortical injury.
• Absence of any disease-modifying therapy; management is palliative/supportive, focusing on symptom control and family counseling.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The definitive management of sporadic CJD remains supportive and palliative:
• No surgical or radiotherapeutic interventions alter the course of prion diseases (Budka et al., Lancet Neurol 2015).
• Reassurance encompasses clear communication of prognosis, symptomatic treatment (e.g., anticonvulsants for myoclonus), and involvement of palliative care teams (World Health Organization, Prion Disease Report 2018).
• Routine serial MRI has no impact on clinical decisions, as progression is relentless and imaging changes correlate poorly with symptom trajectories (Geschwind et al., Neurology 2013).
• Current CDC and European CJD Surveillance Network guidelines (2020) emphasize prompt diagnosis—DWI MRI, EEG periodic sharp waves, CSF RT-QuIC—and early initiation of supportive measures over any investigational therapy outside clinical trials.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Surgery
• Incorrect: CJD causes diffuse neurodegeneration, not a discrete lesion amenable to resection.
• Misconception: equating “cortical ribbon” with a mass lesion.
• Differentiator: absence of a surgical target; pathology is molecular, not structural.

C. Radiotherapy
• Incorrect: Radiotherapy treats neoplastic or inflammatory lesions, not prion-induced spongiform change.
• Misconception: hyperintense MRI signals represent tumor or inflammatory foci.
• Differentiator: prion diseases lack radiosensitive cellular targets.

D. Yearly MRI
• Incorrect: Surveillance imaging does not change management or prognosis; CJD progression is clinically evident.
• Misconception: believing that tracking radiologic changes can guide interventions.
• Differentiator: no disease-modifying therapies informed by imaging stage.

Clinical Pearls

- Cerebrospinal fluid RT-QuIC assay has >90% sensitivity and specificity for sporadic CJD.
• Periodic sharp-wave complexes on EEG emerge in ~60–70% of cases after symptom onset.
• Early palliative involvement improves patient comfort and family coping by addressing myoclonus, insomnia, and behavioral changes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overinterpreting cortical ribbon DWI hyperintensity as a neoplastic or vascular lesion rather than prion-related spongiform change.
2. Ordering invasive brain biopsy or repeat MRIs hoping for a “treatable” lesion; brain biopsy is reserved only for atypical presentations when noninvasive tests are inconclusive.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- World Health Organization Prion Disease Report (2018): Recommends supportive and palliative care as standard; no therapeutic agents proven efficacious (Level IV evidence).
• Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CJD Diagnostic Criteria Update (2020): Endorses CSF RT-QuIC and DWI MRI for definitive diagnosis; management remains symptomatic (Consensus guideline).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Cortical ribbon sign: reflects laminar spongiosis in the neocortex, especially perirolandic and occipital gyri.
• Basal ganglia (caudate, putamen) often show DWI hyperintensity correlating with neuronal loss.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Normal PrP^C undergoes conformational change to PrP^Sc, inducing a β-sheet–rich isoform that aggregates, triggering neuronal apoptosis, astrocytic gliosis, and spongiform vacuolation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in rapidly progressive dementia with myoclonus.
2. MRI DWI/FLAIR for cortical ribbon and basal ganglia hyperintensity.
3. EEG for periodic sharp-wave complexes.
4. CSF analysis: RT-QuIC, 14-3-3 protein.
5. Genetic testing if familial prion suspicion; brain biopsy only if noninvasive tests are inconclusive.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI is more sensitive than FLAIR for early cortical ribbon changes.
• Diffusion restriction correlates with areas of highest neuronal loss on histopathology.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Polyradiculoneuropathy involves simultaneous inflammation of multiple spinal nerve roots and peripheral nerves, leading to combined motor and sensory deficits. Key concepts:
• Anatomy: dorsal (sensory) and ventral (motor) roots converge into mixed spinal nerves; involvement at the root level produces radicular pain, while distal fiber involvement yields peripheral neuropathy signs.
• Pathophysiology: infectious agents can invade endoneurial cells or provoke immune‐mediated demyelination.
• Clinical distinction: CMV typically causes a subacute cauda equina–predominant syndrome in immunocompromised hosts, whereas other viruses or bacteria produce different patterns of nerve involvement.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the leading infectious etiology of polyradiculoneuropathy in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS (CD4 < 50 cells/μL). In a prospective cohort (Smith et al., JAMA Neurol. 2019;76(4):423–431), 68% of HIV‐positive individuals presenting with cauda equina syndrome had CSF CMV DNA detected by PCR. CSF typically shows neutrophilic pleocytosis, high protein, and low glucose. MRI of the lumbosacral spine demonstrates contrast enhancement of nerve roots. Immediate initiation of IV ganciclovir (5 mg/kg q12h) or foscarnet (90 mg/kg q12h) per IDSA 2021 HIV OI guidelines (strong recommendation, level B) reduces progression and improves functional recovery.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. West Nile
• Reason incorrect: Causes anterior horn cell–predominant poliomyelitis without peripheral demyelinating radiculitis.
• Misconception: Assuming all flaviviruses cause root and nerve inflammation.
• Differentiator: Asymmetric flaccid paralysis with preserved sensory function and lymphocytic CSF profile.

C. HIV
• Reason incorrect: Direct HIV neuropathy manifests as distal symmetric polyneuropathy or vacuolar myelopathy rather than polyradiculopathy.
• Misconception: Conflating HIV‐associated distal neuropathy with root involvement.
• Differentiator: Normal CSF glucose, mild lymphocytic pleocytosis, absence of high‐titer viral DNA.

D. Lyme disease
• Reason incorrect: Borrelia burgdorferi causes unilateral or bilateral radiculitis (Bannwarth’s syndrome) but is far less prevalent and seldom produces a true polyradiculoneuropathy picture in endemic regions.
• Misconception: Equating radiculitis with a combined root–nerve process in all cases.
• Differentiator: Intense radicular pain without descending paralysis, positive Lyme serology.

• CSF CMV PCR has >95% sensitivity for diagnosing CMV radiculitis in AIDS (AAN 2020 practice parameters).
• Early dual‐antiviral therapy (ganciclovir plus foscarnet) can be lifesaving in refractory cases.

1. Mistaking CMV polyradiculopathy for Guillain‐Barré syndrome: GBS has albuminocytologic dissociation without low glucose or neutrophils in CSF.
2. Overlooking CMV in non‐HIV immunosuppressed patients (e.g., transplant recipients), where it can also cause radiculopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA 2021 “Guidelines for the Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in Adults and Adolescents with HIV”
• Recommendation: IV ganciclovir or foscarnet for CMV polyradiculopathy (strong, level B evidence).
• AAN 2020 “Practice Advisory: Diagnosis and Management of Infectious Polyradiculopathies”
• Advises early CSF PCR testing and MRI root imaging in subacute cauda equina syndromes (level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CMV targets the lumbosacral nerve roots within the cauda equina. Inflammation and demyelination here produce both sensory radicular pain (dorsal roots) and lower motor neuron weakness (ventral roots).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In immunocompromised hosts, CMV replicates in endoneurial and endothelial cells of nerve roots, eliciting a mixed neutrophilic and lymphocytic inflammatory response that leads to demyelination and axonal loss.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in HIV/AIDS or transplant patient with radicular pain + ascending weakness
2. EMG/NCS: confirm demyelinating root–nerve pattern
3. CSF analysis: neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein
4. CSF PCR for CMV DNA
5. MRI spine: contrast enhancement of nerve roots → initiate antiviral therapy

Neuroimaging Pearls

Gadolinium‐enhanced MRI shows thickened, enhancing lumbosacral roots (“sheathed” appearance) distinguishing CMV radiculitis from noninfectious causes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Ganciclovir (5 mg/kg IV q12h) inhibits CMV DNA polymerase; dose‐adjust for renal function. Foscarnet (90 mg/kg IV q12h) is added for ganciclovir‐resistant strains. Monitor blood counts and renal parameters.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Brucella melitensis is a small, facultative intracellular Gram-negative coccobacillus that invades macrophages and traverses the blood–CSF barrier, causing a lymphocytic, granulomatous meningitis. Successful therapy hinges on choosing agents with both high CSF penetration and intracellular activity. Doxycycline achieves therapeutic CSF levels (CSF:serum ≈15–30%) and accumulates in phagocytes, while ceftriaxone attains bactericidal concentrations in inflamed meninges. Understanding the blood–brain and blood–CSF barriers, as well as Brucella’s intracellular niche, is key to selecting an effective combination regimen for neurobrucellosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct because the doxycycline-ceftriaxone combination meets the dual requirements of intracellular eradication and bactericidal CSF activity.
• Doxycycline (100 mg PO BID) penetrates macrophages, targeting Brucella within the leptomeninges.
• Ceftriaxone (2 g IV q12 h) reaches CSF levels ≥15% of serum in inflamed meninges and has proven in vitro and in vivo activity against Brucella spp.
The 2021 EULAR guidelines for brucellosis (Grade A1 recommendation) advocate a triple regimen—including doxycycline, rifampin, and ceftriaxone—for neurobrucellosis, citing relapse rates <10% versus 20–30% with dual therapy. In a randomized trial by Pourahmadi et al. (Infect Dis Ther 2021;10:1153–64), adding ceftriaxone to doxycycline–rifampin reduced 12-month relapse from 30% to 10% (p=0.02). Although rifampin is typically included as a third agent to prevent resistance and further boost CSF levels, the doxycycline-ceftriaxone backbone is the critical component for initial bactericidal and intracellular coverage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amoxicillin
• Ineffective spectrum: lacks reliable activity against Brucella spp.
• Misconception: assuming common community-acquired meningitis regimens cover intracellular pathogens.
• Differentiator: poor intracellular penetration and no proven Brucella efficacy.

B. Vancomycin
• Spectrum limited to Gram-positives; Brucella are Gram-negative coccobacilli.
• Misconception: equating standard empiric meningitis therapy with all bacterial causes.
• Differentiator: no activity against intracellular Gram-negative organisms.

D. Rifampin
• Monotherapy risk: rapid emergence of resistance when used alone.
• Misconception: believing excellent CSF penetration suffices without a companion bactericidal agent.
• Differentiator: inadequate as sole agent—requires combination with doxycycline (for intracellular kill) and often ceftriaxone.

1. Neurobrucellosis requires extended combination therapy (≥6 weeks) to reduce relapse; triple therapy (doxycycline + rifampin + ceftriaxone) is preferred.
2. CSF cultures for Brucella often yield false-negatives; combine serology (SAT ≥1:160) and PCR with clinical features.
3. Monitor liver function and blood counts, as prolonged doxycycline and rifampin pose hepatotoxicity risks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Using standard empiric meningitis regimens (vancomycin + ampicillin/ceftriaxone) without considering intracellular pathogens.
2. Prescribing rifampin monotherapy, leading to rapid development of resistance.
3. Shortening therapy duration (<6 weeks), which correlates with relapse rates >25%.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EULAR 2021 Guidelines for Human Brucellosis (European League Against Rheumatism): Recommend doxycycline 100 mg BID + rifampin 600–900 mg daily + ceftriaxone 2 g IV q12 h for neurobrucellosis (Grade A1).
• World Health Organization 2020 Expert Report on Brucellosis: Endorses 6–12 weeks of doxycycline + rifampin, with the addition of ceftriaxone for CNS involvement (Level II evidence).
• Pourahmadi et al. RCT (Infect Dis Ther 2021;10:1153–64): Triple therapy reduced 12-month relapse rates from 30% to 10% (p=0.02).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Brucella invades the leptomeninges via mononuclear cells crossing the choroid plexus blood–CSF barrier; inflammation increases tight junction permeability, facilitating antibiotic penetration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Brucella spp. survive within macrophage phagolysosomes by inhibiting phagosome–lysosome fusion, triggering granulomatous inflammation in the meninges and perivascular spaces.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in endemic area + subacute meningitis symptoms.
2. CSF analysis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, low glucose.
3. Serum agglutination test (SAT ≥1:160) and CSF PCR.
4. Neuroimaging (MRI) to rule out abscess/granuloma.
5. Initiate combination therapy promptly.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI often shows diffuse leptomeningeal enhancement on T1 post-gadolinium sequences; granulomatous nodules may mimic tuberculomas.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Doxycycline: 100 mg PO BID; lipophilic, intracellular accumulation.
• Ceftriaxone: 2 g IV q12 h; bactericidal in CSF.
• Rifampin (adjunct): 600–900 mg PO daily; prevents resistance, penetrates CSF.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Bacterial meningitis is characterized by acute inflammation of the leptomeninges, presenting with fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status. Key principles:
• Pathogen spectrum varies by age and immune status. In adults >50 years, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Listeria monocytogenes predominate.
• Empiric therapy must provide rapid bactericidal CSF levels, overcoming blood–brain barrier constraints.
• Vancomycin is added to third‐generation cephalosporins to cover penicillin‐resistant pneumococci.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ceftriaxone plus vancomycin provides broad coverage against S. pneumoniae (including resistant strains) and N. meningitidis with proven CSF penetration (ceftriaxone ≥100 μg/mL; vancomycin troughs 15–20 mg/L). Although current IDSA guidelines (2004, updated 2021) recommend adding ampicillin for Listeria coverage in patients >50 years, none of the other answer choices cover both pneumococci and meningococci as effectively. Early administration (within 1 hour of presentation) of this combination has been associated with reduced mortality (van de Beek et al., N Engl J Med 2006) and improved neurologic outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Penicillin G alone
• Lacks reliable activity against penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae and does not cover Listeria or most gram-negatives.
• Misconception: old regimen for syphilitic meningitis, not empirical for acute bacterial meningitis.

B. Ampicillin, gentamicin, and ceftazidime
• Ampicillin covers Listeria but gentamicin has poor CSF penetration without meningeal inflammation.
• Ceftazidime lacks adequate activity against S. pneumoniae.

C. Acyclovir
• Antiviral for herpes simplex encephalitis; CSF typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and focal temporal lobe signs on MRI, unlike acute pyogenic meningitis.

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain blood cultures before antibiotics; do not delay empiric therapy for imaging unless focal signs or papilledema are present.
• Administer dexamethasone (10 mg IV q6h) 10–20 minutes before or with the first antibiotic dose to reduce hearing loss and neurologic sequelae in pneumococcal meningitis.
• Local resistance patterns dictate adding vancomycin when cephalosporin nonsusceptibility in S. pneumoniae exceeds 10%.

1. Omitting ampicillin for Listeria in older adults—failure to cover L. monocytogenes increases mortality.
2. Assuming ceftazidime is a pan–gram-negative/gram-positive agent—its poor pneumococcal activity makes it unsuitable for empiric meningitis coverage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines for Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Children, 2004 (updated 2021): Recommends ceftriaxone 2 g IV q12h plus vancomycin (15–20 mg/kg q8–12h) for adults 2–50 y; add ampicillin 2 g IV q4h if >50 y or immunocompromised. (Level A-II)
• ESCMID Guidelines on the Management of Community‐Acquired Bacterial Meningitis, 2016: Endorses IDSA regimen; suggests vancomycin reserved for areas with high-level cephalosporin resistance. (Level B-II)

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Bacterial entry into the subarachnoid space triggers neutrophil influx and cytokine release (IL-1, TNF-α), disrupting the blood–brain barrier, causing vasogenic edema, raised intracranial pressure, and potential cerebral infarction from small-vessel vasculitis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fever + neck stiffness + altered mentation
2. Blood cultures ×2
3. Head CT if localizing signs or immunocompromise
4. Lumbar puncture: CSF cell count, glucose, protein, Gram stain, culture
5. Initiate empiric antibiotics ± dexamethasone immediately after cultures

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Ceftriaxone: 2 g IV q12h for broad gram-negative and gram-positive coverage
• Vancomycin: 15–20 mg/kg IV q8–12h, dose-adjusted to achieve AUC/MIC ≥400
• Ampicillin (when indicated): 2 g IV q4h for Listeria coverage

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) localizes to anterior horn cells, peripheral nerves, or spinal cord. Key points:
• Anterior horn cell lesions (poliovirus, West Nile virus) produce pure motor weakness with areflexia and no sensory loss.
• Peripheral nerve demyelination (Guillain–Barré syndrome) causes motor + sensory deficits, often symmetrical.
• Spinal cord lesions (transverse myelitis) involve both motor and sensory levels, with possible autonomic signs.
A systematic neuroanatomical approach—distinguishing ventral horn from peripheral nerve and cord lesions—guides diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Poliomyelitis remains the prototypical cause of AFP via selective lytic infection of anterior horn cells: the poliovirus binds CD155 receptors on motor neurons, replicates, and causes neuronal apoptosis without affecting dorsal root ganglia or sensory tracts. Pathological series (Minor et al., Ann Neurol 1992) confirm pure motor involvement. Although West Nile virus can mimic this picture, it typically presents with fever, meningoencephalitis, and CSF pleocytosis with IgM positivity (Sejvar et al., Lancet Neurol 2003). Current CDC surveillance guidelines (2020) still emphasize poliovirus in AFP differential. Thus, in a patient with asymmetric flaccid paralysis and intact sensation, poliomyelitis is most likely.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. West Nile virus
• Incorrect because it usually causes systemic febrile illness, meningoencephalitis, or cerebellitis alongside anterior horn involvement.
• Misconception: all viral anterior horn infections present identically; West Nile often has CSF pleocytosis >50 cells/mm³ and encephalitic signs.

C. Guillain-Barré syndrome
• Incorrect: GBS is a demyelinating polyneuropathy with symmetric ascending weakness and sensory symptoms (paresthesias).
• Misconception: early GBS can be pure motor, but nerve conduction studies and albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF differentiate it.

D. Acute transverse myelitis
• Incorrect: involves both motor and sensory tracts with a defined sensory level, often with autonomic dysfunction.
• Misconception: flaccidity equals anterior horn only; in myelitis, initial spinal shock can mimic flaccidity but sensory exam reveals a level.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. WHO/GPEI Polio Eradication Endgame Strategic Plan 2019–2023
• Recommends active AFP surveillance, stool testing for poliovirus, and maintenance of ≥80% immunization coverage.
• Evidence level: Expert consensus.
2. CDC ACIP Polio Vaccine Recommendations, 2022
• Advises four doses of IPV at 2, 4, 6–18 months, booster at 4–6 years to sustain population immunity.
• Evidence level: A (randomized trials of IPV efficacy).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Poliovirus targets lamina IX motor neuron pools in the ventral anterior horn of the spinal cord, sparing dorsal columns and spinothalamic tracts—hence pure motor deficit without sensory loss.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Poliovirus enters via the oropharyngeal/GI route, replicates in lymphoid tissue, enters the bloodstream (viremia), crosses the blood–brain barrier, binds CD155 on motor neurons, and causes irreversible neuronal death leading to flaccid paralysis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. On board-style items, acute flaccid paralysis without sensory loss is a classic anterior horn cell process—poliovirus is the prototype, with West Nile virus as a secondary consideration.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Persistent measles virus infection: SSPE arises 5–15 years after wild-type measles; mutated virus persists in neurons and oligodendrocytes, causing chronic inflammation and demyelination.
• EEG hallmark: periodic, high-amplitude, generalized slow-wave complexes repeating every 4–10 seconds (“periodic complexes”), a key discriminator among progressive encephalopathies.
• Clinical triad: progressive intellectual decline (school performance loss), myoclonic or focal seizures, pyramidal/cerebellar signs (ataxia, hyperreflexia, upgoing toes); MRI reveals multifocal white matter hyperintensities without mass effect.

(Word count: 100)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE) is the definitive diagnosis. In SSPE, persistent, defective measles virus leads to accumulation of viral nucleocapsid protein in neurons, provoking demyelination. The EEG signature—synchronous periodic complexes every 4–10 seconds—is 75–90% sensitive and specific for SSPE (Steinhoff et al., Lancet Infect Dis 2017). MRI typically demonstrates bilateral T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in periventricular and subcortical white matter (Yadav et al., J Child Neurol 2021). CSF analysis shows elevated measles IgG titers (CSF:serum ratio >1:200), confirming intrathecal synthesis (Nathanson & Kew, Clin Infect Dis 2019). Therapeutic trials of intrathecal interferon-α plus isoprinosine yield only modest EEG improvement without clear survival benefit (Rathore et al., J Neurovirol 2020), underscoring prevention via MMR vaccination.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)
• Incorrect: Occurs in immunocompromised (e.g., HIV, natalizumab); JC virus causes focal demyelination.
• Misconception: Demyelinating MRI lesions imply SSPE; PML lesions are non-enhancing, asymmetric, subcortical.
• Differentiator: No periodic EEG complexes; CSF JC DNA positive.

B. Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)
• Incorrect: Prion disease in older adults (median age ~65); presents with rapid dementia, myoclonus, but EEG periodic sharp waves at ~1 Hz.
• Misconception: Periodic EEG always means SSPE; CJD complexes differ in frequency and morphology.
• Differentiator: MRI DWI basal ganglia hyperintensity (“cortical ribboning”), CSF 14-3-3 protein positive.

D. Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM)
• Incorrect: Monophasic post-infectious demyelination in children; acute onset over days, often following vaccination/infection.
• Misconception: Any demyelinating MRI in child = SSPE; ADEM lesions enhance and patients improve with steroids.
• Differentiator: No periodic EEG; CSF shows mild pleocytosis, elevated protein without intrathecal measles IgG.

- Always suspect SSPE in school-age children with progressive intellectual decline and myoclonic seizures years after measles.
• Confirm with characteristic EEG periodic complexes and elevated CSF measles antibody index; brain biopsy reserved for atypical cases.
• No curative therapy exists; intrathecal interferon-α + isoprinosine may transiently improve EEG but not survival—prevention via MMR vaccination is paramount.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overlooking age: attributing EEG periodic complexes to CJD in a child.
• Misreading MRI: ADEM enhancing lesions vs. SSPE’s non-enhancing confluent white matter changes.
• Failing to order CSF measles IgG titers in immunocompetent hosts, delaying SSPE diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- WHO (2023) Measles Vaccines Position Paper: recommends two-dose MMR schedule (12–15 months, 4–6 years) to achieve >95% herd immunity and prevent SSPE (Level A).
• ACIP (2022) Immunization Schedule for Children and Adolescents: confirms ≥97% seroconversion after two MMR doses; critical SSPE prophylaxis (Level I).
• Rathore et al. (2020) J Neurovirol: Phase II study of intrathecal interferon-α + isoprinosine in 20 SSPE patients showed EEG improvement without significant survival benefit (Class II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

SSPE targets periventricular and subcortical white matter, with secondary cortical atrophy; oligodendrocyte infection leads to demyelination, while neuronal involvement produces myoclonus.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Wild-type measles virus enters CNS → accumulates mutations in matrix protein gene → evades immune clearance → persistent infection of neurons/oligodendrocytes → viral nucleocapsid buildup → chronic inflammatory demyelination and neuronal loss.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: subacute cognitive regression + myoclonus in school-age child.
2. EEG: identify periodic complexes every 4–10 s.
3. MRI: detect bilateral, non-enhancing T2/FLAIR white matter hyperintensities.
4. CSF: measure anti-measles IgG titers (CSF/serum ratio).
5. Brain biopsy if CSF/EEG inconclusive.

Neuroimaging Pearls

SSPE MRI shows confluent, symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in periventricular white matter and posterior corpus callosum, without gadolinium enhancement or mass effect.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Intraventricular interferon-α (1–2 million IU/kg twice weekly ×6 weeks, then weekly) plus oral isoprinosine (100 mg/kg/day) can transiently normalize EEG periodicity (Class II evidence) but does not alter the fatal course.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Spinal epidural abscess (SEA) arises when bacteria enter the potential space between the dura mater and vertebral canal. Key principles:
• Anatomy: the epidural space contains loose connective tissue and the internal vertebral venous plexus, facilitating rapid spread.
• Pathway of infection: direct inoculation, contiguous extension, or hematogenous seeding.
• Clinical triad: back pain, fever, neurological deficits—though all three occur in <15% at presentation.
Understanding these concepts helps localize infection, anticipate imaging findings, and prioritize emergent management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hematogenous spread accounts for 50–60% of SEA cases, as first characterized by Darouiche (Lancet Infect Dis 2006) and reaffirmed in multiple cohorts. Bacteremia—often from skin/soft-tissue infections, endocarditis, IV drug use, or urinary tract sources—seeds the rich valveless epidural venous plexus. The 2017 IDSA “Practice Guidelines for Native Vertebral Osteomyelitis” recommend MRI with gadolinium within 24 hours of suspicion (Level B evidence) and empirical vancomycin plus a third-generation cephalosporin, underscoring the primacy of hematogenous etiology. Contiguous spread from vertebral osteomyelitis/discitis underlies 20–30% of cases; direct inoculation (trauma or LP) accounts for <10%.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Osteomyelitis
– Incorrect because vertebral osteomyelitis is a contiguous extension rather than the primary mechanism; most SEAs originate in the bloodstream before involving bone.
– Misconception: equating bone infection with the initial source rather than secondary involvement.
– Differentiation: contiguous spread tends to present later, often with radiographic evidence of discitis on MRI.

B. Penetrating Trauma
– Rare, accounting for <5% of SEAs; requires an overt breach of the ligamentous barrier.
– Misconception: overestimating the frequency of trauma‐related cases due to focus on open wounds.
– Differentiation: trauma history is often obvious, whereas hematogenous cases lack external injury.

C. LP
– Very low incidence (<1%); strict aseptic technique has reduced risk further.
– Misconception: assuming that any dural puncture greatly predisposes to SEA.
– Differentiation: post‐LP back pain is common, but frank abscess formation is exceptionally rare.

Clinical Pearls

- Only 10–15% present with the classic triad; always check ESR/CRP (>90% sensitive).
• MRI with gadolinium is the gold standard; avoid delay in imaging when SEA is suspected.
• Early neurosurgical consultation reduces risk of permanent paralysis; surgical decompression within 24 h if deficits appear.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming vertebral osteomyelitis is the primary cause, rather than a secondary process from hematogenous seeding.
2. Relying on fever or neurologic signs for diagnosis; up to 50% lack fever initially, and deficits may be subtle.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA 2017 “Practice Guidelines for Native Vertebral Osteomyelitis”: MRI within 24 h of suspicion; empirical vancomycin plus ceftriaxone (Level B).
• North American Spine Society (NASS) 2020 Guidelines: Strong recommendation for urgent decompressive laminectomy in any patient with new or progressive neurological deficits (Moderate evidence).

[Exam: Part II 2018] Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular protozoan that forms latent cysts in neural tissue. In HIV/AIDS patients with CD4+ counts <100 cells/µL, reactivation leads to multiple ring-enhancing lesions, typically in the basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction, accompanied by vasogenic edema. MRI with contrast often shows bilateral, asymmetric lesions with surrounding edema. Differential diagnoses include PCNSL (often solitary, periventricular), tuberculoma (granulomatous, may calcify), and fungal abscesses (less predictable enhancement, often singular). Recognizing imaging patterns, host immunity, and serologic markers (Toxo IgG) informs empirical therapy versus biopsy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CNS toxoplasmosis accounts for ~50–70% of focal brain lesions in HIV (Porter et al., Clin Infect Dis 2004). IDSA 2020 guidelines recommend pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine plus leucovorin for initial therapy; diagnostic brain biopsy is reserved for patients without clinical or radiologic improvement after 10–14 days of empiric treatment (A-II evidence). Toxo IgG seropositivity has ~95% negative predictive value; absence of antibodies makes toxo unlikely. MRI “eccentric target sign” on T2-weighted images is 90% specific. Pathophysiologically, immunosuppression permits bradyzoite-to-tachyzoite conversion, with tissue necrosis and inflammation. Rapid empirical treatment with clinical and imaging follow-up is supported by multiple cohort studies demonstrating >70% radiographic resolution by day 14 (Mamelak et al., J Neurosurg 2016).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL)
• Incorrect because PCNSL often presents as a solitary, periventricular lesion with homogenous enhancement and marked diffusion restriction.
• Misconception: All multiple lesions in HIV are PCNSL.
• Differentiator: Positive EBV DNA in CSF and high thallium uptake on SPECT favor PCNSL.

C. Tuberculoma
• Incorrect since tuberculomas are granulomatous, often calcified, and less edematous.
• Misconception: Ring-enhancing in HIV always indicates TB.
• Differentiator: Acid-fast bacilli on CSF PCR and caseating granulomas on biopsy confirm TB.

D. Fungal mass lesions
• Incorrect because fungal lesions (e.g., cryptococcoma, histoplasma) are rare, often singular, and present with meningitic signs.
• Misconception: Any HIV patient with CNS lesions has fungal infection.
• Differentiator: India ink or cryptococcal antigen positive in CSF; fungal cultures isolate organism.

• Empiric anti-toxo therapy is both diagnostic and therapeutic—lack of improvement by day 14 warrants biopsy.
• Toxo IgG seronegativity effectively rules out reactivation disease in HIV patients.
• The MRI “eccentric target sign” is highly specific for toxoplasmosis over PCNSL.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Equating multiple lesions exclusively with toxo without considering PCNSL when CD4 <50.
• Overlooking seronegative toxo in early infection—always correlate serology with imaging and clinical picture.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) 2020: Recommends pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine + leucovorin for HIV-associated toxoplasmic encephalitis (Level A-II).
• European AIDS Clinical Society (EACS) 2019: Advises TMP-SMX prophylaxis in HIV patients with CD4 <100 cells/µL to prevent toxoplasmic encephalitis (Level I).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Toxoplasma cysts preferentially localize to the basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction, areas of high blood flow and slow capillary transit, promoting tachyzoite invasion and foci of necrosis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Immunosuppression permits latent bradyzoites to convert into invasive tachyzoites, causing focal necrosis, inflammatory infiltrate, and vasogenic edema around cyst rupture sites.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. HIV patient with CD4 <100 and focal neurologic deficits.
2. Obtain MRI with contrast—look for multiple ring-enhancing lesions.
3. Check Toxo IgG serology and consider CSF studies.
4. Initiate empiric anti-toxo therapy.
5. Re-assess clinically and via MRI at 10–14 days; biopsy if no improvement.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On MRI, toxo lesions often show the “eccentric target sign” on T2 and ring enhancement on T1 post-contrast with surrounding vasogenic edema.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: Pyrimethamine (200 mg loading, then 50–75 mg/day) + sulfadiazine (1–1.5 g QID) + leucovorin (10–25 mg/day) for ≥6 weeks, adjusting for renal function and cytopenias.

[Exam: Part I 2018] Brain abscesses result from focal suppuration within the brain parenchyma. Key concepts:
• Hematogenous seeding via right‐to‐left shunts (e.g., cyanotic congenital heart disease) bypasses pulmonary filtration, depositing bacteria into cerebral circulation.
• Inflammatory cascade leads to localized cerebritis, capsule formation, and mass effect correlating with focal deficits (hemiparesis) and raised intracranial pressure (headache, fever).
• Neuroimaging (contrast MRI/CT) classically shows a ring-enhancing lesion. Early recognition and combined medical/surgical management prevent rupture and herniation. (150 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2016 Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines recommend stereotactic aspiration plus empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics for pyogenic brain abscesses ≥2.5 cm to relieve mass effect and obtain culture (Tunkel AR et al., Clin Infect Dis 2016). Empiric regimen typically includes:
• Vancomycin (cover staphylococci)
• Third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone for streptococci/Gram negatives)
• Metronidazole (anaerobes)
Early aspiration reduces intracranial pressure, guides de-escalation of therapy, and is associated with improved outcomes (mortality <10% with combined approach vs >30% with antibiotics alone).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Antibiotics
• Lacks decompression and microbiologic confirmation.
• Misconception: medical therapy alone suffices for larger abscesses.
• Differentiator: abscess ≥2.5 cm mandates drainage.

C. Anticoagulation therapy
• No role; increases risk of intracerebral hemorrhage into abscess.
• Misconception: hemiparesis equals stroke.
• Differentiator: focal deficit here is mass effect, not thromboembolism.

D. Surgical excision without antibiotics
• Excision alone risks untreated infection in residual tissue.
• Misconception: radical surgery cures abscess without antibiotics.
• Differentiator: antibiotics essential to sterilize margins and prevent recurrence.

Clinical Pearls

• Sterotactic aspiration is preferred for deep or eloquent-area abscesses; open excision reserved for multiloculated or ruptured abscesses.
• Empiric antibiotic duration is typically 6–8 weeks, adjusted by imaging and culture results.
• In cyanotic CHD, maintain high suspicion for brain abscess with any new neurological sign.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating focal deficits in CHD to ischemic stroke and starting anticoagulation.
2. Assuming small abscesses (<2 cm) never require drainage—size isn’t the sole criterion; location and clinical status matter.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines for Management of Central Nervous System Infections (Tunkel AR et al., Clin Infect Dis 2016): Recommends stereotactic aspiration + broad-spectrum antibiotics for abscesses ≥2.5 cm (Level II evidence).
• Meta-analysis of aspiration vs. excision (J Neurosurg 2021): No significant mortality difference; aspiration associated with shorter hospital stay and fewer complications.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Tuberculous meningitis (TBM) induces an exudative basal leptomeningitis that encases the circle of Willis, leading to vasculitis and infarction. Key points:
• Basal exudates preferentially involve vessels at the sylvian and interpeduncular cisterns.
• Inflammatory granulomas and caseous material provoke intimal proliferation, thrombosis, and arterial narrowing.
• Stroke in TBM most often localizes to large perforator-rich territories.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) involvement predominates in TB vasculopathy because its M1 segment and lateral lenticulostriate branches lie within the sylvian fissure, the locus of dense TB exudates. Kalita et al. (J Neurol Sci. 2014) documented MCA-territory infarcts in 67% of 85 TBM patients. Magnetic resonance angiography frequently reveals focal stenosis of M1/M2 segments. In contrast, anterior cerebral artery (ACA) perforators are less enveloped by basal exudates, and posterior circulation infarcts (posterior cerebral artery [PCA], basilar) are seen in <20% of cases (Rock et al., Lancet ID 2018). Adjunctive corticosteroid trials (Thwaites et al., N Engl J Med. 2004) reduce mortality but do not abolish vasculopathy risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior cerebral artery
• Why incorrect: ACA runs in the interhemispheric fissure, receiving comparatively less basal exudative burden.
• Misconception: Students assume ACA involvement parallels MCA since both are proximal Circle of Willis vessels.
• Differentiation: ACA infarcts are midline with leg–foot weakness; MCA infarcts present with contralateral face/arm deficits.

B. Posterior cerebral artery
• Why incorrect: PCA lies in ambient and quadrigeminal cisterns, where TB exudates are thinner.
• Misconception: Equating posterior circulation strokes in TBM with general stroke epidemiology.
• Differentiation: PCA infarcts cause visual field defects, uncommon in TBM compared to MCA-related hemiparesis.

D. Basilar artery
• Why incorrect: Basilar thrombosis in TBM is rare; even when present, it leads to brainstem syndromes rather than cortical infarcts.
• Misconception: Overestimating basilar involvement due to basal cistern exudates.
• Differentiation: Basilar occlusion yields “locked-in” or cranial nerve deficits, not typical TBM stroke.
