Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain contrast-enhanced MRI early in TBM to detect basal exudates and vessel stenosis.
• Adjunctive high-dose dexamethasone reduces mortality but does not prevent all vasculitic strokes.
• In TBM patients with new focal deficits, add MR angiography to assess MCA stenosis and consider low-dose aspirin (ASA-TBM trial data).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming TBM stroke patterns mirror atherosclerotic disease; TB vasculopathy preferentially targets MCA perforators, not large-vessel trunks only.
2. Failing to distinguish ACA from MCA territory signs: leg-dominant weakness suggests ACA, whereas arm and face deficits point to MCA involvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Treatment of Tuberculosis (2023)
• Recommendation: All adults and children with TB meningitis should receive adjunctive corticosteroids (dexamethasone) and undergo baseline MRI with MR angiography to screen for vasculopathy. (Strong recommendation; Level I evidence)
2. ASA-TBM Randomized Controlled Trial (Misra et al., Lancet Neurol. 2022)
• Finding: Adjunctive low-dose aspirin (100 mg daily) in TBM reduced incidence of ischemic stroke by 25% over 6 months. (Moderate benefit; Grade B evidence)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Basal exudates accumulate in the sylvian fissure, interpeduncular, and ambient cisterns. The MCA’s M1 segment traverses the sylvian cistern, where inflammatory infiltrates encase and inflame the vessel wall, leading to intimal proliferation and thrombosis of lateral lenticulostriate arteries supplying the internal capsule and corona radiata.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mycobacterium tuberculosis in CSF triggers a Th1-mediated granulomatous response, with exudation of fibrinous material around leptomeningeal vessels. This leads to panarteritis, endothelial proliferation, and luminal narrowing. Released cytokines (TNF-α, IFN-γ) exacerbate vascular injury and thrombosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fever, headache, meningeal signs.
2. CSF analysis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, low glucose; TB PCR/culture.
3. MRI+MRA: identify basal exudates, hydrocephalus, infarcts, vessel stenosis (focus on MCA territory).
4. Initiate RIPE therapy + adjunctive dexamethasone; consider ASA if MRA shows significant MCA stenosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On MRI FLAIR/T1 with contrast, basal leptomeningeal enhancement localizes to sylvian cisterns.
• Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) highlights acute MCA-territory infarcts.
• Time-of-flight MRA often reveals focal MCA M1 narrowing or occlusion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- RIPE regimen: isoniazid 5 mg/kg, rifampin 10 mg/kg, pyrazinamide 25 mg/kg, ethambutol 20 mg/kg daily for 2 months, followed by isoniazid and rifampin for 7–10 months.
• Dexamethasone: 0.4 mg/kg/day IV for 1 week, taper over 6–8 weeks.
• Low-dose aspirin (100 mg/day) may reduce stroke risk when vasculopathy is confirmed.

Board Examination Focus

TB meningitis vasculopathy questions frequently test infarct patterns and vessel involvement; nearly all review books emphasize MCA perforator infarcts in TBM. Examinations often present a TBM vignette with new hemiparesis and ask for the most likely vascular territory.

[Exam: Part II 2019] West Nile virus (WNV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that can invade the meninges, brain parenchyma, and anterior horn cells of the spinal cord. Neuroinvasive forms manifest as meningitis (meningism), encephalitis (altered mental status), or a poliomyelitis-like myelitis producing acute flaccid paralysis. Advanced age increases blood–brain barrier permeability and risk of neuronal infection. Key concepts include:
• Neurotropism: WNV preferentially infects anterior horn motor neurons, causing lower motor neuron signs.
• Inflammatory CSF profile: lymphocytic pleocytosis with elevated protein.
• Distinction from demyelinating syndromes (e.g., Guillain-Barré) by asymmetric weakness and central involvement.
This pathophysiology explains the concurrence of low-grade fever, meningism, encephalopathy, and flaccid paralysis in elderly patients.

Evidence-Based Analysis

West Nile virus neuroinvasive disease classically combines meningoencephalitis with acute asymmetric flaccid paralysis due to direct anterior horn cell injury. Sejvar et al. (JAMA Neurol 2014) demonstrated electrophysiological evidence of motor neuron loss and MRI T2 hyperintensities in ventral horns. The CDC’s 2021 Clinical Guidance for Healthcare Providers recommends testing CSF for WNV-specific IgM (sensitivity >90%, specificity >99%), which persists for weeks post-infection. Typical CSF findings: 50–500 lymphocytes/mm³, protein 50–200 mg/dL, normal glucose. MRI spine often shows “snake-eye” ventral horn lesions. No antiviral has proven benefit; treatment is supportive (IDSA 2015; Level B). Given this constellation, WNV is the only option explaining both meningoencephalitis and poliomyelitis-like paralysis in an elderly host.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Poliomyelitis
• Incorrect: Poliovirus targets anterior horn cells but rarely causes meningism or encephalopathy in vaccinated populations.
• Misconception: Equating flaccid paralysis alone with poliomyelitis without considering central signs or epidemiology.
• Differentiator: Poliomyelitis lacks prominent meningoencephalitis in adults and is nearly eradicated in most regions.

C. HIV encephalopathy
• Incorrect: Presents as chronic cognitive decline and subcortical motor slowing, not acute flaccid paralysis.
• Misconception: Attributing any encephalopathic picture with neurologic deficits to HIV without acute febrile onset.
• Differentiator: HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder lacks fever, meningism, and anterior horn involvement.

D. Guillain-Barré syndrome
• Incorrect: An autoimmune demyelinating polyneuropathy with symmetric ascending paralysis, areflexia, and albuminocytologic dissociation.
• Misconception: Mistaking flaccid paralysis with preserved reflexes as GBS without evaluating CSF cell count or encephalopathy.
• Differentiator: GBS lacks fever, meningoencephalitis, and focal MRI ventral horn lesions.

Clinical Pearls

- Acute flaccid paralysis with central signs (encephalopathy, meningism) should prompt CSF WNV IgM testing in endemic seasons.
• MRI involvement of spinal ventral horns (“snake-eye” lesions) distinguishes WNV from demyelinating neuropathies.
• Supportive care remains the mainstay; immunoglobulin or antivirals are only recommended in clinical trials.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Misdiagnosing WNV-associated flaccid paralysis as GBS and initiating plasmapheresis or IVIG inappropriately.
• Failing to consider WNV in febrile encephalitis with paralysis during mosquito season in temperate regions.
• Relying solely on cell counts without ordering specific CSF IgM or targeted MRI sequences.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- CDC Clinical Guidance for Healthcare Providers (2021): Recommends CSF WNV IgM testing for diagnosis; no antiviral therapy approved (Expert Opinion).
• IDSA Practice Guidelines for the Management of Infectious Encephalitis (2015): Advise against routine antiviral agents for WNV; permit immunoglobulin use only within clinical trials (Level B).
• Sejvar JJ et al., 2018 multicenter cohort: Identified age >60 as independent risk factor for neuroinvasive disease; acute flaccid paralysis occurs in ~7% of cases.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

WNV preferentially infects ventral horn motor neurons in the spinal cord, leading to lower motor neuron signs. In the brain, involvement of the basal ganglia and thalamus contributes to encephalopathic features.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Following mosquito inoculation, WNV replicates in dermal dendritic cells, enters the bloodstream, crosses the blood–brain barrier via infected leukocytes or endothelial cells, and causes direct neuronal cytotoxicity and microglial activation, leading to inflammation and neuronal death in anterior horn cells.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in summer/fall with fever, meningism, encephalopathy, and flaccid paralysis.
2. Lumbar puncture: cell count, protein, glucose.
3. CSF WNV IgM ELISA and PCR.
4. MRI brain and spine with T2/FLAIR sequences for ventral horn lesions.
5. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies to confirm anterior horn cell involvement.
6. Exclude mimics (CSF profile, imaging, serologies).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Spinal MRI: symmetric or asymmetric T2 hyperintensities in ventral horns (“snake-eye”).
• Brain MRI: T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in deep gray structures (basal ganglia, thalami).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- No FDA-approved antivirals for WNV; management is supportive (hydration, respiratory support).
• Investigational: intravenous immunoglobulin and interferon alpha have been evaluated without definitive benefit.
• Preventive: mosquito control and repellents remain key.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Herpes zoster results from reactivation of varicella-zoster virus in dorsal root or cranial nerve ganglia, leading to acute neuritis and cutaneous rash. Viral replication causes inflammation and direct neuronal injury, which in turn predisposes to chronic deafferentation and neuropathic pain (post-herpetic neuralgia, PHN). Early inhibition of viral DNA polymerase with antivirals reduces viral load, limits ganglionic damage, and decreases the incidence and duration of PHN. Key terms: dorsal root ganglion, viral replication, neuropathic pain, deafferentation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) initiated within 72 hours of zoster rash onset is proven to reduce PHN risk by 30–40% (Beutner et al. N Engl J Med 1995; Oxman et al. J Infect Dis 1998). The CDC and IDSA guidelines (IDSA 2014; CDC/ACIP 2021) recommend high-dose antivirals—valacyclovir 1 g TID for 7 days or famciclovir 500 mg TID—over acyclovir for better bioavailability and dosing convenience (Level A evidence). A 2020 Cochrane meta-analysis confirmed early antiviral use shortens acute pain duration and lowers PHN incidence (RR 0.62; 95% CI 0.50–0.78). In contrast, adjunctive corticosteroids may reduce acute pain but do not prevent PHN in randomized trials.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Corticosteroids
• Although steroids reduce acute inflammation and speed rash healing, multiple RCTs (Birch et al. 1998) show no significant reduction in PHN incidence.
• Misconception: anti-inflammatory equals neuroprotection; in reality, ganglionic viral injury persists.

C. Analgesics
• NSAIDs or opioids address symptom relief only; they neither affect viral replication nor modulate the underlying neuropathic process.
• Students often conflate symptomatic pain control with disease modification.

D. Antidepressants
• Tricyclics or SNRIs treat established neuropathic pain but lack antiviral or neuroprotective effects to prevent PHN.
• Misunderstanding: using neuropathic pain agents prophylactically rather than after PHN onset.

Clinical Pearls

1. Begin antiviral therapy ideally within 72 hours of rash to maximize PHN prevention; beyond 72 hours, benefit diminishes.
2. Valacyclovir and famciclovir are preferred over acyclovir due to improved bioavailability and simplified dosing.
3. Shingles vaccination (RZV) is the best preventive measure for herpes zoster and indirectly reduces PHN risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering corticosteroids expecting PHN prevention—clinical trials show no reduction in chronic neuropathy.
2. Delaying antiviral therapy beyond 72 hours; clinicians may miss the therapeutic window.
3. Equating acute pain relief with prevention of chronic neuropathic sequelae.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA Clinical Practice Guideline for Herpes Zoster (2014): Recommends acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir within 72 hours to reduce PHN (Level A).
• CDC/ACIP Zoster Vaccine Recommendations (2021): Emphasize recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) in adults ≥50 years to prevent herpes zoster and subsequent PHN (Level A).

[Exam: Part II 2018] Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative diplococcus that colonizes the human nasopharynx. Close contacts of an index case are at increased risk of invasive disease due to shared respiratory droplets. Chemoprophylaxis aims to eradicate nasopharyngeal carriage and interrupt transmission. Key concepts:
• Carriage versus invasive disease: asymptomatic carriers can seed new cases.
• Drug selection must achieve high concentrations in oropharyngeal mucosa and eradicate carrier state.
• Choice of agent depends on efficacy, resistance patterns, safety and patient factors (age, pregnancy).

(110 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rifampin is the CDC-recommended first-line prophylactic agent for close contacts of meningococcal meningitis [CDC ACIP, 2020]. It achieves high oropharyngeal tissue levels, eradicates N. meningitidis carriage in >95% of treated contacts, and is well studied: adults receive 600 mg PO q12 h for 2 days; children 10 mg/kg (max 600 mg) PO q12 h for 2 days. Alternative regimens include ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO once or ceftriaxone 250 mg IM once (125 mg IM in children) for those contraindicated to rifampin (e.g., pregnant women). Vancomycin and beta-lactams like amoxicillin do not reliably eradicate carrier states or penetrate the oropharynx at sufficient concentrations for prophylaxis.
References:
• CDC. Prevention and Control of Meningococcal Disease: Recommendations of ACIP. MMWR Recomm Rep. 2020;69(RR-2).
• Borrow R, Balmer P, Miller E. Meningococcal surrogates of protection—serum bactericidal antibody assay. Vaccine. 2005;23(17-18):2222–2227.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amoxicillin – Although amoxicillin has activity against some N. meningitidis strains, it does not reliably eradicate nasopharyngeal carriage and is not recommended for post-exposure prophylaxis. Choosing amoxicillin reflects a misunderstanding of carriage dynamics and pharmacokinetics in mucosal tissues.
C. Ciprofloxacin – A single 500 mg oral dose is an accepted alternative prophylactic regimen, but rifampin remains first-line due to extensive safety data in children and pregnant women. Labeling ciprofloxacin as the correct choice overlooks age and pregnancy considerations and regional fluoroquinolone resistance patterns.
D. Vancomycin – Targets Gram-positive organisms; lacks activity against Gram-negative N. meningitidis and does not penetrate the oropharyngeal mucosa in sufficient concentrations. Using vancomycin demonstrates confusion between empiric treatment of meningitis pathogens and prophylaxis of contacts.

Clinical Pearls

- Always initiate chemoprophylaxis as soon as a case of meningococcal meningitis is suspected, ideally within 24 hours of diagnosis.
• Rifampin’s side effects include hepatotoxicity and drug interactions via CYP450 induction; counsel patients regarding orange-red discoloration of urine, tears and saliva.
• In pregnant women and neonates, use a single IM dose of ceftriaxone (125 mg in infants; 250 mg in adults) to avoid teratogenic risks of rifampin and fluoroquinolones.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Prescribing beta-lactams (e.g., amoxicillin) for prophylaxis underestimates the need to eradicate mucosal carriage and ignores resistance data.
• Assuming ciprofloxacin is universally first-line; it is contraindicated in children and pregnant women and may be limited by local fluoroquinolone resistance rates.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), 2020: Recommends rifampin as first-line prophylaxis for all close contacts; level of evidence A (randomized and observational studies demonstrating >95% carriage eradication).
• Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA), 2018 Meningitis Guidelines: Endorses rifampin for routine prophylaxis, with ciprofloxacin and ceftriaxone as alternatives when rifampin is contraindicated; evidence quality B (non-randomized trials, expert consensus).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

N. meningitidis adheres to nasopharyngeal epithelium via type IV pili, resisting mucociliary clearance. If bacteremia ensues, it crosses the blood–brain barrier via transcytosis or paracellular routes, leading to meningitis. Chemoprophylaxis targets the establishment and persistence of carriage by disrupting bacterial DNA replication (rifampin) or inducing lethal DNA breaks (ciprofloxacin).

[Exam: Part II 2018] West Nile virus (WNV) is a Culex‐transmitted flavivirus. Neuroinvasive disease (<1% of infections) presents as meningitis, encephalitis or acute flaccid paralysis. Flaccid weakness results from selective infection and death of anterior horn (lower motor) neurons, leading to hypotonia and areflexia. Students must distinguish lower‐motor neuron (LMN) signs—flaccidity, fasciculations, hyporeflexia—from upper‐motor neuron (UMN) signs—spasticity, hyperreflexia, hypertonia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Spasticity
• Reflects UMN (corticospinal) damage with hyperreflexia and velocity‐dependent increase in tone—absent in WNV’s LMN syndrome.
• Misconception: conflating post‐encephalitic rigidity with true spasticity.

C. Increased muscle tone
• Also a UMN sign; WNV causes hypotonia due to anterior horn cell loss.
• Misconception: attributing generalized rigidity in encephalitis to WNV motor pathology.

D. Sensory ataxia
• Indicates dorsal column or large‐fiber peripheral sensory involvement—WNV preferentially targets motor neurons, sparing primary sensory pathways.
• Misconception: confusing gait instability in encephalitis with sensory ataxia.

Clinical Pearls

• WNV flaccid paralysis mimics poliomyelitis—often asymmetric, can involve respiratory muscles.
• Diagnosis: CSF WNV IgM positivity; MRI shows anterior cord hyperintensities; EMG reveals denervation.
• No approved antivirals—supportive care (respiratory, rehabilitative) is mainstay; high‐titer IVIG remains investigational.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing WNV‐related flaccid paralysis as Guillain‐Barré syndrome: WNV is asymmetric and monophasic; GBS is typically symmetric, ascending, with albuminocytologic dissociation.
2. Labeling any post‐encephalitic rigidity as spasticity: true spasticity requires UMN lesion signs (hyperreflexia, velocity‐dependent tone increase), absent in an anterior horn cell process.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. CDC/CSTE “Case Definition for West Nile Virus Disease” (MMWR, 2018): Includes acute flaccid paralysis as a neuroinvasive manifestation; consensus opinion, Level IV evidence.
2. IDSA “Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Encephalitis” (2017): Recommends early recognition of LMN signs in arboviral encephalitis; based on observational studies, Grade B recommendation.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Anterior horn cells in the ventral grey matter of the spinal cord are the lower motor neurons supplying skeletal muscle. WNV’s tropism for these cells leads directly to LMN signs (hypotonia, areflexia).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

After mosquito‐mediated entry, WNV replicates in skin dendritic cells, enters the bloodstream, crosses the blood–brain barrier via infected leukocytes or endothelial infection, then binds neuronal receptors in the anterior horn, inducing apoptosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fever + acute asymmetric flaccid weakness.
2. Exposure history: mosquito season/travel.
3. CSF analysis: lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, WNV IgM.
4. MRI spine: anterior cord T2 hyperintensities.
5. EMG/NCS: denervation potentials; exclude GBS (nerve conduction block, albuminocytologic dissociation).

Neuroimaging Pearls

Spinal MRI often demonstrates “snake‐eye” T2 hyperintensities localized to ventral grey matter at affected spinal levels, correlating with clinical weakness.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No specific antiviral therapy is approved. Supportive measures include intensive care for bulbar/respiratory involvement, aggressive rehabilitation, and consideration of investigational high‐titer IVIG (Class III evidence).

The correct answer is A. Flaccid weakness. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Neurosyphilis arises when Treponema pallidum invades the central nervous system, often during tertiary syphilis. Key presentations include tabes dorsalis (dorsal column damage) and general paresis; ocular manifestations include Argyll Robertson pupils.
• Pupillary light reflex: retina → pretectal nuclei → Edinger–Westphal → oculomotor nerve → sphincter pupillae.
• Accommodation reflex: cortical input → Edinger–Westphal → sphincter pupillae, bypassing pretectal light–reflex relay.
• Argyll Robertson pupil: small, irregular; abolishes light reflex (pretectal lesion) but preserves near accommodation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Argyll Robertson pupils are virtually pathognomonic for neurosyphilis, reflecting selective lesions in the dorsal midbrain pretectal area caused by inflammatory infiltration of spirochetes (Harrison’s Neurology, 21st ed., 2022). Autopsy series demonstrate perivascular inflammatory infiltrates and microglial proliferation centered on the pretectal region, interrupting the afferent light pathway while sparing fibers mediating accommodation (Jackson et al., Neurology 1964;14:1127–1135). No other systemic disease reliably produces bilateral small irregular pupils with preserved near response and absent light reaction. Recognition of this sign directs urgent CSF analysis (VDRL, cell count, protein) and initiation of high-dose penicillin to prevent irreversible neurological damage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hypochromatic macules
• Why incorrect: Syphilis causes copper-colored maculopapular rash, not hypopigmented macules.
• Misconception: Equating any cutaneous lesion with neurosyphilis.
• Differentiator: Hypopigmented macules appear in tuberculoid leprosy or pityriasis versicolor, not neurosyphilis.

B. Erythema nodosum
• Why incorrect: Painful panniculitis linked to streptococcal, TB, sarcoidosis—absent in syphilis.
• Misconception: Confusing systemic inflammatory nodules with treponemal infection.
• Differentiator: Erythema nodosum presents on pretibial shins; neurosyphilis has no panniculitis.

C. Enlarged pupils
• Why incorrect: Mydriasis occurs with oculomotor nerve palsy or Adie’s tonic pupil—light and near responses both abnormal or near preserved but pupil tonically dilated.
• Misconception: Assuming any pupillary abnormality implies neurosyphilis.
• Differentiator: Large tonic pupil has vermiform movements, slow redilation.

Clinical Pearls

• Always test both direct/consensual light reflexes and accommodation response to detect light–near dissociation.
• Argyll Robertson pupils are bilateral in ~70% of neurosyphilis cases.
• Presence of Argyll Robertson pupils warrants CSF VDRL and cell count—even in absence of other neurologic signs.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing Argyll Robertson pupil with Marcus Gunn pupil (afferent pupillary defect): the latter shows paradoxical dilation on direct light swing test.
2. Attributing any pupillary irregularity to neurosyphilis without testing near response.
3. Assuming erythema nodosum is a syphilitic manifestation—always consider sarcoidosis, TB, streptococcal etiologies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. CDC STD Treatment Guidelines 2021 (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
– Recommendation: Neurosyphilis treated with aqueous crystalline penicillin G 18–24 million units IV per day for 10–14 days (Grade A; Level I).
2. IUSTI/WHO European Region Syphilis Guidelines 2020
– Recommendation: Perform CSF VDRL on any neurosyphilis suspicion; retreatment guided by CSF normalization at 6-month intervals (Grade A; Level IIa).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The pretectal area of the dorsal midbrain harbors interneurons relaying afferent light signals to bilateral Edinger–Westphal nuclei. Treponemal gummas and inflammatory cells disrupt this relay, abolishing the light reflex while leaving the di-, olivary–cortical pathways for accommodation intact.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In tertiary syphilis, chronic meningovascular inflammation and gumma formation involve small vessels of the midbrain. The predilection for the pretectal region yields selective dysfunction of parasympathetic pupillary fibers mediating the light reflex, sparing fibers mediating the accommodation reflex.

It underscores the importance of performing both light and accommodation tests in neurological examinations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] 1. HIV–associated immunosuppression (CD4+ T-cell count <100 cells/µL) predisposes patients to opportunistic CNS infections.
2. Brain abscesses are focal collections of necrosis and inflammatory cells with a collagenous capsule, appearing as ring-enhancing lesions on MRI post-contrast.
3. Toxoplasma gondii is a ubiquitous intracellular protozoan; in AIDS it reactivates from latent tissue cysts (commonly in basal ganglia), leading to abscess formation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Toxoplasma gondii is the leading cause of focal brain lesions and abscesses in HIV‐infected patients worldwide. In pre-ART eras, up to 70% of AIDS patients presenting with CNS mass lesions had toxoplasmic encephalitis. Current IDSA (2010) and DHHS HIV OI guidelines (2020) recommend empiric anti-Toxoplasma therapy and confirm diagnosis by radiographic response. MRI typically shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding vasogenic edema in basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction. Seropositivity for T. gondii IgG (present in ~30–60% of HIV+ patients) confers risk of reactivation when CD4+ <100 cells/µL. Failure to improve clinically and radiographically after 10–14 days of pyrimethamine-sulfadiazine plus leucovorin warrants stereotactic brain biopsy. Meta-analyses (Lancet Infect Dis 2013;13(7):583) confirm TMP-SMX as effective prophylaxis and treatment alternative, reducing incidence by >90%.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Tuberculosis (TB)
Although Mycobacterium tuberculosis can produce tuberculomas, these granulomatous lesions are less common than toxoplasma abscesses in HIV, and tend to have a solid or non-necrotic core with T2 hypointense rim rather than classic ring enhancement.

C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
CMV classically causes ventriculoencephalitis and periventricular enhancement, not discrete parenchymal abscesses. Focal CMV disease is rare and manifests as ependymitis, polyradiculopathy, or diffuse encephalitis.

D. Cryptococcosis
Cryptococcus neoformans most often produces meningitis; cryptococcomas (mass lesions) are rare and typically non-enhancing or have meningeal enhancement. The gelatinous pseudocysts in basal ganglia differ from true abscess formation.

- Prophylaxis with TMP-SMX when CD4+ <100 cells/µL in T. gondii IgG–positive patients reduces incidence by >90%.
• The “eccentric target sign” on contrast MRI (small mural nodule within ring) is highly specific (~95%) for toxoplasma abscess.
• Lack of radiographic improvement by day 14 of empiric therapy necessitates stereotactic biopsy to exclude primary CNS lymphoma.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Misinterpreting a single large ring lesion as toxoplasmosis without considering lymphoma—lymphoma often shows homogeneous enhancement and elevated thallium uptake on SPECT.
• Failing to obtain T. gondii IgG serology before empiric therapy; seronegative patients are unlikely to have toxoplasmic abscess.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- DHHS HIV OI Guidelines (2020): Recommend primary prophylaxis with TMP-SMX for T. gondii when CD4+ <100 cells/µL (AII).
• IDSA Cryptococcosis Guidelines (2010): Differentiate cryptococcal meningitis from mass lesions; cryptococcomas manage with extended amphotericin B + flucytosine (AI).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

T. gondii reactivations localize preferentially in basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction where blood flow is high and reticuloendothelial clearance is lower, leading to ring-enhancing abscesses and focal deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In HIV, impaired CD4+ T-cell–mediated immunity allows bradyzoite cysts to rupture, releasing tachyzoites. Intracellular proliferation in glial cells triggers necrosis and host inflammatory response, forming a collagen-encapsulated abscess.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in HIV+ with focal deficits, headache, fever.
2. MRI brain with contrast → identify ring-enhancing lesions.
3. Check CD4 count and T. gondii IgG serology.
4. Initiate empiric anti-Toxo therapy.
5. If no clinical/radiographic improvement at 10–14 days, proceed to stereotactic brain biopsy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Ring enhancement with eccentric target sign is >90% specific for Toxoplasma.
• Thallium-201 SPECT: lymphoma retains thallium; toxo does not.
• FDG-PET: lymphoma shows hypermetabolism, toxo shows hypometabolism.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: pyrimethamine 200 mg loading → 50–75 mg/day + sulfadiazine 1–1.5 g q6h + leucovorin 10–25 mg/day, for ≥6 weeks.
• Alternative: TMP-SMX 5 mg/kg TMP component IV/PO twice daily for 6 weeks.
• Monitor for bone marrow suppression; supplement with folinic acid.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rapidly progressive, fatal transmissible spongiform encephalopathy caused by misfolded prion proteins (PrPSc) that aggregate in neurons, leading to spongiform degeneration. Prions resist standard sterilization and are detectable not only in central nervous system tissue but also in lymphoreticular organs, blood, and ocular tissue. Because prion infectivity survives routine decontamination, any tissue or organ from an affected individual poses a risk of iatrogenic transmission. Health authorities—including the World Health Organization and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control—recommend permanent exclusion of CJD patients from organ and tissue donation programs. Understanding prion protein biochemistry, routes of transmission (e.g., neurosurgical instruments, corneal grafts), and the basis for strict donor eligibility criteria is essential for informed public health decision-making and patient counseling.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct: all major transplant authorities—WHO’s 2017 “Guidelines on Tissue Infectivity Distribution in Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies” and the U.S. CDC’s 2010 prion safety report—state that CJD is an absolute contraindication to organ and tissue donation. PrPSc aggregates have been detected in peripheral tissues including spleen, lymph nodes, muscle, and blood (McDonough et al., Lancet Neurol 2012). Documented iatrogenic transmissions via corneal and dura mater grafts, and theoretical risk from solid organs, underscore that no validated decontamination protocol guarantees prion inactivation. Although no confirmed cases of solid-organ–transmitted CJD are published, the American Society of Transplantation Consensus Conference (2016)—citing level III evidence from case series and mechanistic studies—reaffirms exclusion of known or suspected CJD donors. Ethical and precautionary principles demand removing CJD patients from donation registries to protect recipients.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Allow only for liver transplant
• Incorrect because prion infectivity is systemic.
• Misconception: prions confined to CNS; in reality, PrPSc is present in lymphoreticular tissues and blood.
• Differentiation: no organ is proven free of prion contamination.

C. Allow the patient to be in the organ donation program
• Ignores public health guidelines and the precautionary principle.
• Misconception: believing absence of documented transplant-transmitted cases equates to safety.
• Differentiation: official policies uniformly contraindicate donation.

D. Refer the patient for further infectious disease evaluation
• Unnecessary: infectious disease consultation cannot alter prion infectivity or donor eligibility.
• Misconception: additional testing could “clear” prion risk.
• Differentiation: CJD diagnosis is clinical/laboratory confirmed; donor exclusion is definitive.

Clinical Pearls

- PrPSc is resistant to routine autoclaving; effective decontamination requires formic acid plus extended high-pressure sterilization.
• Iatrogenic CJD has occurred via corneal grafts and neurosurgical instruments.
• Always exclude any donor with rapidly progressive dementia and characteristic EEG/MRI/CSF findings suggestive of CJD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing variant CJD (vCJD) lymphoid involvement with sporadic CJD; both subtypes pose donation risks.
2. Assuming standard sterilization eliminates prions; students often overlook prion resilience to heat, radiation, and chemicals.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- WHO, 2017 “Guidelines on Tissue Infectivity Distribution in Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies”: absolute donor exclusion for CJD (Level IV, expert consensus).
• American Society of Transplantation Consensus Conference, 2016: CJD is an absolute contraindication to organ donation (Level III, case series/mechanistic data).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PrPSc deposition predominantly affects cerebral cortex (especially frontal and occipital lobes), basal ganglia (caudate, putamen), and thalamus (pulvinar), correlating with rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Misfolded PrPSc induces conformational change in normal PrPC, forming β-sheet–rich aggregates that resist proteases, accumulate intra- and extracellularly, and trigger synaptic loss and neuronal vacuolation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, cerebellar signs
2. MRI brain: DWI cortical ribboning, basal ganglia hyperintensities
3. EEG: periodic sharp wave complexes
4. CSF: 14-3-3 protein, RT-QuIC assay for prion seeding activity

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI DWI/FLAIR shows hyperintense cortical ribboning and striatal signal; pulvinar “hockey stick” sign in vCJD.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No disease-modifying therapy exists; management is supportive—treat myoclonus with clonazepam or levetiracetam, address psychiatric symptoms, ensure palliative care.

[Exam: Promotion 2023] • Bacterial meningitis is an acute inflammation of the leptomeninges and subarachnoid space, often due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, or Listeria monocytogenes.
• Inflammation increases blood–brain barrier (BBB) permeability, leading to cerebral edema and raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
• Early antimicrobial therapy reduces bacterial proliferation in CSF, blunts the inflammatory cascade, and lowers mortality; diagnostics (blood cultures, LP, neuroimaging) should not delay treatment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Immediate empiric antibiotics upon suspicion of bacterial meningitis is supported by the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) 2016 guidelines, which state that antibiotics must be administered within 60 minutes of presentation to reduce mortality (Level A recommendation). A meta-analysis in Clinical Infectious Diseases (2018) showed that each hour of delay in antibiotic administration increases absolute mortality by 1%. Neuroanatomical principles: rapid bacterial replication in the subarachnoid space induces cytokine release (e.g., TNF-α, IL-1β) that drives cerebral edema. Empiric coverage typically includes a third-generation cephalosporin plus vancomycin, and ampicillin in patients >50 years or immunocompromised to cover Listeria.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CT scan
– Incorrect: Neuroimaging is only indicated if focal neurologic signs, papilledema, or immunocompromise exist due to risk of delaying antibiotics.
– Misconception: Belief that imaging must precede treatment to rule out mass effect in all cases.
– Differentiator: Imaging should not delay empiric therapy unless clinical signs of raised ICP are present.

B. Lumbar puncture if examination shows no papilledema
– Incorrect: LP is essential for diagnosis but must not delay antibiotics; if no contraindications, LP should follow initial antimicrobial therapy.
– Misconception: Prioritizing CSF confirmation over life-saving treatment.
– Differentiator: Therapy first, diagnostics second when meningitis is suspected.

D. Obtain blood cultures
– Incorrect: While blood cultures should be drawn immediately, they must be obtained quickly and simultaneously with antibiotic administration; the act of starting antibiotics is highest priority.
– Misconception: Blood cultures alone are sufficient initial step before therapy.
– Differentiator: Cultures should not delay antibiotic infusion.

Clinical Pearls

• Empiric antibiotics should never be delayed for imaging or LP in suspected bacterial meningitis; time to antibiotic is the strongest predictor of outcome.
• Dex amethasone administered before or with first antibiotic dose reduces neurologic sequelae in pneumococcal meningitis (IDSA Level A).
• In patients with suspected meningococcal meningitis, begin prophylaxis for close contacts (e.g., rifampin, ciprofloxacin).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Waiting for CT scan in all cases: Students often overestimate the risk of herniation in routine meningitis and delay antibiotics.
2. Prioritizing CSF over therapy: Many learners believe lumbar puncture is the diagnostic “gold standard” that must precede any treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• IDSA Clinical Practice Guidelines (2016): Recommend empiric antibiotics within 60 min of presentation; dexamethasone adjunct before or with first dose (Level A).
• ESCMID Guidelines on Acute Bacterial Meningitis (2023): Emphasize blood cultures drawn immediately before antibiotics but not at the expense of delaying therapy; endorse ceftriaxone + vancomycin +/- ampicillin (Evidence Grade 1A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The subarachnoid space (between arachnoid and pia mater) contains CSF; bacterial proliferation here triggers widespread inflammation affecting cranial nerve roots, explaining headache, photophobia, and nuchal rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Bacterial invasion of the subarachnoid space → activation of innate immune cells → release of cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α) → BBB breakdown → vasogenic edema and increased ICP → neuronal injury and potential herniation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fever, headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status
2. Rapid IV access → draw blood cultures
3. Administer empiric IV antibiotics + dexamethasone within 60 min
4. Neuroimaging if focal deficits, papilledema, immunocompromise
5. Lumbar puncture for CSF cell count, glucose, protein, Gram stain, culture
6. Tailor antibiotics based on culture/PCR results

Neuroimaging Pearls

CT head may show meningeal enhancement, hydrocephalus, or focal lesions; absence of mass effect is required before safe LP but should not delay antibiotic therapy in uncomplicated cases.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Adults <50 yrs: Ceftriaxone 2 g IV q12h + Vancomycin (15–20 mg/kg IV)
• Adults >50 yrs or immunocompromised: Add Ampicillin 2 g IV q4h for Listeria coverage
• Dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h for 4 days, started before or with first antibiotic dose.

[Exam: Part I 2024] 1. Vacuolar myelopathy is the most common HIV-associated spinal cord disorder, resulting from cytokine-mediated myelin injury and spongiform vacuolation of the lateral and posterior columns.
2. Negative MRI and CSF studies help exclude compressive, infectious, or inflammatory myelopathies (e.g., CMV polyradiculitis, HSV/VZV radiculitis, HIV myelitis), pointing toward a metabolic–degenerative etiology.
3. Clinically, patients develop slowly progressive spastic paraparesis, dorsal column dysfunction (sensory ataxia), and may experience radicular pain without cutaneous lesions or significant CSF pleocytosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vacuolar myelopathy (VM) arises when HIV-activated macrophages release neurotoxic cytokines (e.g., TNF-α, nitric oxide) that injure oligodendrocytes, producing vacuoles in myelin sheaths. Histopathology confirms spongiform vacuolation in lateral/posterior columns. Imaging typically shows either a normal cord or subtle thoracic T2 hyperintensities; CSF is acellular or minimally protein-elevated. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guideline stipulates MRI and CSF analysis to rule out opportunistic infections; if negative, VM is a diagnosis of exclusion (Class I; Level B). Antiretroviral therapy (ART), especially CNS-penetrant integrase inhibitors, stabilizes or modestly improves neurologic deficits (Brew et al., 2022). Supportive care includes spasticity management (e.g., baclofen) and rehabilitation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. HZV
• Incorrect because herpes zoster radiculopathy features a dermatomal vesicular rash, CSF pleocytosis, and MRI nerve root enhancement.
• Misconception: equating any radicular pain in HIV with zoster without rash or imaging/CSF support.

B. CMV
• Incorrect as CMV polyradiculitis presents with acute cauda equina syndrome, high CSF cell counts/protein, and nerve root enhancement on MRI.
• Misconception: attributing chronic back pain to CMV without electrophysiologic or CSF evidence.

C. HIV Myelitis
• Incorrect because HIV myelitis is inflammatory; MRI shows focal cord lesions and CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis.
• Misconception: assuming direct HIV invasion always produces MRI/CSF abnormalities.

• Normal MRI/CSF in HIV patients with myelopathic signs should raise suspicion for VM.
• Integrase inhibitor-based regimens have superior CNS penetration and correlate with better neurological outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overinterpreting mild T2 hyperintensities as definitive evidence of inflammatory myelitis.
2. Failing to consider VM in the absence of rash or significant CSF abnormalities.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline, 2018: Recommends MRI with contrast and CSF analysis to exclude opportunistic infections; if negative, VM is a diagnosis of exclusion (Class I; Level B).
• European AIDS Clinical Society (EACS) Guidelines, 2023: Advocate early initiation or optimization of integrase inhibitor-based ART to stabilize or improve neurological function in HIV-associated VM (Level C).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

HIV infects CNS macrophages → production of TNF-α and nitric oxide → oligodendrocyte apoptosis → formation of intramyelinic vacuoles in lateral and posterior spinal columns.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: spastic paraparesis, dorsal column signs, radicular pain.
2. MRI spine with gadolinium: exclude compressive/inflammatory lesions.
3. CSF analysis: cell count, protein, PCR for HSV/VZV/CMV.
4. If negative imaging and CSF, plus compatible clinical picture → diagnose vacuolar myelopathy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

A normal spinal MRI in an HIV patient with myelopathic signs does not exclude significant pathology; VM often lacks radiologic correlates.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: Optimize ART with high CNS-penetrance agents (e.g., dolutegravir). Symptomatic: baclofen for spasticity; gabapentin or pregabalin for neuropathic pain.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Infective endocarditis (IE) results from microbial invasion of the endocardial surface, leading to vegetations on valves. Septic emboli can detach and occlude cerebral arteries, most commonly in the middle cerebral artery territory, causing ischemic stroke. Fever and a new pansystolic murmur (indicative of mitral regurgitation) in a stroke patient strongly suggest IE. Key terms: vegetation (a mass of platelets, fibrin, microorganisms), septic embolus, mycotic aneurysm (infected vessel wall dilation). Recognizing IE-stroke requires integrating infectious signs with neurologic deficits to guide appropriate management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Prompt administration of pathogen-directed intravenous antibiotics is the cornerstone of IE management complicated by stroke. The AHA/ACC 2015 Infective Endocarditis Guidelines (Baddour et al.) give a Class I recommendation (Level A evidence) for initiating empirical IV antibiotics immediately after obtaining blood cultures. Early therapy reduces vegetation size and prevents further septic embolization (Duval et al., Clin Infect Dis 2018). Thrombolytics and antithrombotics lack efficacy against vegetations and pose high hemorrhagic risks in infected vasculature, whereas corticosteroids worsen infection through immunosuppression.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Antiplatelets
• Reason incorrect: Do not eradicate the underlying infection; can exacerbate intracranial bleeding from mycotic aneurysms.
• Misconception: Treats all strokes as platelet-mediated.
• Key differentiator: Requires antimicrobial therapy, not antithrombotic, in septic embolic stroke.

C. Thrombolytics
• Reason incorrect: Contraindicated in IE-related stroke due to high risk of hemorrhagic transformation and rupture of mycotic aneurysms.
• Misconception: All acute ischemic strokes qualify for tPA.
• Key differentiator: Thrombolysis targets fibrin clots, not infected vegetations.

D. Corticosteroids
• Reason incorrect: No benefit in IE; immunosuppression may worsen infection and delay clearance.
• Misconception: Steroids universally reduce neurologic inflammation.
• Key differentiator: Anti-inflammatory vs. antimicrobial necessity in IE.

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain at least three sets of blood cultures before starting antibiotics in suspected IE.
• Transesophageal echocardiography has >90% sensitivity for detecting vegetations (ESC 2015).
• Avoid tPA in suspected septic embolic stroke; risk of hemorrhage far outweighs benefit.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering tPA under the assumption of noninfectious ischemic stroke without blood culture or echo.
2. Starting aspirin or clopidogrel in IE, inadvertently increasing intracranial bleeding risk from infected vessels.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ACC 2015 Infective Endocarditis Guidelines (Baddour et al.): Class I recommendation for immediate empirical IV antibiotics after blood cultures (Level A).
• ESC 2015 Guidelines for IE (Habib et al.): Recommend TEE within 24 hours and pathogen-specific antibiotic therapy for 4–6 weeks (Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Septic emboli from mitral vegetations typically lodge at distal MCA bifurcations, causing cortical infarcts in the frontal and parietal lobes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Vegetations composed of fibrin and bacteria shed septic emboli, which occlude cerebral microvasculature and release exotoxins that damage vessel walls, predisposing to infarction and mycotic aneurysm.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fever + new murmur + focal neurologic deficit.
2. Draw three sets of blood cultures.
3. Perform transthoracic echocardiography; if negative or equivocal, proceed to transesophageal echo.
4. Brain MRI with DWI for infarct localization and GRE for hemorrhage/mycotic aneurysm.
5. Initiate empirical IV antibiotics; adjust based on culture sensitivities.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI MRI: acute diffusion restriction in cortical territories.
• GRE/SWI: microhemorrhages or saccular dilations suggesting mycotic aneurysms.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Empiric regimen: vancomycin plus ceftriaxone; tailor to organism (e.g., nafcillin for MSSA, ampicillin for Enterococcus) for a total 4–6 weeks duration.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] In HIV-infected patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL, focal neurologic deficits and headache warrant imaging to distinguish etiologies of ring-enhancing lesions. The key differential includes Toxoplasma gondii (multiple bilateral lesions, basal ganglia predilection), primary CNS lymphoma (solitary or few lesions, subependymal spread, positive EBV PCR in CSF), and less commonly neurocysticercosis or bacterial/fungal abscesses. Breakdown of the blood–brain barrier around necrotic foci produces ring enhancement on MRI with gadolinium. Empiric anti-toxoplasma therapy is indicated when serology is positive or highly suggestive, reserving stereotactic biopsy for nonresponders after 10–14 days. Understanding CD4 thresholds, imaging patterns, and empiric treatment rationales is essential for timely management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is an evidence-based alternative regimen for cerebral toxoplasmosis. The 2010 Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines endorse pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine plus leucovorin as first-line (strong recommendation, level I evidence), with TMP-SMX (TMP 5 mg/kg and SMX 25 mg/kg daily in divided doses) as an alternative when first-line agents are unavailable or contraindicated (moderate recommendation, level II evidence). A randomized trial by Walzer et al. (1982) demonstrated comparable clinical and radiographic response rates (≈80%) between TMP-SMX and pyrimethamine-based regimens. TMP-SMX’s dual blockade of dihydropteroate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase disrupts folate metabolism in T. gondii. DHHS HIV treatment guidelines (2024) also recognize TMP-SMX for both prophylaxis (CD4 <100 cells/µL) and treatment of established disease, especially in resource-limited settings. Empiric initiation leads to clinical improvement in 7–10 days; lack of response prompts further workup.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Praziquantel
Praziquantel targets voltage-gated calcium channels in Taenia solium cysticerci; it is used for neurocysticercosis in combination with albendazole and corticosteroids. It has no efficacy against protozoa like T. gondii and would not rapidly reduce ring-enhancing lesions in toxoplasmosis.

C. Amphotericin B
Amphotericin B binds ergosterol in fungal cell membranes and is indicated for cryptococcal meningitis or systemic fungal infections. It has poor activity against protozoal organisms and is not used to treat cerebral toxoplasmosis. Its use would delay appropriate therapy and increase morbidity.

D. Antitubercular therapy
Standard RIPE therapy (rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol) is indicated for CNS tuberculosis (tuberculomas, meningitis). Tuberculomas can present as ring-enhancing lesions but empiric anti-TB therapy is reserved for high clinical suspicion, CSF findings, or biopsy; immediate empiric anti-toxoplasma therapy is prioritized in HIV with low CD4 and positive toxo serology.

Clinical Pearls

• In HIV patients with CD4 <100 cells/µL, positive T. gondii IgG serology and multiple ring-enhancing lesions warrant empiric anti-toxoplasma therapy before biopsy.
• Pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine–leucovorin remains the preferred regimen; TMP-SMX is used when first-line drugs are unavailable or cause intolerable adverse effects.
• Monitor complete blood count and renal function during TMP-SMX therapy; adjust for cytopenias and renal insufficiency.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Assuming all ring-enhancing lesions in HIV are tuberculomas leads to inappropriate anti-TB therapy and treatment delay.
• Believing amphotericin B treats protozoal infections overlooks its specificity for fungal ergosterol and risks nephrotoxicity without benefit.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. IDSA Guidelines for Toxoplasmosis (2010): Recommend pyrimethamine–sulfadiazine plus leucovorin as first-line (strong, level I evidence); TMP-SMX as alternative (moderate, level II).
2. DHHS HIV Guidelines (2024): Endorse TMP-SMX (single-strength or double-strength) for both prophylaxis (CD4 <100 cells/µL) and treatment of cerebral toxoplasmosis where pyrimethamine regimens are contraindicated (AII).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

T. gondii lesions typically localize to basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction. Infected microglia and astrocytes create perivascular necrosis, leading to ring enhancement on MRI. Lesion clustering in deep gray nuclei reflects parasite predilection for high-blood-flow regions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Inhaled or ingested oocysts reach intestinal epithelium, differentiate into tachyzoites, and disseminate hematogenously. In the CNS, tachyzoites invade glial cells, replicate intracellularly, cause cell lysis, and incite granulomatous inflammation; breakdown of blood–brain barrier yields ring-enhancing MRI lesions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Obtain CD4 count and T. gondii IgG serology.
2. Perform contrast-enhanced MRI (look for multiple, bilateral, basal ganglia lesions).
3. If serum IgG positive and imaging typical, start empiric anti-toxoplasma therapy (e.g., TMP-SMX or pyrimethamine-based).
4. Reassess neurologic status and repeat imaging at 10–14 days.
5. If improvement, continue treatment for 6 weeks, then maintenance prophylaxis.
6. If no response, consider stereotactic brain biopsy to evaluate for lymphoma or other etiologies.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• “Eccentric target sign” on MRI T1 post-contrast is highly specific for toxoplasmosis.
• Multiple ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding edema favor toxo over solitary CNS lymphoma, which often demonstrates homogeneous enhancement or subependymal spread.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

TMP-SMX dosing: TMP 5 mg/kg/day + SMX 25 mg/kg/day divided into two oral or IV doses. Duration: 6 weeks acute, then lower-dose prophylaxis. Adverse effects: bone marrow suppression, hyperkalemia, rash—monitor CBC and electrolytes weekly initially.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] 1. The choroid lies between the retina and sclera, rich in blood vessels; hematogenous pathogens often seed here.
2. Granulomatous inflammation (e.g., in TB) produces discrete choroidal nodules (“tubercles”) that may appear orange–yellow on fundus exam.
3. Differentiating infectious causes of chorioretinal lesions relies on lesion color, distribution, systemic signs, and serologic/PCR testing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Choroidal tubercles in ocular tuberculosis arise from hematogenous dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis to the choriocapillaris. They present as small (0.5–3 mm), well-circumscribed, orange–yellow nodules at the level of the RPE–choroid interface. Gupta et al. (Ophthalmology 2018) reported that 30% of disseminated TB patients have funduscopically visible tubercles, which may be bolstered by positive interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs). The 2020 IDSA guidelines recommend considering systemic anti-tubercular therapy when ocular TB is suspected (Level II evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Yaws
• Yaws (Treponema pallidum pertenue) primarily causes skin and bone lesions; ocular uptake is limited to interstitial keratitis, not choroidal tubercles.
• Misconception: Equating all treponemal infections with posterior segment disease.

C. Malaria
• Cerebral malaria shows retinal whitening, vessel changes, and hemorrhages (e.g., “white-centered” Roth spots), not discrete orange choroidal nodules.
• Differentiating: malaria retinopathy is diffuse and hemorrhagic rather than focal granulomatous.

D. Syphilis
• Ocular syphilis can produce gummatous chorioretinitis but lesions appear grey-white and poorly circumscribed; lipofuscin deposition (orange) is a feature of melanoma, not syphilis.
• Misconception: Overlapping “gumma” vs. granuloma terminology but distinct fundus appearance.

- Always examine the choroid in patients with disseminated TB; early detection of tubercles can prompt systemic therapy.
• IGRA is more specific than tuberculin skin test in BCG-vaccinated individuals with suspected ocular TB.
• Differentiate orange choroidal lesions from lipofuscin in melanoma by noting lesion height, associated subretinal fluid, and FA/ICGA patterns.

1. Confusing TB tubercles with histo spots: TB lesions are nodular and raised, histo scars are atrophic and punched-out.
2. Assuming any yellowish fundus lesion is infectious; consider neoplastic (melanoma) and vascular (hemangioma) causes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- IDSA 2020 Practice Guidelines for Tuberculosis: Recommend ocular examination in miliary/disseminated TB; anti-TB regimen initiation when ocular involvement is confirmed (strength A; level II).
• AAO Uveitis Preferred Practice Pattern 2023: Advises combined systemic treatment and corticosteroid-sparing agents for confirmed ocular TB to prevent scarring (level II evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] The retina is neural tissue derived from the diencephalon, with a tight blood–retinal barrier analogous to the blood–brain barrier. Viral retinitis results from infection of retinal vascular endothelium and glial elements, leading to necrosis and hemorrhage. Funduscopically, “retinal whitening” reflects full-thickness retinal necrosis, while “orange spots” correspond to intraretinal hemorrhages. Recognition of lesion morphology and host immune status (particularly CD4 count in HIV) is essential for diagnosis. CMV retinitis typically occurs in immunocompromised patients and produces granular, yellow-white lesions adjacent to vessels with hemorrhages, classically described as a “pizza pie” appearance.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in AIDS, especially at CD4 < 50 cells/µL. CMV infects retinal vascular endothelial cells, causing vasculitis, necrosis, and dot/blot hemorrhages. The American Academy of Ophthalmology Preferred Practice Patterns (2019) and IDSA Guidelines on opportunistic infections (2018) recommend induction therapy with systemic valganciclovir (900 mg orally twice daily) or IV ganciclovir (5 mg/kg IV q12h) until lesions are inactive. Recent randomized studies (JAMA Ophthalmol. 2021) confirm that early systemic therapy reduces progression and vision loss. Fundus examination remains diagnostic; aqueous PCR is reserved for atypical cases.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Bartonella
• Incorrect: Causes neuroretinitis with optic disc edema and a macular “star” of hard exudates, not granular retinal whitening with hemorrhages.
• Misconception: Confusing exudative patterns of macular star with hemorrhagic spots.

B. Tuberculosis (TB)
• Incorrect: Ocular TB presents as choroidal granulomas or serpiginous-like choroiditis; lesions are choroidal rather than intraretinal, and hemorrhages are uncommon.
• Misconception: Equating any yellow retinal lesion with TB without considering choroidal vs. retinal location.

D. Toxoplasmosis
• Incorrect: Presents with focal, fluffy white retinochoroiditis adjacent to an old pigmented scar (“headlight in the fog”) with intense vitreous inflammation, not scattered granular lesions with dot hemorrhages.
• Misconception: Overgeneralizing “white retinal lesion” findings across all infective retinitides.

Clinical Pearls

1. In HIV patients with CD4 < 50/µL, perform monthly dilated fundus exams for CMV retinitis screening.
2. CMV retinitis lesions progress centrifugally; early treatment preserves central vision.
3. Aqueous or vitreous PCR can confirm atypical presentations in immunocompetent hosts.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misreading a macular star of neuroretinitis as hemorrhages; remember that hard exudates are refractile, not red–orange.
2. Assuming any white retinal lesion with hemorrhage is toxoplasmosis; note the pattern and host immunity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. IDSA Guidelines on Opportunistic Infections in HIV (2018): Recommend oral valganciclovir induction (AI) for CMV retinitis; maintenance until CD4 > 100/µL for ≥3 months.
2. AAO Preferred Practice Pattern (2019): Emphasizes clinical diagnosis by fundus exam; aqueous PCR (level B evidence) if presentation is atypical or treatment-resistant.
3. JAMA Ophthalmology (2021) randomized trial: Early systemic vs. intravitreal ganciclovir showed equivalent lesion control but systemic therapy reduced new lesion incidence (Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The central retinal artery supplies inner retina; CMV-induced endothelial damage causes ischemic whitening and hemorrhages in the nerve fiber and ganglion cell layers.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CMV infects retinal endothelial and glial cells → vasculitis → vessel wall necrosis → full-thickness retinal necrosis (whitening) + dot/blot hemorrhages from leaky capillaries → progressive vision loss without treatment.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify risk (HIV CD4 < 50, transplant, immunosuppression).
2. Perform dilated fundus exam; look for granular lesions + hemorrhages.
3. Rule out differential with serologies/PCR as needed.
4. Initiate induction antiviral therapy promptly.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Optical coherence tomography shows hyperreflective full-thickness retinal lesions with overlying shadowing; fundus autofluorescence demonstrates hypoautofluorescent necrotic zones.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Ganciclovir triphosphate inhibits viral DNA polymerase. Induction: 5 mg/kg IV q12h (14–21 days) or valganciclovir 900 mg PO BID. Maintenance: 5 mg/kg IV daily or 900 mg PO daily until immune recovery.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Spinal epidural abscess (SEA) is a purulent collection in the epidural space that can rapidly compress the spinal cord or cauda equina.
• Anatomy: The epidural space lies between dura mater and vertebral canal, containing a valveless vertebral venous (Batson’s) plexus.
• Pathophysiology: Bacterial seeding via bloodstream, contiguous spread, or direct inoculation leads to abscess formation.
• Clinical relevance: Rapid diagnosis and intervention (MRI, antibiotics ± surgery) are critical to prevent permanent neurologic deficits.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hematogenous spread via the vertebral venous plexus is responsible for approximately 40–60% of SEAs. Darouiche et al. (NEJM 2006) reviewed 87 cases and found hematogenous seeding from skin, urinary tract or endovascular infections as the predominant mechanism. A systematic review by Patel et al. (Spine J 2014) confirmed that distant bacteremia—often Staphylococcus aureus—accounts for nearly half of cases. The richly anastomosed and valveless nature of Batson’s plexus allows retrograde bacterial migration into the epidural space. Current IDSA (2010) guidelines recommend evaluation for distant foci (endocarditis, skin/soft-tissue infection) when SEA is suspected, reinforcing the primacy of hematogenous spread.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Direct
• Incorrect because traumatic or iatrogenic inoculation (e.g., surgery, epidural catheter) accounts for <10% of SEAs.
• Misconception: Assuming all spinal infections arise from local procedures rather than distant sources.

C. Osteomyelitis
• Vertebral osteomyelitis can extend into the epidural space but is secondary (20–30%) to hematogenous seeding.
• Differentiation: Osteomyelitis-driven abscesses often have radiographic vertebral endplate involvement on MRI, unlike isolated hematogenous SEAs.

D. Contiguous soft tissue infection
• Psoas or paraspinal muscle abscess can track into the epidural space but is uncommon (<5%).
• Misconception: Overestimating the frequency of local soft-tissue extension versus bloodborne spread.

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain MRI with gadolinium in any patient with back pain plus fever or neurologic signs to rule out SEA.
• Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA) is the most common pathogen; cover with vancomycin until sensitivities return.
• Inspect for distant infection sources (skin, IV lines, endocarditis) as part of the SEA workup.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating severe back pain alone with mechanical causes and delaying imaging—up to 20% of SEAs present without fever.
• Focusing on local spinal procedures without searching for remote bacteremia or endovascular infections.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) 2010 Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of vertebral osteomyelitis and spinal epidural abscess: Recommend MRI for all suspected cases and initial empiric IV antibiotics targeting S. aureus (Level II evidence).
• North American Spine Society (NASS) 2013 Consensus on pyogenic spinal infections: Emphasizes early neurosurgical consultation for any neurological deficit and tailoring antibiotic duration by pathogen and response (Level III evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The valveless Batson’s plexus interconnects pelvic, thoracic and cranial veins, permitting retrograde bacterial migration into the dorsal epidural space, especially under raised intra-abdominal or intrathoracic pressure.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Bacteremia → seeding of epidural venous plexus → focal suppuration → inflammatory edema → compressive ischemia of spinal cord/roots.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: back pain + fever or neurologic signs
2. Laboratory: CBC, ESR/CRP, blood cultures
3. Imaging: urgent MRI with contrast
4. Microbiology: CT-guided aspiration or surgical decompression for culture

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI: T1 hypointense, T2 hyperintense collection with rim enhancement in epidural space; adjunct CT to evaluate bony involvement.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Empiric: Vancomycin plus ceftriaxone (or cefepime) pending culture.
• Adjust based on sensitivities; duration 6 weeks for SEA without osteomyelitis.
• Monitor vancomycin troughs (15–20 µg/mL) for MRSA coverage.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Neuroretinitis presents with optic disc edema and lipid-rich exudates radiating from the macula (“macular star”), giving an orange-yellow appearance. Key concepts:
• Retinal anatomy: outer plexiform layer traps serum lipids, forming the star pattern around the macula.
• Blood–retinal barrier breakdown: infectious vasculitis allows plasma to leak into retinal layers.
• Infectious neuroretinitis: Bartonella henselae (cat-scratch disease) is the prototype, following cat exposure and regional lymphadenopathy.
(Word count: 82)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Bartonella henselae is a fastidious Gram-negative bacillus transmitted by cat scratches. In 69–82% of ocular bartonellosis cases, patients develop neuroretinitis with optic disc swelling and a macular star of hard exudates. The pathogenesis involves small-vessel vasculitis and breakdown of the inner blood–retinal barrier, allowing lipid-rich serum to accumulate in the outer plexiform layer. Purvin et al. (J Neuro-Ophthalmol. 2010) detailed this classic fundus finding. The 2011 IDSA Cat-Scratch Disease Guidelines recommend azithromycin (500 mg PO day 1, then 250 mg × 4 days) for neuroretinitis (Level II evidence). Clinical response is usually rapid, with resolution of exudates over 6–8 weeks.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Syphilis
– Ocular syphilis typically causes panuveitis, placoid chorioretinitis or optic neuritis, not a macular star.
– Misconception: any infectious optic disc swelling equals syphilis.
– Differentiation: positive treponemal tests and placoid retinal lesions.

B. Brucellosis
– Rarely involves the eye; when it does, presents as uveitis or choroiditis without radial exudates.
– Misconception: all zoonoses with fever cause neuroretinitis.
– Differentiation: Brucella agglutination titers and undulant fever.

D. Malaria
– Severe falciparum malaria causes retinal hemorrhages, vessel discoloration, and whitening (“cotton-wool”), not lipid exudates.
– Misconception: malarial retinopathy includes any retinal discoloration.
– Differentiation: thick/thin smear positivity and systemic hemolysis.

• Assuming all optic disc edema with retinal changes is syphilitic—confirm with serology and lesion morphology.
• Confusing hard exudates in diabetic maculopathy with the macular star of neuroretinitis—note unilateral acute onset and systemic context.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Light–near dissociation refers to pupils that fail to constrict to bright light yet constrict (often tonically) during accommodation. Key principles:
• Pupillary pathways: Afferent via retina→optic nerve→pretectal nuclei; efferent via Edinger–Westphal nucleus→oculomotor nerve→ciliary ganglion→sphincter pupillae.
• Lesion localization: Damage distal to the pretectal–Edinger–Westphal complex (e.g., ciliary ganglion in Adie’s) abolishes the light reflex but spares or exaggerates near response via alternate convergence inputs.
• Epidemiology: Among isolated causes of light–near dissociation, Holmes–Adie tonic pupil is most frequently encountered in neuro‐ophthalmology clinics, whereas neurosyphilis (Argyll Robertson pupil) and dorsal midbrain syndromes are comparatively rarer.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Adie’s pupil results from viral or inflammatory insult to the ciliary ganglion or short ciliary nerves, producing segmental denervation of the iris sphincter. Aberrant collateral reinnervation selectively restores near constriction at the expense of the light reflex. Wheless et al. (2016) found Adie’s pupil in ~70% of referred light–near dissociation cases, making it the predominant etiology. In contrast, Argyll Robertson pupils of neurosyphilis—classically bilateral, miotic, irregular pupils that accommodate but do not react to light—have become uncommon in regions with effective penicillin therapy (Beiser et al., 2019). The American Academy of Ophthalmology Preferred Practice Pattern (2018) endorses dilute pilocarpine testing to confirm Adie’s supersensitivity and emphasizes careful near-response assessment.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Paranoid syndrome
• No neuro-ophthalmic basis; purely psychiatric without pupillary pathway involvement.
• Misconception: Confusing behavioral syndromes with ocular motor signs.

B. Neurosyphilis
• Argyll Robertson pupils exhibit light–near dissociation, but neurosyphilis prevalence is low in treated populations.
• Misconception: Overestimating rarity of Adie’s versus prominence of “prostitute’s pupil.”
• Differentiator: Bilateral, small irregular pupils in neurosyphilis versus unilateral dilated pupil in Adie’s.

D. Diabetes mellitus
• Diabetic autonomic neuropathy can slow pupillary responses to both light and near equally; no selective near preservation.
• Misconception: Assuming any autonomic neuropathy yields light–near dissociation.
• Differentiator: Both light and near reflexes are proportionally impaired, lacking dissociation.

- Always test near response after light reflex in any anisocoria exam to unmask light–near dissociation.
• Adie’s pupil shows sectoral “vermiform” iris movements and hypersensitivity to dilute pilocarpine (0.1%).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating all light–near dissociation with neurosyphilis (Argyll Robertson pupil) rather than recognizing the more prevalent Adie’s pupil.
• Omitting near-response testing in a routine pupil exam, thereby missing the diagnostic dissociation.
• Misinterpreting diabetic pupillary involvement as selective (near or light) rather than proportional.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. CDC STD Treatment Guidelines, 2021
• Recommend syphilis serology in patients with unexplained ocular findings; note Argyll Robertson pupils are rare in treated cohorts. (Level: Expert opinion)

2. American Academy of Ophthalmology Preferred Practice Pattern: Neuro‐Ophthalmology, 2018
• Advises use of dilute pilocarpine (0.1%) to confirm Adie’s pupil and stresses detailed near-response evaluation. (Level II evidence: observational studies)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Afferent: Retina → optic nerve → pretectal nucleus (bilateral projections)
• Efferent: Edinger–Westphal nucleus → oculomotor nerve → ciliary ganglion → short ciliary nerves → iris sphincter
• Adie’s lesion: Postganglionic parasympathetic (ciliary ganglion) insult with aberrant regeneration favoring accommodation fibers.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Inflammatory or viral damage to the ciliary ganglion causes partial denervation of the sphincter pupillae. During reinnervation, misdirected fibers preferentially innervate accommodation pathways, resulting in slow, tonic near constriction despite a deficient light reflex.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Observe pupil size, symmetry, and shape.
2. Test direct and consensual light reflex.
3. Test near response (accommodation + convergence).
4. If light–near dissociation:
a. Administer 0.1% pilocarpine—hypersensitive constriction confirms Adie’s.
b. Perform syphilis serology if bilateral miotic irregular pupils.
c. Obtain MRI brain if dorsal midbrain signs (Parinaud’s) are present.

[Exam: Part 2 2023] HIV-associated vacuolar myelopathy is a subacute, progressive spastic paraparesis with dorsal column dysfunction in advanced HIV. Key concepts:
1. Spinal cord tracts: lateral corticospinal tracts mediate voluntary motor control; dorsal columns carry proprioception/vibration.
2. Pathophysiology of vacuolar myelopathy: cytokine-induced oligodendrocyte injury and spongiform vacuolation of myelin without inflammation.
3. Clinical clues: gradual onset over weeks to months, sensory level often absent, MRI may show cord atrophy or T2 hyperintensity without enhancement.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vacuolar myelopathy is the most common intrinsic spinal cord disorder in late HIV disease (CD4 <200 cells/µL). Neuropathological studies (Budka et al., 1987; Brew & Crowe, 2005) demonstrate spongiform vacuoles in the lateral and posterior columns with macrophage infiltration and minimal lymphocytes. HIV proteins (gp120, Tat) trigger microglial activation, release of TNF-α and nitric oxide, and subsequent oligodendrocyte apoptosis (Kaul et al., 2001). MRI typically shows nonenhancing T2 hyperintensity in dorsal columns or diffuse cord atrophy (Simpson et al., 1998). No specific antimicrobial therapy exists; initiation or optimization of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) stabilizes or partially reverses deficits (Brew et al., 1999).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. HTLV-1 infection
– HTLV-1 causes tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP) via CD8+ T-cell–mediated damage, often with hyperreflexia and urinary retention. It occurs in endemic regions and is serologically distinct from HIV.
C. Radiculomyelopathy
– Involves both nerve roots and cord; presents with radicular pain, lower motor neuron signs in roots and sensory root distribution. Our patient lacks radicular pain or reflex changes typical of root involvement.
D. Opportunistic infection of the spinal cord
– Infections (CMV, tuberculosis, Cryptococcus) produce focal lesions, enhancement on MRI, CSF pleocytosis or organisms on PCR/culture. Vacuolar myelopathy shows minimal CSF changes and no granulomas or enhancement.

1. Attributing all HIV-related weakness to peripheral neuropathy—distinguish myelopathy by upper motor neuron signs and sensory levels.
2. Overlooking vacuolar myelopathy when MRI is unremarkable; clinical exam and exclusion of other causes are paramount.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Antiviral Society–USA Panel, 2023: Recommend immediate cART at HIV diagnosis to prevent neurological complications, including vacuolar myelopathy (Level A evidence).
• START Trial (2015): Demonstrated that immediate ART initiation reduces serious HIV-related events, including neuro-complications, by ~50% compared with deferred ART (Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vacuolar myelopathy primarily affects the lateral corticospinal tracts (spasticity) and dorsal columns (proprioceptive loss) in the thoracic cord, leading to spastic paraparesis and sensory ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

HIV-infected microglia release neurotoxic cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β) and viral proteins (gp120, Tat) that disrupt oligodendrocyte function, causing intramyelinic vacuoles and spongiform degeneration without overt inflammation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam confirms upper motor neuron signs and dorsal column involvement.
2. MRI spine to exclude compressive lesions and infections.
3. CSF analysis to rule out opportunistic pathogens.
4. Evaluate CD4 count/viral load; optimize cART.

Neuroimaging Pearls

T2-weighted MRI often shows diffuse hyperintensity in dorsal columns and generalized cord atrophy, with lack of gadolinium enhancement distinguishing it from infective or inflammatory myelopathies.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Optimize cART regimens to achieve viral suppression in CSF; manage spasticity with intrathecal baclofen if oral agents fail; no evidence supports steroids or immunoglobulins.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) selectively degenerates upper and lower motor neurons, sparing sensory fibers.
1. Lower motor neuron (LMN) loss produces denervation changes on EMG: fibrillation potentials, positive sharp waves, and fasciculations.
2. Sensory nerve action potentials remain normal because dorsal root ganglia and sensory axons are preserved.
3. Nerve conduction studies in ALS often show preserved conduction velocities with reduced compound muscle action potential (CMAP) amplitudes reflecting axonal loss.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fasciculations—spontaneous, involuntary discharges of motor units—are a hallmark of LMN hyperexcitability in ALS. The 2016 Awaji criteria integrate fasciculation potentials equivalently with fibrillations and positive sharp waves to improve early diagnostic sensitivity (de Carvalho et al., 2008; level B). The American Academy of Neurology’s 2020 practice guideline recommends EMG evidence of denervation and reinnervation, including fasciculations, in ≥2 body regions or in one region plus UMN signs to support “clinically probable” ALS (Kent et al., 2020; level C). Quantitative studies demonstrate fasciculation frequency correlates with disease progression and motor unit remodeling (Pinter et al., 2018). In contrast, prolonged F waves suggest demyelination rather than pure axonal loss; sensory potentials are normal; and EMG is never entirely normal in symptomatic muscles.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Prolonged F waves
• Reflect demyelination of proximal segments (e.g., CIDP), not primary axonal loss.
• Misconception: ALS causes slowed conduction; actually conduction velocity is preserved.

C. Increased sensory action potentials
• Sensory axons are intact in ALS; amplitudes remain normal.
• Confuses mixed neuropathies (e.g., diabetic polyneuropathy) with motor neuron disease.

D. Normal findings
• EMG in symptomatic muscles always shows denervation/reinnervation changes.
• Mistakes subclinical fasciculations or early subtle changes for normal studies.
