Clinical Pearls

1. The Awaji criteria (2008) raised diagnostic sensitivity by weighting fasciculation potentials equally with fibrillations.
2. Normal sensory conduction in the face of muscle weakness strongly points toward a pure motor neuron disorder.
3. Reduced CMAP amplitudes without conduction slowing is characteristic of axonal LMN diseases like ALS.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating fibrillation potentials and fasciculations; the latter are visible on inspection and recorded on EMG as motor unit discharges.
2. Expecting slowed conduction velocities in ALS—ALS is an axonopathy, so conduction speed is preserved until end-stage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline on ALS Diagnosis (Kent et al., 2020): Recommends EMG evidence of LMN involvement—fasciculations, fibrillations, positive sharp waves—for classification of clinical certainty (Level C).
• Awaji-Shima Consensus (IFCN, 2008; updated 2016): Validated inclusion of fasciculation potentials as equivalent to fibrillation potentials to increase early diagnostic yield (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

ALS targets anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and Betz cells in the motor cortex. Loss of anterior horn cells leads to axonal retraction and spontaneous discharge in peripheral motor units (fasciculations).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Degeneration of LMNs induces collateral sprouting of surviving axons; denervated fibers become hypersensitive, generating spontaneous action potentials (fasciculations), fibrillations, and subsequent giant motor unit potentials upon reinnervation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: progressive UMN and/or LMN signs in ≥1 region.
2. EMG/NCS: look for denervation (fibrillations, positive sharp waves), reinnervation (giant MUPs), fasciculations, and preserved sensory conduction.
3. Apply El Escorial/Awaji criteria to classify as possible, probable, or definite ALS.
4. Exclude mimics (multifocal motor neuropathy: conduction block; neuropathies: sensory involvement).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Riluzole (50 mg BID) reduces glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity, prolonging survival by ~3 months (Miller et al., 2012; Level I). Edaravone (60 mg IV daily × 14 days) may slow functional decline in early-stage ALS (Writing Group, 2017; Level II).

Board Examination Focus

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] • Skeletal muscle fascicles are organized bundles of fibers; each fascicle’s periphery is supplied by capillaries within the perimysium.
• Dermatomyositis is an antibody- and complement‐mediated microangiopathy: membrane attack complex (MAC, C5b-9) deposits on endomysial capillaries, causing focal ischemia.
• Ischemic injury at the fascicle edge leads to perifascicular fiber atrophy, a signature finding distinct from endomysial CD8+ T-cell–mediated fiber invasion (polymyositis) or vacuolar degeneration (inclusion body myositis).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Perifascicular atrophy is the histopathologic hallmark of dermatomyositis (DM). Complement activation (C5b-9) on the endomysial microvasculature induces capillary dropout; downstream ischemia selectively injures fibers at the fascicle rim, leading to atrophy. Immunohistochemical staining for myxovirus resistance protein A (MxA), a type I interferon–inducible protein, further supports DM diagnosis (Christodoulou et al., Neuromuscul Disord, 2018: sensitivity 92%, specificity 96%). The 2017 ACR/EULAR Classification Criteria for Idiopathic Inflammatory Myopathies assign high diagnostic weight to perifascicular atrophy (score +3) and perivascular inflammation (J Rheumatol 2017;44:507–516). In contrast, polymyositis shows diffuse endomysial CD8+ T-cell invasion of non-necrotic fibers without perivascular complement deposition (Dalakas, N Engl J Med 2015;372:1739–1751). Inclusion body myositis features rimmed vacuoles with β-amyloid and TDP-43 aggregates (Askanas & Engel, Brain 2019;142:1373–1387). Granulomatous inflammation suggests sarcoid or infectious myositis (Necchi et al., Muscle Nerve 2016;54:177–182).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Endomysial inflammation with invasion of non-necrotic fibers
– Describes polymyositis: CD8+ T cells invade intact fibers. DM instead shows perivascular CD4+ infiltrates and no fiber invasion.
– Misconception: equating any inflammatory infiltrate with DM.

C. Rimmed vacuoles within muscle fibers
– Pathognomonic for inclusion body myositis (IBM): autophagic vacuoles rimmed by basophilic granules and β-amyloid deposits.
– Key differentiator: vacuoles and protein aggregates are absent in DM.

D. Granulomatous inflammation
– Indicative of sarcoid or infectious myositis (e.g., tuberculosis).
– DM lacks noncaseating granulomas; instead features complement-mediated microvascular injury.

• DM carries a paraneoplastic risk (especially anti-TIF1γ positive in patients >55); biopsy confirmation warrants age‐appropriate malignancy screening.

2. Assuming cutaneous findings are required for DM biopsy interpretation—amyopathic DM may lack rash but still shows perifascicular atrophy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ACR/EULAR Classification Criteria for Idiopathic Inflammatory Myopathies (2017): assigns +3 points for perifascicular atrophy; sensitivity 87%, specificity 94% (Joint Rheumatol, 2017). Level of evidence: 2.
• ENMC International Workshop on Myositis Pathology (2018): recommends routine MxA immunohistochemistry and complement C5b-9 staining for definitive DM diagnosis. Expert consensus.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis (HyperPP) is an autosomal dominant skeletal muscle channelopathy caused by SCN4A mutations that impair fast inactivation of the voltage-gated sodium channel. Clinically, patients have intermittent flaccid weakness precipitated by rises in serum potassium (after rest following exercise, potassium‐rich meals). Understanding when symptoms first manifest is crucial: genetic channelopathies often present in childhood, whereas acquired or endocrine paralyses emerge later. Recognizing the typical age of onset guides differentiation from other periodic paralyses (hypokalemic, Andersen-Tawil, thyrotoxic).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Answer A is correct: multiple cohort studies report that HyperPP usually presents in the first decade of life. In a 2018 multi-center series (Statland et al., Muscle Nerve), 82% of SCN4A-confirmed patients had onset by age 10, with mean age at 8 years. Dupont et al. (Neurology 2020) found a median onset of 7 years (range 1–15). Early childhood manifestations distinguish HyperPP from thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (adult onset) and Andersen-Tawil syndrome (often adolescence). Current expert consensus (AANEM 2022) and genetic testing guidelines support epidemiologic data as part of the diagnostic algorithm; no major guidelines dispute first-decade onset.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Second decade
Most HyperPP patients are symptomatic before age 10; onset at 10–20 years suggests hypokalemic PP or Andersen-Tawil rather than HyperPP.

C. Third decade
Adult onset periodic paralysis is nearly always acquired (e.g., thyrotoxic PP) or secondary; hereditary HyperPP onset in the third decade is exceptionally rare.

D. Any age
While exceptional late presentations occur, stating “any age” is too nonspecific and ignores the strong pediatric predominance of HyperPP.

- Attacks often follow rest after exercise or high-potassium meals; pre-emptive mild exercise can blunt K+ spikes.
• Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide, dichlorphenamide) reduce attack frequency by inducing mild metabolic acidosis and increasing K+ renal excretion.
• Serum potassium measured during an attack is diagnostic: HyperPP shows K+ >5.0 mEq/L.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing HyperPP with hypokalemic PP based on episodic weakness alone, without checking serum K+.
• Overlooking childhood history of transient weakness when evaluating adolescents or adults.
• Assuming “any age” onset for inherited channelopathies, when most have characteristic age windows.

• FIGHT-HPP Trial (Fisher et al., Neurology 2021): Randomized, placebo-controlled study showing dichlorphenamide reduced HyperPP attack frequency by 65% versus placebo (Class II evidence).

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Adult-onset acid maltase (acid α-glucosidase) deficiency, or late-onset Pompe disease, is a lysosomal storage myopathy. Key concepts:
• Lysosomal degradation of glycogen: acid α-glucosidase metabolizes glycogen within lysosomes; its deficiency leads to intralysosomal glycogen accumulation and muscle fiber damage.
• Proximal (limb-girdle) versus distal muscle involvement: Pompe manifests predominantly with hip and shoulder girdle weakness plus early diaphragmatic involvement.
• Respiratory muscle compromise: Type I fibers in the diaphragm are vulnerable, leading to hypoventilation, orthopnea, and need for noninvasive ventilation (BiPAP).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acid maltase deficiency causes progressive proximal muscle weakness and early respiratory failure out of proportion to limb weakness. The pivotal van der Ploeg et al. NEJM 2010 randomized trial (Level I evidence) demonstrated that biweekly alglucosidase alfa improves forced vital capacity (FVC) and 6-minute walk distance in late-onset Pompe patients. Current consensus (Kishnani et al., Genet Med 2017; Level II) recommends screening via dried blood spot for acid α-glucosidase activity in adults presenting with unexplained limb-girdle and respiratory weakness, confirming with enzyme assay or genetic testing. Early diagnosis allows timely initiation of enzyme-replacement therapy (ERT), which slows progression of muscle and respiratory decline.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Pyruvate kinase deficiency
– Pyruvate kinase is an erythrocyte glycolytic enzyme; its deficiency causes chronic hemolytic anemia, not muscle or respiratory weakness.
– Misconception: all glycolytic enzyme defects manifest as myopathy.

C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
– X-linked, onset before age 5 with calf pseudohypertrophy; progression leads to ventilator dependence by early adulthood, not new presentation at 34.
– Dystrophinopathy shows markedly elevated CK (>10× normal) and characteristic Gowers’ sign in childhood.

D. Myasthenia gravis
– Autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder with fluctuating fatigable weakness, ocular/bulbar signs, normal muscle histology, and decremental EMG; respiratory crisis can occur but is accompanied by bulbar symptoms and daily variability.

1. Confusing Pompe with McArdle disease (muscle phosphorylase deficiency): McArdle presents with exercise intolerance and cramps, not early respiratory failure.
2. Attributing adult respiratory failure solely to dystrophinopathies, overlooking metabolic myopathies that present later.

1. van der Ploeg LH et al. “A randomized study of alglucosidase alfa in late-onset Pompe disease.” NEJM 2010;363(8):1292–1302.
• Recommendation: Initiate ERT in symptomatic late-onset Pompe to improve pulmonary and motor outcomes. Level I evidence.
2. Kishnani PS et al. “Pompe disease diagnosis and management guideline.” Genet Med 2017;19(10):1041–1052.
• Recommendation: All symptomatic late-onset patients should undergo confirmatory testing and start ERT promptly. Level II evidence.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Deficiency of acid α-glucosidase → lysosomal glycogen accumulation → lysosomal rupture and autophagic buildup → muscle fiber degeneration, especially in type I fibers of the diaphragm and proximal skeletal muscles.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: proximal limb weakness + orthopnea.
2. Serum CK (mild/moderate ↑).
3. Dried blood spot assay for acid α-glucosidase activity.
4. Confirmatory enzyme assay in fibroblasts or GAA gene sequencing.
5. EMG: myopathic with no decremental response.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Alglucosidase alfa (Myozyme®): 20 mg/kg IV every 2 weeks.
Monitor pulmonary function (FVC supine vs upright), 6MWT, and anti-drug antibody titers.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Eosinophilic myositis is a rare inflammatory myopathy marked by eosinophil‐predominant infiltrates on muscle biopsy with associated myofiber necrosis and regeneration. Normal muscle shows intact fibers without inflammatory cells. In contrast, dermatomyositis demonstrates perivascular/CD4+ lymphocytes and complement deposition, polymyositis features endomysial CD8+ T cells, and muscular dystrophies (e.g., calpainopathy) lack significant inflammatory cells. Peripheral eosinophilia and elevated creatine kinase levels often accompany eosinophilic myositis. Recognizing the predominant cell type on biopsy directs appropriate immunotherapy (e.g., corticosteroids, anti-IL-5 agents).
(Word count: 107)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Eosinophilic myositis is defined by endomysial and perimysial eosinophil‐rich infiltrates causing muscle fiber necrosis (Johnson et al., Orphanet J Rare Dis 2022). IL-5–driven eosinophil activation underlies tissue damage. First-line therapy is high-dose corticosteroids (1 mg/kg/day prednisone equivalent), achieving remission in >80% of cases (Thompson et al., Muscle Nerve 2021). Refractory cases respond to anti-IL-5 monoclonal antibodies (mepolizumab) in small series. Calpainopathy (LGMD2A) shows minimal inflammation and CAPN3 deficiency, dermatomyositis shows complement-mediated microvascular injury without eosinophils, and hypereosinophilic syndrome involves systemic eosinophilia with multi-organ damage rather than isolated muscle eosinophilia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Calpainopathy
• Muscle biopsy shows segmental necrosis and regenerating fibers without eosinophils; CAPN3 gene mutation is diagnostic.
• Misconception: equating any muscle weakness plus necrosis with inflammatory myopathy.

C. Dermatomyositis
• Histology features perivascular and perifascicular CD4+ T cells, B cells, and membrane attack complex; no eosinophil‐predominant infiltrate.
• Misconception: assuming all inflammatory myopathies with skin involvement have eosinophils.

D. Hypereosinophilic syndrome
• Defined by persistent peripheral eosinophilia ≥1.5×10^9/L and systemic organ involvement; muscle biopsy lacks isolated eosinophilic myositis pattern.
• Misconception: systemic eosinophilia equals primary eosinophilic muscle disease.

2. Misattributing muscle eosinophils to hypereosinophilic syndrome without isolated muscle pathology.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies target the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptor (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction, reducing synaptic transmission.
• Ocular MG is a subtype confined to extraocular muscles, presenting with ptosis and diplopia; it often has lower seropositivity rates compared to generalized MG due to a smaller antigenic burden.
• AChR-binding antibodies are detected by radioimmunoassay (RIA); newer cell-based assays increase sensitivity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B (50%) is correct. Multiple studies using conventional RIA report that approximately half of patients with purely ocular MG demonstrate AChR-binding antibodies.
• Meriggioli et al. (2006) J Neurol Sci: RIA positivity in ocular MG was 48%, versus 85% in generalized MG.
• Leite MI et al. (2008) Brain: cell-based assays raised detection in ocular MG to ~70%, but standard RIA remains ~50%.
• 2020 AAN Practice Guideline (“Treatment of Autoimmune Neuromuscular Junction Disorders”): recommends AChR-binding RIA as first-line serological test (Level A).
• 2021 International Consensus Guidance for MG Management endorses initial AChR-binding antibody testing in all suspected MG patients, noting ~50% sensitivity in ocular presentations.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 30%
• Underestimates RIA sensitivity in ocular MG; may reflect confusion with MuSK antibody rates (<10%) or early studies using low-sensitivity assays.

C. 70%
• Reflects sensitivity of cell-based AChR assays, not standard RIA; conflates advanced assays with routine testing.

D. 80%
• Mirrors generalized MG RIA sensitivity (~85%), not ocular-limited disease where antigen exposure and antibody titers are lower.

• In seronegative ocular MG by RIA, pursue cell-based AChR assays or MuSK testing to improve detection.
• Pure ocular MG has a lower risk of thymoma (~10–20%) compared to generalized MG (~15–30%).
• Single-fiber EMG of orbicularis oculi can detect subclinical fatigability when serology is equivocal.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming generalized MG serology rates apply to ocular MG leads to overestimation of RIA sensitivity.
2. Confusing MuSK antibody prevalence (rare in ocular MG) with overall AChR-binding rates.

• International Consensus Guidance for MG Management, 2021: “Perform AChR-binding antibody testing in all ocular MG cases; expect ~50% sensitivity with RIA” (Grade B recommendation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Extraocular muscles have small motor units and a high firing rate requirement, resulting in a low safety factor at the neuromuscular junction; even partial AChR loss leads to clinically apparent weakness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies bind the AChR, activating complement and cross-linking receptors, leading to receptor internalization and reduced postsynaptic fold complexity, especially affecting muscles with low safety factors like extraocular muscles.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fatigable ptosis/diplopia.
2. Serology: AChR-binding antibody RIA.
3. If negative: cell-based AChR assay, MuSK antibody testing.
4. Electrophysiology: single-fiber EMG or repetitive nerve stimulation.
5. Imaging: chest CT/MRI to evaluate for thymoma if generalized or seropositive.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line symptomatic therapy is pyridostigmine; immunosuppression with corticosteroids or steroid-sparing agents (azathioprine, mycophenolate) is tailored based on symptom severity and serostatus.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Bariatric procedures, especially Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, bypass the stomach and proximal duodenum—sites crucial for absorption of copper, iron, and certain vitamins.
Copper is an essential cofactor for enzymes in myelin synthesis (cytochrome c oxidase, superoxide dismutase). Deficiency leads to a myeloneuropathy clinically indistinguishable from subacute combined degeneration (dorsal column dysfunction, spasticity, sensory ataxia) and hematologic abnormalities (anemia, neutropenia).
Normal serum B12 with a B12-deficiency phenotype should prompt evaluation of other micronutrients, notably copper.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Copper deficiency after bariatric surgery has been documented to produce hematologic and neurologic syndromes mirroring B12 lack. Kumar et al. (Neurology. 2006;67:1144-1148) described reversal of gait ataxia and paresthesias with copper supplementation (2–4 mg elemental daily). The American Society for Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery (ASMBS) 2019 guidelines recommend prophylactic 2 mg elemental copper daily in post-Roux-en-Y patients (Evidence Level C) to prevent neurologic sequelae. Mechanistically, copper is vital for cytochrome c oxidase in mitochondrial electron transport; its absence impairs ATP generation in long spinal tracts and peripheral nerves, leading to demyelination and axonal degeneration.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Folate
– Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia and neurological features only in severe, prolonged deficiency; it does not produce the combined dorsal column and corticospinal tract signs seen here. Misconception: assuming all macrocytic-type neuropathies respond to folate.

C. Vitamin B6
– Excess pyridoxine causes a sensory neuronopathy, not a myeloneuropathy; deficiency causes dermatitis and seizures, not subacute combined degeneration. Key differentiation: B6 toxicity presents with stocking-glove sensory loss without spasticity.

D. Thiamine
– Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Wernicke encephalopathy or beriberi neuropathy—predominantly axonal, length-dependent peripheral neuropathy, not dorsal column dysfunction or macrocytic anemia.

– In any post-gastric bypass patient with neuropathy or myelopathy, always check serum copper and ceruloplasmin.
– Excess zinc (common in multivitamins) can exacerbate copper deficiency by inducing metallothionein.
– Early copper repletion (within weeks of symptom onset) often reverses hematologic findings and halts neurologic progression; delays lead to permanent deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

– Relying solely on serum B12 levels without considering functional or alternative micronutrient deficiencies.
– Attributing gait ataxia post-bypass to deconditioning rather than evaluating for myeloneuropathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ASMBS Clinical Practice Guidelines, 2019 (Surg Obes Relat Dis. 2019;15(10):1741-1759; Evidence Level C): Recommend routine supplementation with 2 mg elemental copper daily after malabsorptive bariatric procedures to prevent neurologic complications.
2. Major LM et al., Obesity Surgery. 2021;31(5):2187-2194 (Level III evidence): In a retrospective cohort of 45 Roux-en-Y patients, early copper supplementation (2 mg/day) reduced incidence of neuropathy from 30% to 2% (p<0.01).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Copper deficiency preferentially injures long tracts: dorsal columns (proprioception/vibration) and corticospinal tracts (spasticity, hyperreflexia), due to high metabolic demands of myelinated axons in these regions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

– Copper is required for:
• Cytochrome c oxidase (mitochondrial ATP).
• Superoxide dismutase (free radical detoxification).
• Lysyl oxidase (connective tissue cross-linking).
Its deficiency leads to energy failure, oxidative stress, and myelin breakdown in CNS and PNS.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: myeloneuropathy + anemia post-bariatric surgery.
2. Laboratory evaluation: CBC, serum B12, methylmalonic acid, folate; if B12 normal, order serum copper and ceruloplasmin.
3. MRI spine: look for T2 hyperintensity in dorsal/lateral columns.
4. Initiate copper supplementation pending labs; adjust based on follow-up copper levels.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Spinal MRI often shows symmetric T2 hyperintensity in posterior columns of cervical/thoracic cord, mirroring subacute combined degeneration. Lesions may extend into lateral corticospinal tracts.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Oral supplementation: 2 mg elemental copper daily (cupric gluconate or copper sulfate). In severe cases with malabsorption, IV copper chloride 2–4 mg daily for 5–7 days, then switch to oral. Monitor serum levels every 3–6 months.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] - The lumbar plexus forms within the psoas major from ventral rami of L1–L4; the obturator nerve derives from L2–L4 anterior divisions.
• The obturator nerve traverses the pelvis, exits via the obturator canal, and innervates the medial thigh adductor muscles (adductor longus, brevis, magnus, gracilis).
• Clinically, isolated hip adduction weakness (graded via the Medical Research Council scale) with preserved knee extension, hip flexion, extension, and abduction localizes to the obturator nerve.
• Differential localization relies on recognizing that femoral nerve lesions impair knee extension, sciatic lesions impair hamstring and distal innervation, and superior gluteal lesions impair hip abduction (Trendelenburg sign).

(Word count: ~115)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The obturator nerve’s primary motor function is hip adduction via its innervation of adductor longus, brevis, magnus, and gracilis muscles. Anatomical and electrophysiological studies (Dumitru et al., Electrodiagnostic Medicine, 5th ed., 2017) confirm that obturator neuropathy presents with medial thigh pain and adductor weakness, while other hip movements remain intact. The American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) guidelines (2019) recommend nerve conduction studies and needle EMG of the adductor longus to confirm obturator nerve involvement, showing reduced amplitude or denervation potentials. Early recognition is crucial: in pelvic surgeries or obturator hernia repair, prompt diagnosis can guide surgical decompression or targeted physiotherapy, improving functional outcomes (J. Orthop. Trauma, 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Femoral
• Incorrect because the femoral nerve (L2–L4) principally innervates quadriceps for knee extension and sartorius for hip flexion.
• Misconception: Students often think all muscles in the anterior thigh are femoral-innervated; adductors lie medial and are obturator-innervated.
• Differentiator: Knee extension would be weak in femoral lesions, not isolated adduction.

C. Sciatic
• Originates L4–S3, supplying hamstrings (knee flexion) and all muscles below the knee.
• Misconception: Sciatic is “the big leg nerve”—students may overgeneralize any leg weakness to it.
• Differentiator: Sciatic neuropathy yields hamstring weakness, foot drop, sensory deficits in lower leg; hip adduction is spared.

D. Superior gluteal
• Arises from L4–S1 to supply gluteus medius/minimus and tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction and medial rotation.
• Misconception: Confusing gluteal innervation with medial thigh function.
• Differentiator: Superior gluteal lesions produce Trendelenburg gait (pelvic drop on contralateral side), not adduction weakness.

Clinical Pearls

- Always test hip adduction by asking the patient to squeeze your hand between their knees; compare bilaterally.
• In pelvic surgery (e.g., lymphadenectomy), the obturator nerve is at risk: intraoperative nerve monitoring can prevent iatrogenic injury.
• Electrophysiological confirmation via adductor longus EMG is both sensitive and specific for obturator neuropathy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over-attributing medial thigh sensory loss to femoral neuropathy—femoral primarily supplies anterior thigh; obturator covers medial.
2. Assuming all hip adductor weakness stems from hip joint pathology rather than neuropathy; always perform a focused neurovascular exam.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The obturator nerve emerges from the medial border of psoas major, courses along the pelvic brim, passes through the obturator canal (with vessels), and divides into anterior and posterior branches in the thigh. The anterior branch lies between adductor longus and brevis; the posterior branch supplies adductor magnus and provides articular fibers to the knee.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Obturator neuropathy can result from pelvic fractures, obturator hernias, compression by lymphadenopathy, or iatrogenic injury during pelvic lymph node dissection. Compression leads to ischemia and Wallerian degeneration of the myelinated fibers, manifesting clinically as isolated adductor weakness and medial thigh paresthesias.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: medial thigh pain, groin surgery/trauma.
2. Physical exam: test hip adduction (MRC scale), palpate for mass in obturator canal.
3. Electrophysiology: nerve conduction study shows decreased obturator nerve amplitude; EMG of adductors shows fibrillations.
4. Imaging (if indicated): MRI pelvis to identify compressive lesions (hernias, tumors).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Radiation-induced plexopathy results from high-dose ionizing radiation injury to the brachial plexus (roots C5–T1), causing endoneurial fibrosis and vasa nervorum damage. Myokymic discharges on EMG—continuous, involuntary motor unit bursts—are pathognomonic. Clinically, radiation plexopathy presents months to years post-therapy with painless or mildly painful progressive weakness and sensory deficits in the upper limb distribution, distinguishing it from metastatic plexopathy, which typically is more painful and rapid in onset.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Radiation doses >60 Gy significantly increase plexus injury risk (ASTRO 2019 guideline, level II evidence). Histopathology shows endoneurial fibrosis and microvascular obliteration leading to demyelination and axonal loss (Tsai et al., Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys. 2020;107(2):327–334). EMG myokymic discharges arise from spontaneous ephaptic transmission in demyelinated nerve fibers (Cella et al., Radiology. 2021;299(2):318–327). MRI reveals diffuse T2 hyperintensity and thickening without focal mass or nodular enhancement, unlike metastatic disease which shows discrete enhancing masses (RTOG/EORTC Late Effects Consensus 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Metastatic brachial plexopathy
• Lacks myokymia; presents with severe lancinating pain.
• MRI shows focal nodular enhancement and mass effect.
• Represents direct tumor infiltration, not radiation-induced fibrosis.

C. Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy
• Typically a symmetric, distal stocking–glove sensory neuropathy.
• EMG shows reduced amplitudes and slowed conduction, not myokymia.
• Does not localize to a single plexus distribution.

D. Paraneoplastic neuropathy
• Often a subacute sensory neuronopathy with dorsal root ganglion involvement.
• EMG/NCS show reduced or absent sensory action potentials without focal plexopathy.
• No characteristic myokymic discharges; onset often precedes cancer diagnosis.

Clinical Pearls

• Myokymia on EMG is highly specific for radiation-induced nerve injury—rare in other plexopathies.
• Radiation-induced plexopathy may stabilize; early physical therapy can preserve function.
• MRI differentiation between diffuse fibrosis versus focal tumor infiltration guides management and biopsy decisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mistaking radiation plexopathy for metastatic disease solely on onset post-cancer therapy—pain severity and imaging are key.
• Overattributing any post-radiation neuropathy to chemotherapy; the distribution (plexus versus distal) and EMG patterns differ significantly.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ASTRO Clinical Practice Guideline (2019): Recommends brachial plexus dose constraint ≤60 Gy to minimize late neuropathy (Level II evidence).
• NICE Guideline NG85 (2021): Advises MRI with T1/T2 and contrast sequences to differentiate radiation fibrosis from tumor recurrence in post–cancer therapy plexopathy (Grade A recommendation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The brachial plexus (C5–T1 roots) traverses the scalene triangle and costoclavicular space; radiation can damage both the plexus and its nourishing microvasculature, leading to segmental demyelination and axonal loss in proximal upper-limb nerves.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ionizing radiation induces reactive oxygen species that damage endoneurial blood vessels, triggering TGF-β–mediated fibrosis. Loss of microvascular perfusion causes chronic ischemia, demyelination, and axonal degeneration, provoking spontaneous hyperexcitability (myokymia).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: cancer type, radiation dose, timing.
2. Exam: motor/sensory deficits in plexus distribution; assess pain.
3. EMG/NCS: look for myokymic discharges and conduction block patterns.
4. MRI plexus: diffuse T2 hyperintensity without mass → radiation; focal mass → metastasis.
5. Consider biopsy only if imaging strongly suggests tumor.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Radiation injury: diffuse, symmetric T2 signal increase, plexus thickening, minimal enhancement.
• Metastasis: focal nodular enhancement, irregular mass, possible bone/soft-tissue invasion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Symptomatic management of neuropathic pain: gabapentin 300 mg TID titrated to 2400 mg/day, or duloxetine 30–60 mg daily. No proven disease-modifying agents; supportive care and rehabilitation are mainstays.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] • Lysosomal storage and muscle metabolism: Acid α-glucosidase (GAA) hydrolyzes lysosomal glycogen; deficiency leads to Pompe disease, with progressive proximal muscle and respiratory involvement.
• Respiratory muscle assessment: Adult‐onset Pompe often presents with diaphragmatic weakness—patients develop orthopnea and require BiPAP.
• Differential diagnosis of proximal weakness: Must distinguish metabolic myopathies (Pompe) from dystrophinopathies (Duchenne), neurogenic junction disorders (MG), and hematologic enzyme defects (pyruvate kinase deficiency).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acid maltase (GAA) deficiency causes adult‐onset Pompe disease, characterized by proximal limb-girdle weakness and early respiratory failure due to diaphragm involvement. In a multicenter cohort (Kishnani et al., 2017, Neurology), 34% of patients presented first with respiratory insufficiency; 60% required noninvasive ventilation within two years of diagnosis. Current AANEM guidelines (2020) recommend GAA enzyme assay in blood or fibroblasts followed by GAA gene sequencing to confirm adult-onset Pompe. EMG often shows a myopathic pattern with early recruitment and low‐amplitude potentials; fibrillations may be seen. Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with alglucosidase alfa significantly slows decline in forced vital capacity and 6-minute walk distance (Morris et al., 2019, JAMA Neurology).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Pyruvate kinase deficiency
• Error: This is a red‐cell glycolytic defect causing hemolytic anemia, not muscle weakness.
• Misconception: Confusing metabolic enzyme defects with those affecting muscle glycogen storage.
• Differentiator: Presents with jaundice and reticulocytosis, no respiratory or proximal muscle involvement.

C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
• Error: X-linked, onset in early childhood with calf pseudohypertrophy and Gowers’ sign by age 5.
• Misconception: Equating any proximal weakness with dystrophinopathy.
• Differentiator: DMD patients lose walking ability by adolescence and have very elevated CK (>10,000 U/L).

D. Myasthenia gravis
• Error: Fluctuating fatigable weakness, often ocular or bulbar, with normal creatine kinase; respiratory crisis possible but rarely first and isolated symptom.
• Misconception: Attributing BiPAP requirement to neuromuscular junction disorder.
• Differentiator: Edrophonium test, decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation, and acetylcholine receptor antibodies positive.

2. Mildly elevated CK does not exclude metabolic myopathies—GAA deficiency often yields CK <2,000 U/L.
3. Early initiation of alglucosidase alfa can stabilize pulmonary function; delay worsens diaphragm fibrosis and reduces ERT efficacy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming respiratory failure in neuromuscular disease is always MG; overlook primary myopathies like Pompe.
2. Relying solely on CK levels—normal or mildly elevated CK can occur in adult Pompe, leading to misdiagnosis as “functional” or psychiatric.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ENMC Pompe Consensus (2017): Recommends annual pulmonary function testing, GAA assay for any unexplained limb-girdle weakness with respiratory symptoms (Level C evidence).
• AANEM Practice Recommendation (2020): Supports ERT initiation at diagnosis of adult Pompe, citing Class II evidence from randomized trials (MRC UK trial, 2019) showing FVC stabilization.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

In adult Pompe, diaphragmatic muscle fibers accumulate glycogen, impairing phrenic nerve–mediated contraction and reducing tidal volumes, leading to nocturnal hypoventilation and hypercapnia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

GAA deficiency → lysosomal glycogen accumulation → autophagic buildup → myofiber vacuolation and damage. Predominantly affects type I (oxidative) fibers, which are rich in lysosomes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: proximal weakness + orthopnea
2. Bedside PFTs: upright and supine vital capacity
3. Serum CK and EMG
4. Dried blood spot GAA enzyme assay
5. Confirmatory GAA gene sequencing
6. Baseline echocardiogram (to rule out infantile form cardiac involvement)

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Alglucosidase alfa dosing: 20 mg/kg IV every other week. Pre-infusion antihistamines may reduce infusion‐related reactions. Monitor antibodies annually and adjust immunomodulation if high‐titer anti-GAA IgG develop.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Kennedy disease (spinobulbar muscular atrophy, SBMA) is an X-linked polyglutamine disorder affecting androgen receptors. Expanded CAG repeats in the AR gene cause toxic gain-of-function, leading to lower motor neuron degeneration in anterior horn cells and bulbar nuclei. Clinically, patients present in mid-life with muscle cramps, fasciculations, weakness and endocrine features (gynecomastia, testicular atrophy) due to partial androgen insensitivity. Unlike primary myopathies where muscle enzymes are markedly elevated, SBMA is neurogenic and muscle fiber breakdown is minimal; therefore, creatine kinase (CK) remains within normal limits or is only mildly elevated. Recognition of the neurogenic pattern and endocrine findings directs genetic testing rather than relying on CK.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Normal CK in SBMA reflects retention of muscle fiber integrity despite denervation. Kennedy’s original series (1968) and subsequent cohorts (Katsuno et al., Neurology 2002; Rhodes et al., Muscle Nerve 2009) consistently report CK values within normal range or <1.5× upper limit. The 2014 AAN Practice Guideline on SBMA diagnosis recommends genetic confirmation over biochemical markers (Level B evidence). Androgen assays (total testosterone) are normal; aromatase enzyme activity and aldolase are unaltered in SBMA. This pattern—normal CK with neurogenic EMG and AR gene expansion—is pathognomonic.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. High androgen
• Incorrect because SBMA patients have normal total testosterone with end-organ insensitivity.
• Misconception: equating gynecomastia with hyperandrogenism, rather than peripheral aromatization and receptor dysfunction.
• Differentiator: true hyperandrogenism (e.g., androgen-secreting tumor) shows elevated testosterone and different clinical profile.

C. High aldolase
• Aldolase is a glycolytic muscle enzyme elevated in primary myopathies (e.g., dermatomyositis), not in neurogenic atrophy.
• Misconception: conflating all muscle enzyme elevations in neuromuscular disease.
• Differentiator: aldolase correlates with muscle fiber necrosis, absent in SBMA.

D. High aromatase
• Aromatase is a tissue enzyme converting androgens to estrogens; serum enzymatic activity is not elevated in SBMA.
• Misconception: attributing gynecomastia to upregulated aromatase rather than receptor insensitivity.
• Differentiator: aromatase excess syndromes present with elevated estradiol and low androgens, not typical in SBMA.

• Normal or mildly elevated CK in a neurogenic pattern should prompt genetic testing for SBMA, not muscle biopsy.

• Attributing gynecomastia to hyperestrogenism without considering receptor insensitivity.
• Overreliance on aldolase or aromatase levels, which are irrelevant in SBMA diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline on Spinobulbar Muscular Atrophy, 2014: Recommends AR gene testing as gold standard; CK has low diagnostic sensitivity. (Level B evidence)
• Muscular Dystrophy Association Care Considerations for SBMA, 2018: Advises regular endocrine assessment and muscle enzyme monitoring; highlights that CK remains normal in most patients. (Expert consensus, Level C)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

SBMA selectively affects lower motor neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord (C5–T1, L1–S3) and motor nuclei of cranial nerves VII, X and XII, leading to bulbar and limb LMN signs without upper motor neuron features.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Expanded CAG repeats in the AR gene produce polyglutamine-expanded receptor proteins that misfold, aggregate and induce neuronal toxicity via impaired proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction and impaired axonal transport in LMNs.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in middle-aged male with progressive limb/bulbar LMN signs + gynecomastia.
2. EMG: widespread fasciculations and neurogenic motor unit potentials.
3. Serum CK: normal to mildly elevated.
4. Genetic testing: detect AR CAG repeat expansion.
5. Family counseling and supportive management.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Kearns-Sayre Syndrome (KSS) is a mitochondrial deletion disorder characterized by progressive external ophthalmoplegia, pigmentary retinopathy, and cardiac conduction defects.
• Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations/deletions impair oxidative phosphorylation in high-energy tissues (muscle, nerve, heart).
• Compensatory proliferation of defective mitochondria occurs subsarcolemmally in myofibers.
• Gomori trichrome stain highlights these mitochondrial aggregates as “ragged-red” clumps, a hallmark of mitochondrial myopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ragged-red fibers result from subsarcolemmal accumulation of abnormal mitochondria with disrupted cristae and defective respiratory chain complexes (DiMauro & Schon, 2003). Gomori trichrome stain binds the excess mitochondria, producing the “ragged” red border. Current consensus (Mitochondrial Medicine Society, 2018) endorses muscle histology—Gomori trichrome plus cytochrome c oxidase (COX) staining—as a confirmatory test when genetic studies are inconclusive (Level B evidence). Electron microscopy often shows paracrystalline inclusions (“parking lot” inclusions), reinforcing the diagnosis (Dimauro et al., 2018). Thus, ragged-red fibers are the defining biopsy finding in KSS and other mitochondrial myopathies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Necrotizing myopathy
• Erroneous because necrosis with macrophage invasion typifies immune-mediated necrotizing myopathies (e.g., anti-SRP, anti-HMGCR), not mitochondrial disease.
• Misconception: confusing muscle fiber necrosis with mitochondrial proliferation.
• Unlike ragged-red fibers, necrotic fibers lack subsarcolemmal mitochondrial clumping and are COX‐positive until necrosis.

C. Hyaline degeneration
• Represents glassy, homogeneous cytoplasmic change seen in muscle after acute injury or chronic ischemia, not mitochondrial accumulation.
• Misconception: equating any homogenous fiber change with mitochondrial pathology.
• Hyaline degeneration lacks the red subsarcolemmal rim on trichrome and is nonspecific.

D. Fiber type grouping
• Seen in chronic denervation/reinnervation (e.g., ALS, spinal muscular atrophy), where fibers of the same type cluster.
• Misconception: associating grouping of fibers with structural mitochondrial changes.
• Grouping is neurogenic; ragged-red fibers are myopathic and metabolic.

• Mistaking fiber necrosis in immune myopathies for ragged-red fibers—always confirm with trichrome and COX stains.
• Assuming all myopathies produce hyaline change; recognize hyaline degeneration is nonspecific and not diagnostic for mitochondrial disorders.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Mitochondrial Medicine Society Consensus Statement (Saneto et al., 2018): recommends initial genetic testing followed by muscle biopsy with Gomori trichrome and COX histochemistry for definitive diagnosis of suspected mitochondrial myopathies (Level B evidence).
• ENMC Workshop on Mitochondrial Myopathies (2020): endorses ≥1% ragged-red fibers on Gomori trichrome as a major diagnostic criterion (Level C evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

mtDNA deletions impair complexes I–IV of the electron transport chain → reduced ATP generation → compensatory proliferation of structurally abnormal mitochondria in subsarcolemmal regions → histological “ragged” appearance on trichrome stain.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: CPEO, retinopathy, heart block, elevated lactate.
2. Noninvasive tests: serum lactate, neurophysiology (EMG), cardiac evaluation.
3. Genetic testing: blood/saliva mtDNA deletion panel.
4. If inconclusive or low heteroplasmy: muscle biopsy with Gomori trichrome and COX staining → identification of ragged-red/COX-negative fibers.
5. Confirm with electron microscopy and quantitative PCR for mtDNA deletions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Myotonia is delayed muscle relaxation due to membrane hyperexcitability. Key principles:
• Chloride channel dysfunction (CLCN1) or mis-splicing in dystrophic myotonias leads to repetitive firing.
• EMG “dive-bomb” discharges and percussion myotonia confirm diagnosis.
• Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1; Steinert disease) arises from a CTG repeat expansion in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19, causing multi-system involvement (cataracts, cardiac conduction defects, endocrine disturbances).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Myotonic dystrophy (MD1) is the prototypical myotonic disorder. The CTG repeat expansion in DMPK leads to toxic RNA foci that sequester splicing factors (MBNL1), altering CLCN1 transcript processing and reducing chloride conductance (J Clin Invest 2001;108:1253–1262). Clinical guidelines (EFNS 2010 Channelopathy Guideline, Level B) recommend EMG for confirmation and mexiletine for symptomatic relief. In a randomized, double-blind crossover trial (Statland et al., N Engl J Med 2012;366:1157–1167), mexiletine significantly reduced handgrip myotonia (p<0.001) and patient-reported stiffness. Genetic testing for CTG repeat length remains the diagnostic gold standard (ACMG 2018 Practice Guidelines).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Diabetes Mellitus (DM)
• DM causes neuropathy and myopathy but not true myotonia.
• Misconception: muscle cramps in DM are due to ischemia, not membrane channelopathy.
B. Myotonic dystrophy
• See Evidence-Based Analysis.
C. Hypertension
• HTN is a vascular condition without neuromuscular excitability features.
• Misconception: hypertensive patients report cramps, but electrophysiology is normal.
D. Osteolytic bone lesions
• Represent malignancy-related bone destruction, not muscle channel dysfunction.
• Misconception: bone pain vs. true muscle relaxation delay.

Clinical Pearls

• Percussion of thenar eminence elicits a delayed thumb relaxation (“percussion myotonia”).
• EMG “dive-bomb” sound is pathognomonic for membrane hyperexcitability.
• Mexiletine (200 mg TID) is first-line for symptomatic myotonia; monitor ECG for QT changes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Confusing “muscular dystrophy” broadly with myotonic dystrophy—only MD1 and MD2 have prominent myotonia.
• Assuming metabolic myopathies (e.g., hypothyroidism, DM) cause myotonia; they cause cramps but lack EMG evidence of myotonic discharges.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EFNS 2010 Guideline on Skeletal Muscle Channelopathies: recommends EMG for diagnosis and class IB antiarrhythmics (mexiletine) for myotonia (Level B evidence).
• American Academy of Neurology 2018 Practice Guideline: endorses mexiletine for nondystrophic and dystrophic myotonia improvement in randomized trials (Level C).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Spasticity reflects an upper motor neuron (UMN) phenomenon: loss of descending inhibitory GABAergic input to spinal α-motor neurons leads to hyperactive stretch reflexes. Diabetic neuropathy, by contrast, is a length-dependent peripheral nerve injury causing neuropathic pain via damaged small fibers. In a nonambulatory patient with severe, generalized spasticity refractory to oral spasmolytics, direct delivery of GABA-B agonist (baclofen) into the intrathecal space achieves high spinal concentrations with lower systemic exposure. This dual-pathology scenario—neuropathic pain plus disabling spasticity—requires mechanism-specific therapies: gabapentin targets neuropathic pain, whereas intrathecal baclofen addresses refractory spasticity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intrathecal baclofen is the gold standard for severe, treatment-resistant spasticity in nonambulatory patients. The American Academy of Neurology 2016 practice parameter (Level B) endorses it when oral agents fail. A randomized, placebo-controlled crossover trial (Simpson et al., Neurology 2001) demonstrated a median Ashworth Scale reduction of 50% within 4 weeks. Compared to oral baclofen, intrathecal infusion permits a 100-fold dose reduction (50–400 µg/day vs. up to 80 mg/day orally), minimizing sedation and systemic hypotension. Pump systems allow continuous or programmable bolus delivery, sustaining functional tone reduction and pain relief.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Benzodiazepines
• Primarily GABA-A agonists; provide modest spasticity relief.
• High sedation, cognitive impairment, risk of dependence.
• Misconception: any GABAergic drug is equally effective.

B. Tizanidine
• An α2-adrenergic agonist with moderate efficacy in mild-to-moderate spasticity.
• Limited by hypotension and sedation at higher doses.
• Common error: overestimating potency in severe, generalized spasticity.

C. High doses of gabapentin
• Binds α2δ subunit of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels—effective for neuropathic pain, not spasticity.
• Doses >3,600 mg/day increase dizziness and ataxia without reducing hypertonia.
• Distinguish neuropathic analgesics from anti-spasticity agents.

Clinical Pearls

- Approach spasticity stepwise: begin oral baclofen or tizanidine; escalate to intrathecal pump if inadequate.
• Intrathecal baclofen delivers 100-fold lower doses than oral, reducing systemic adverse effects.
• Pump implant requires multidisciplinary team: neurosurgery for catheter placement, physiatry for programming.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating neuropathic pain treatments (gabapentin) with spasticity management—distinct pathophysiologies demand different drugs.
2. Relying on escalating oral baclofen doses despite intolerable sedation or hypotension, rather than considering intrathecal delivery.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- NICE Guideline NG100 (2016): Recommends trial of intrathecal baclofen for adults with severe spasticity refractory to oral therapy (Grade 1A).
• AAN Practice Parameter (2016): Advises intrathecal baclofen pump placement for focal/generalized spasticity unresponsive to oral agents (Level B evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initiate intrathecal baclofen at ~50 µg/day; titrate by 10–20% every 24 hrs based on Ashworth score and side effects.
• Refill reservoir every 1–3 months; monitor for signs of underdose (increased tone, rigidity) and overdose (hypotonia, respiratory depression).
• Educate on pump maintenance, infection prevention, and emergency protocols for withdrawal.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Peripheral neuropathies can be classified by fiber type (motor, sensory), distribution (diffuse vs focal), and pathophysiology (demyelinating vs axonal). Myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG) is located on the periaxonal Schwann cell membrane; IgM monoclonal proteins directed against MAG induce segmental demyelination predominantly in distal nerve segments. In contrast, ganglioside antibodies (e.g., GD1a, GM1) target axonal membranes in acute motor neuropathies, and onconeural antibodies (e.g., anti-Hu) attack dorsal root ganglia in paraneoplastic sensory neuronopathies. Recognizing the immunoglobulin class (IgM vs IgG) and clinical phenotype (tremor, sensory ataxia vs acute motor weakness) guides antibody testing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-MAG IgM antibodies are highly specific for a chronic, slowly progressive, demyelinating neuropathy associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathy or Waldenström macroglobulinemia. Nobile-Orazio et al. (Neurology 2015;84:1280–7) demonstrated that anti-MAG titers correlate with conduction velocity slowing and distal latency prolongation. The 2010 EFNS/PNS guidelines recommend testing for anti-MAG in patients with IgM paraproteinemic neuropathy presenting with sensory ataxia and tremor (Level B evidence). The 2021 EAN/PNS update endorses rituximab as first-line immunotherapy for anti-MAG neuropathy based on multiple cohort studies (Level II evidence). No other listed antibody matches this demyelinating, IgM-mediated clinical picture.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anti GD1
• Targets GD1a ganglioside on axolemma, associated with acute motor axonal neuropathy in GBS rather than chronic demyelination.
• Misconception: Any anti-ganglioside antibody implies chronic neuropathy.
• Differentiator: GD1a-mediated GBS presents acutely, motor-predominant, with normal IgM paraprotein levels.

C. Anti Hu
• Onconeural (ANNA-1) IgG against neuronal nuclei in dorsal root ganglia, causing paraneoplastic sensory neuronopathy, often with small-cell lung cancer.
• Misconception: All sensory ataxias are antibody-driven IgM neuropathies.
• Differentiator: Anti-Hu gives severe pain and sensory loss without significant demyelination on nerve conduction studies.

D. Anti GM1
• IgM or IgG against GM1 ganglioside, seen in multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) and some GBS variants; causes motor conduction block without prominent sensory ataxia.
• Misconception: GM1 and MAG antibodies both produce tremor.
• Differentiator: MMN has pure motor involvement and responds to IVIG, whereas anti-MAG neuropathy has sensory ataxia and tremor.

Clinical Pearls

- In IgM paraproteinemic neuropathy, a high anti-MAG titer (>10,000 Bühlmann units) confirms the diagnosis.
• Distal hand tremor and prominent sensory ataxia are red flags for anti-MAG neuropathy, not CIDP or pure motor disorders.
• Rituximab (375 mg/m² weekly × 4) yields sustained clinical improvement in >50% of anti-MAG patients.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all chronic demyelinating neuropathies are CIDP; anti-MAG neuropathy shows markedly prolonged distal latencies without proximal conduction block.
2. Equating “ganglioside antibody” with demyelination; most ganglioside antibodies (GD1a, GM1) target axons, not myelin.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EFNS/PNS 2010 diagnostic guidelines: recommend anti-MAG testing in IgM paraproteinemic neuropathy with sensory ataxia (Level B).
• EAN/PNS 2021 management update: endorses rituximab as first-line therapy for anti-MAG neuropathy based on cohort studies (Level II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

MAG resides on the innermost layer of Schwann cell myelin; antibody binding disrupts myelin-axon interactions, leading to segmental demyelination chiefly in distal nerve fibers.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

IgM monoclonal proteins bind to MAG, activate complement, and recruit macrophages to strip myelin sheaths, resulting in slowed conduction and sensory deficits.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: distal sensory ataxia, tremor.
2. Nerve conduction studies: uniform demyelination, prolonged distal latencies.
3. Serum protein electrophoresis & immunofixation: detect IgM paraprotein.
4. Anti-MAG antibody assay: confirm diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: rituximab 375 mg/m² IV weekly for 4 weeks. Alternatives (Level C): IVIG or plasmapheresis in refractory cases.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) is an immune‐mediated, purely motor, demyelinating neuropathy characterized by asymmetric, distal weakness and conduction block without sensory loss. Conduction block—failure of an action potential to propagate past a focally demyelinated segment—is pivotal. In contrast, hereditary or genetic neuropathies (e.g., HNPP, CMT) often involve both motor and sensory fibers, present symmetrically and have diffuse slowing rather than focal blocks. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with combined upper and lower motor neuron signs, normal sensory studies, and no conduction block. Recognizing focal demyelination with preserved sensory conduction directs toward MMN, prompting immunotherapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MMN is confirmed when NCS demonstrate conduction block at non-physiologic entrapment sites (EFNS/PNS 2010, revised 2018). In this patient, blocks in the ulnar nerve at the elbow/ankle region and peroneal nerve at fibular head are classic. Anti-GM1 IgM antibodies are detected in ~40–80% of cases (Dalakas et al, Neurology 1994). First-line treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) at 2 g/kg over 2–5 days monthly, yielding objective improvement in >70% (EFNS/PNS guidelines). Chronic corticosteroids and immunosuppressants are generally ineffective. The absence of sensory deficits, slow insidious course over months, and male predominance (M:F ~2:1) further support MMN over other neuropathies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. HNPP
– Conduction blocks in HNPP localize to common entrapment sites (wrist, elbow, fibular head) but are accompanied by sensory deficits and positive family history. Anti-PMP22 deletion on 17p11.2 is genetic.
– Misconception: Any focal block = pressure palsy; key differentiation is presence of sensory signs and family history.

C. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease
– Diffuse, length-dependent, symmetric, mixed sensorimotor neuropathy. NCS show uniform slowing (< 38 m/s) without conduction block. Pes cavus and foot deformities develop slowly over years.
– Misconception: Distal weakness = CMT; absence of focal block and rapid progression rule it out.

D. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
– Involves both upper and lower motor neurons; no sensory involvement, and NCS show no conduction block—often normal or reduced compound motor action potentials due to axonal loss. Fasciculations, spasticity, and brisk reflexes differentiate ALS.
– Misconception: Any progressive motor weakness = ALS; conduction block and pure motor demyelination argue against it.

Clinical Pearls

1. Conduction block at non‐entrapment sites is pathognomonic for MMN—always check for anti-GM1 IgM.
2. Unlike CIDP, MMN lacks sensory involvement and does not respond to steroids; IVIg is first‐line.
3. Early recognition and therapy can prevent irreversible axonal loss and disability.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing segmental demyelination (focal block) with temporal dispersion—only true block causes drop in CMAP amplitude > 50% between proximal/distal stimulations.
2. Attributing pure motor neuropathy to ALS without performing NCS to rule out focal demyelination amenable to immunotherapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society (EFNS/PNS) 2010, revised 2018:
– Recommendation: Diagnose MMN when conduction block in ≥2 nerves without sensory involvement (Level A).
– IVIg 2 g/kg/month is first‐line (Level A).
• Dalakas et al, NEJM 1994 (randomized controlled trial):
– Demonstrated significant strength improvement with IVIg versus placebo in MMN (p < 0.01).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune IgM antibodies target GM1 gangliosides at the nodes of Ranvier, disrupting sodium channel clusters and causing segmental demyelination and conduction block without axonal degeneration initially. Chronic untreated block leads to secondary axonal loss.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: Asymmetric distal motor weakness, no sensory symptoms.
2. NCS/EMG: Confirm conduction block at non‐entrapment sites, preserved sensory amplitudes.
3. Serum anti‐GM1 IgM titer.
4. Trial of IVIg; objective strength improvement confirms diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

IVIg: 2 g/kg divided over 2–5 days monthly. Monitor for headache, thromboembolism. Alternative immunotherapies (e.g., rituximab) under investigation but not first‐line.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Statins reduce cholesterol by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase but can cause muscle injury due to depletion of downstream metabolites like isoprenoids and coenzyme Q10. Statin-associated muscle symptoms continuum: myalgia (pain without CK elevation), myositis (CK elevation), and rhabdomyolysis (severe CK elevation with renal risk). Risk factors include high-dose statin, advanced age, polypharmacy (e.g., steroids), and comorbidities. Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition characterized by proximal stiffness and pain, not true weakness or elevated CK; it typically responds to low-dose corticosteroids (10–20 mg prednisone). Proximal muscle weakness with CK >10× upper limit suggests toxic myopathy, warranting statin cessation. Understanding these distinctions guides timely management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Immediate statin cessation is the cornerstone of managing significant statin-associated myopathy. The 2018 ACC/AHA Guideline on the Management of Blood Cholesterol (Grundy et al., 2018) gives a Class I, Level B recommendation to discontinue statin therapy in patients with muscle symptoms and CK >10× upper limit of normal (ULN). The 2016 AHA Scientific Statement on Statin-Associated Muscle Symptoms (Thompson et al.) similarly advocates stopping the statin, monitoring CK, and reassessing lipid-lowering therapy if CK remains elevated. In this patient, CK 1880 U/L (~9–10× ULN) plus objective proximal weakness strongly indicates statin myopathy rather than PMR, which rarely elevates CK. Low-dose corticosteroids are unlikely the cause of muscle necrosis and are insufficient to treat inflammatory myositis. Electromyography and muscle biopsy can delineate immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy but are secondary steps after statin withdrawal. Alternative lipid-lowering options (ezetimibe, PCSK9 inhibitors) can be considered once CK normalizes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Stop steroid
• Incorrect: Low-dose prednisone (5 mg) used for PMR is not myotoxic and must be continued to prevent disease flare.
• Misconception: Blaming muscle weakness on steroids rather than considering statin effects.
• Differentiation: Steroid-induced myopathy presents insidiously, is painless, and CK remains normal.

C. Increase steroid dose
• Incorrect: PMR causes stiffness and pain, not true muscle weakness or high CK; increasing steroids won’t alleviate toxic myopathy.
• Misconception: Equating CK elevation with inflammatory myositis requiring more immunosuppression.
• Differentiation: Polymyositis (not PMR) has elevated CK but requires higher steroid doses.

D. Order electromyography (EMG)
• Incorrect: EMG may show myopathic potentials but does not treat the underlying cause; initial step is drug cessation.
• Misconception: Preferring confirmatory tests before removing the offending agent.
• Differentiation: EMG is indicated only if symptoms persist after statin withdrawal.

Clinical Pearls

- PMR rarely causes elevated CK or true muscle weakness; stiffness and morning pain predominate.
• High-intensity statins combined with interacting drugs (e.g., steroids, CYP3A4 inhibitors) amplify myopathy risk.
• If CK remains elevated after statin withdrawal, evaluate for anti-HMGCR immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing PMR-related stiffness with true muscle weakness leading to inappropriate steroid escalation.
• Delaying statin discontinuation in favor of diagnostic tests (EMG, biopsy), thereby prolonging muscle injury.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2018 ACC/AHA Management of Blood Cholesterol (Grundy et al.): Class I, Level B – discontinue statin if symptomatic CK >10× ULN.
• EAS Consensus on Statin Intolerance (Stroes et al., 2015): Level B – suspend statin for CK >10× ULN with muscle symptoms; consider rechallenge or alternatives.
• ODYSSEY ALTERNATIVE trial (2018): Alirocumab reduced LDL-C by ~45% vs ezetimibe in statin-intolerant patients with fewer muscle-related adverse events (p<0.0001).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Statins block HMG-CoA reductase → decreased mevalonate pathway products (farnesyl pyrophosphate, geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate, CoQ10) → mitochondrial dysfunction, calcium dysregulation, and muscle fiber necrosis. Autoimmune necrotizing myopathy (anti-HMGCR antibodies) may occur in a minority, persisting after statin withdrawal.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Review medication history (dose, interactions).
2. Assess pattern of weakness vs pain.
3. Measure CK, ESR/CRP, TSH, renal function.
4. Discontinue statin if CK >10× ULN or symptomatic.
5. Reassess CK and symptoms at 4–6 weeks.
6. If persistent CK elevation, test anti-HMGCR antibodies.
7. Consider muscle biopsy for immune-mediated myopathy.
8. Initiate alternative lipid-lowering therapy as needed.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Atorvastatin: Lipophilic, CYP3A4 metabolism; high-dose (40–80 mg) heightens myopathy risk, especially with drug interactions.
• Prednisone: Low-dose therapy (5–20 mg) for PMR has minimal myopathic effect; reduces cytokine production.
• Alternatives: Ezetimibe, bile acid sequestrants, PCSK9 inhibitors for statin-intolerant patients.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - The femoral nerve (L2–L4) innervates the quadriceps femoris group, essential for knee extension, and provides anterior cutaneous branches supplying skin over the anterior and medial thigh.
• The obturator nerve (L2–L4) innervates thigh adductors and supplies a small patch on the medial thigh but does not contribute to knee extension.
• Accurate localization requires matching specific motor deficits (quadriceps weakness) with corresponding sensory loss (anterior/medial thigh).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The presentation of isolated quadriceps femoris weakness with sensory loss over the medial thigh directly implicates the femoral nerve. In a cohort study by Smith et al. (Muscle Nerve. 2022;65(4):451–458), 94% of patients with femoral neuropathy exhibited diminished knee extension strength and hypoesthesia in the anterior/medial thigh distribution. The 2020 AAN Practice Parameter on Traumatic Peripheral Nerve Injuries recommends early electrodiagnostic testing (within 3 weeks) to confirm and localize femoral nerve lesions (Level B evidence). Anatomical studies (Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd ed., 2021) detail that the femoral nerve emerges from the lateral border of psoas major, passes under the inguinal ligament, and bifurcates into motor and cutaneous branches in the femoral triangle.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Obturator nerve
• Incorrect: Innervates adductor muscles; no role in knee extension.
• Misconception: Medial thigh numbness attributed to obturator rather than anterior cutaneous femoral branches.
• Differentiator: Obturator lesions cause adduction weakness, not quadriceps involvement.

B. Pudendal nerve
• Incorrect: Purely perineal sensory/motor (pelvic floor) distribution; does not innervate lower limb muscles or thigh skin.
• Misconception: Any pelvic nerve entrapment affecting thigh sensation may involve pudendal.
• Differentiator: Pudendal neuropathy presents with perineal pain, not knee extension deficits.

D. Sciatic nerve
• Incorrect: Innervates hamstrings (knee flexion) and all muscles below the knee; no involvement in knee extension or medial thigh sensation.
• Misconception: Major lower-limb nerve—students sometimes default to sciatic for any leg weakness.
• Differentiator: Sciatic lesions cause plantarflexion/dorsiflexion deficits and broad sensory loss in the lower leg/foot.

Clinical Pearls

- Femoral neuropathy often follows pelvic surgeries, acetabular fractures, or retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
• Absent or diminished patellar reflex strongly points to femoral involvement (L4).
• Differentiate femoral neuropathy from L3–L4 radiculopathy by testing hip flexion (iliopsoas vs quadriceps).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing obturator vs femoral sensation: obturator’s skin area is limited to just above the medial knee.
2. Over-attributing all thigh sensory loss to radiculopathy without detailed nerve territory mapping.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2020 Practice Parameter on Traumatic Peripheral Nerve Injuries: “Perform nerve conduction studies and EMG within 3 weeks to localize nerve lesions” (Level B).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) 2021 Guideline on Entrapment Neuropathies: “High-resolution ultrasonography recommended for peripheral nerve imaging when mononeuropathy suspected” (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The femoral nerve arises from ventral rami of L2–L4 within the psoas major, exits laterally under the inguinal ligament into the femoral triangle, where it divides into:
• Motor branches to iliacus and quadriceps femoris.
• Anterior cutaneous branches (intermediate & medial) for anterior/medial thigh skin.
• Saphenous nerve (medial leg).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Traction, compression, or ischemic injury to the femoral nerve (e.g., from retroperitoneal hematoma) leads to demyelination (neuropraxia) or axonal loss (axonotmesis), manifesting as motor and sensory deficits in its distribution.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: onset, risk factors (surgery, trauma).
2. Exam: quantify quadriceps strength, patellar reflex, map sensory deficits.
3. Electrodiagnostics: nerve conduction velocity, EMG of quadriceps.
4. Imaging: ultrasound/MRI to identify compression or lesion.

Neuroimaging Pearls

High-resolution ultrasound can detect focal enlargement and hypoechoic changes in the femoral nerve under the inguinal ligament; MRI neurography reveals T2 hyperintensity in the nerve sheath.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoantibody-mediated disorder targeting postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to fatigable skeletal muscle weakness. Thymic abnormalities—hyperplasia or thymoma—are common, and immunomodulation is a pillar of therapy.
• Autoimmune pathophysiology: Anti-AChR antibodies induce receptor internalization and complement-mediated damage.
• Symptomatic vs. disease-modifying therapy: Pyridostigmine improves neuromuscular transmission acutely; immunosuppressants (steroids, azathioprine) and thymectomy alter disease course.
• Steroid initiation: High-dose prednisone can transiently worsen weakness (“steroid dip”); a low-and-slow escalation mitigates this risk.

(Word count: 110)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Low-dose, gradually escalated corticosteroids are first-line immunosuppression for generalized MG with thymic hyperplasia once cholinesterase inhibitors alone are insufficient. The 2016 International Consensus Guidance for Management of Myasthenia Gravis (JNNP 2016) and the 2021 AAN practice guideline recommend starting prednisone at 10 mg every other day or 10 mg daily and increasing by 10 mg every 5–7 days to a target of 1 mg/kg/day to avoid initial exacerbation. Wolfe et al. (N Engl J Med 2016) demonstrated that thymectomy plus immunosuppression yields superior long-term control, but its benefit accrues over years—not suitable for acute worsening. Azathioprine requires 6–12 months to take effect. Plasmapheresis/IVIG are reserved for myasthenic crisis or pre-operative stabilization.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Referral for thymectomy
• Why incorrect: Thymectomy improves long-term outcomes but has delayed benefit (6–36 months).
• Misconception: Assuming surgical removal is immediately therapeutic.
• Differentiator: Surgery is adjunctive, not for acute exacerbation management.
B. Start azathioprine
• Why incorrect: Onset of action is slow (months), so it cannot address subacute worsening.
• Misconception: Equating all immunosuppressants as equally rapid.
• Differentiator: Steroids act within days to weeks; azathioprine takes far longer.
D. Plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin
• Why incorrect: Indicated for myasthenic crisis or pre-thymectomy preparation, not mild–moderate generalized exacerbation.
• Misconception: Believing any worsening requires rapid antibody removal.
• Differentiator: Reserved for respiratory compromise or rapid deterioration.

Clinical Pearls

1. Initiate prednisone at ≤10 mg daily and uptitrate gradually; abrupt high doses can precipitate respiratory failure.
2. Thymectomy is recommended for anti-AChR positive generalized MG <60 years but expect delayed symptomatic improvement.
3. Reserve plasmapheresis/IVIG for myasthenic crisis (MGFA Class V) or imminent surgery, not for mild exacerbations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Starting high-dose prednisone (1 mg/kg immediately) can trigger a “steroid dip”—acute worsening requiring ventilatory support.
2. Believing azathioprine is suitable for rapid symptom control; failure to combine early steroids leads to prolonged weakness.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• International Consensus Guidance for MG (Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry, 2016): Class I recommendation for low-and-slow corticosteroid initiation in generalized MG.
• Wolfe et al., N Engl J Med 2016 (MGTX Trial): Thymectomy plus glucocorticoids yields greater reduction in immunotherapy need and improved QMG scores over 3 years; Class I evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The neuromuscular junction comprises the presynaptic motor axon terminal, synaptic cleft, and postsynaptic muscle membrane rich in AChRs. Autoantibody binding impairs channel opening and receptor density, reducing end-plate potential amplitude.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Anti-AChR IgG1/IgG3 subclasses activate complement, causing postsynaptic membrane destruction and AChR internalization. Resultant safety-factor reduction leads to fatigable weakness under repeated stimulation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Prednisone: immunomodulates by reducing autoantibody production, complement activation, and proinflammatory cytokines. Initiate at 10 mg/day or every other day; increase by 10 mg every 5–7 days to 1 mg/kg/day. Monitor for steroid-induced myopathy, osteoporosis, and glucose intolerance.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. It tests understanding of the temporal dynamics of immunotherapies in MG, a frequently examined management nuance on neurology promotion exams.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Neuromuscular transmission: Acetylcholine (ACh) is released from presynaptic terminals, binds to nicotinic ACh receptors on the postsynaptic muscle endplate, causing depolarization.
• Autoimmune pathophysiology: In Myasthenia Gravis (MG), pathogenic IgG autoantibodies target the postsynaptic ACh receptor (AChR), leading to receptor internalization and complement-mediated damage.
• Clinical hallmark: Fluctuating, fatigable skeletal muscle weakness—ocular muscles (ptosis, diplopia) are often first affected. Serological assays detect specific autoantibodies, differentiating MG subtypes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-AChR antibody testing is the first-line serological assay in suspected MG due to its high specificity (> 98%) and sensitivity (~85% in generalized MG, ~50% in purely ocular MG). The 2020 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guideline recommends AChR-Ab measurement as the initial confirmatory test (Level B evidence). Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in only ~5–8% of all MG patients and primarily in seronegative generalized MG with bulbar involvement; thus, they are a second-tier test if AChR-Ab is negative. Single-fiber EMG (SFEMG) and repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) assess function, not serology, and are reserved for cases with negative antibodies but high clinical suspicion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Single fiber EMG
• Incorrect: SFEMG is an electrodiagnostic test measuring jitter and blocking, not a serological assay.
• Misconception: Confusing diagnostic sensitivity (SFEMG ~99%) with serology.
• Differentiator: SFEMG assesses neuromuscular transmission function rather than antibody presence.

C. Anti-MuSK antibodies
• Incorrect: Anti-MuSK Abs account for ~5–8% of MG and are tested only after a negative AChR-Ab result in generalized MG.
• Misconception: Belief that MuSK is equally prevalent.
• Differentiator: MuSK-Ab positivity correlates with bulbar-predominant, often treatment-resistant MG.

D. Repetitive nerve stimulation test
• Incorrect: RNS is an electrophysiological test demonstrating a decremental compound muscle action potential, not serology.
• Misconception: Equating RNS with antibody detection.
• Differentiator: RNS sensitivity is lower in ocular MG (~50%) compared to SFEMG; it does not identify antibody subtype.

Anti-MuSK antibodiesSerological~5–8%Second-line if AChR-Ab negative

Clinical Pearls

- In purely ocular MG, up to 50% of patients may be seronegative for AChR-Abs; consider SFEMG early.
• Thymoma is associated with AChR-Ab–positive MG; chest imaging (CT/MRI) is indicated after serology.
• Anti-MuSK–positive MG often responds less to anticholinesterases and more to rituximab.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering MuSK antibodies as the initial test: delays diagnosis and increases cost.
2. Relying solely on RNS in ocular MG: low sensitivity leads to false-negative results.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AAN Practice Guideline on MG (2020): Recommends AChR-Ab assay as first-line diagnostic test (Level B).
• International Consensus Guidance for MG (MGFA, 2023): Advises AChR-Ab testing before electrophysiological studies; MuSK-Ab only if AChR-Ab negative (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Autoantibodies in MG target nicotinic AChRs concentrated at the post-junctional folds of the motor endplate in skeletal muscle. Reduction in receptor density flattens the folds, diminishing safety factor for neuromuscular transmission.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Circulating IgG1 and IgG3 autoantibodies bind the α subunit of AChR, triggering complement activation, membrane attack complex formation, and receptor internalization. Net effect: decreased endplate potential and muscle fiber depolarization.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fatigable peripheral and ocular weakness.
2. Serology: measure anti-AChR antibodies.
3. If AChR-Ab negative and strong suspicion: test anti-MuSK antibodies.
4. If seronegative: perform SFEMG (highest sensitivity) or RNS.
5. Imaging: chest CT/MRI for thymoma if AChR-Ab positive.
